Document 1 of 487

Introduction: Diversity and Development

Author: Faulkner, Audrey1; Roberts-DeGennaro, Maria; Weil, Marie1 c/o Weil -- School Social Work CB#3550 U North Carolina, Chapel Hill 27599-3550

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61611137?accountid=14667

Abstract: Introduces this journal issue (see related abstracts in SOPODA 17:1) exploring issues related to cultural diversity & community development. Together the articles provide significant guidance for further work in theory construction & curriculum development, & offer direction for effective practice & research. Leadership development, self-help, & empowerment practice approaches are presented for work in neo-gemeinschaft ethnic & racial communities. Effective methods & strategies for working with diverse populations in changing social & economic times are provided for community practitioners & faculty. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction%3A+Diversity+and+Development&amp;rft.au=Faulkner%2C+Audrey%3BRoberts-DeGennaro%2C+Maria%3BWeil%2C+Marie&amp;rft.aulast=Faulkner&amp;rft.aufirst=Audrey&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 2 of 487

Commitment to social action

Author: Buffum, William E; MacNair, Ray H

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59666963?accountid=14667

Abstract: Analyzes practices which engender commitment to socio-political organizations and community action; focus on efforts of feminist organizations and social workers; US and Canada; 6 articles. Topics include a feminist approach to community organizing with minority women, linking social work professionals with community organizations, the New Jersey Tenants Organization, and social action by Canadian social workers.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apais&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Commitment+to+social+action&amp;rft.au=Buffum%2C+William+E%3BMacNair%2C+Ray+H&amp;rft.aulast=Buffum&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 3 of 487

Social Work, Economic Conversion, and Community Practice: Where Are the Social Workers?

Author: Mary, Nancy L11 Dept Social Work California State U, San Bernardino 92407-2397

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625123?accountid=14667

Abstract: With the fall of the Berlin Wall, & a new administration in Washington, DC, hope is renewed for a peace economy. This hope is evidenced in the growth of new economic conversion projects ranging from legislative initiatives to new grass-roots organizations. Here, survey data from 15 directors of conversion projects used to examine the kinds of strategies used & the degree of social work participation. Although results indicate that only 33% of the organizations involved social workers, there is much common ground among conversion strategies, community practice, & social work. 4 Tables, 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work%2C+Economic+Conversion%2C+and+Community+Practice%3A+Where+Are+the+Social+Workers%3F&amp;rft.au=Mary%2C+Nancy+L&amp;rft.aulast=Mary&amp;rft.aufirst=Nancy&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=7&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 4 of 487

Community Development with Emerging Ethnic Communities

Author: Daley, John M1; Wong, Paul1 School Social Work Arizona State U, Tempe 85286-1802

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61370370?accountid=14667

Abstract: Building on the analysis of F. G. Rivera & J. L. Erlich (1984), recent events & changing conditions significant to minority communities are discussed, noting implications for community development professionals. The importance of ethnic competence is discussed in terms of community practice. A proposal for a national & local strategy to improve practice & professional education is also described. 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 5 of 487

Community Organizing with Women of Color: A Feminist Approach

Author: Gutierrez, Lorraine M1; Lewis, Edith A1 Social Work U Washington, Seattle 98195

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61377739?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community organization methods with women of color requires addressing deficiencies of feminist theory in analyzing women's experience. Presented here is one approach that suggests how race & gender issues can be worked on simultaneously. Issues & practice principles relevant for both women of color & European-American women organizing in communities of color are discussed. 68 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Organizing+with+Women+of+Color%3A+A+Feminist+Approach&amp;rft.au=Gutierrez%2C+Lorraine+M%3BLewis%2C+Edith+A&amp;rft.aulast=Gutierrez&amp;rft.aufirst=Lorraine&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 6 of 487

Toward a Hybrid Model for Effective Organizing in Communities of Color

Author: Bradshaw, Catherine1; Soifer, Steven; Gutierrez, Lorraine1 c/o Gutierrez -- School Social Work U Washington, Seattle 98195

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625605?accountid=14667

Abstract: Viewing the feminist & (Saul) Alinsky approaches to community organizing as flexible & interflowing, a hybrid organizing model that draws from the strengths of both approaches is proposed. The model calls for continual assessment of the changing organizing context & flexibility to change the blend of strategies according to the needs of the moment. Also explored are how the dynamics of race & ethnicity affect organizing in communities of color, & the usefulness of the proposed model in dealing with these dynamics. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Toward+a+Hybrid+Model+for+Effective+Organizing+in+Communities+of+Color&amp;rft.au=Bradshaw%2C+Catherine%3BSoifer%2C+Steven%3BGutierrez%2C+Lorraine&amp;rft.aulast=Bradshaw&amp;rft.aufirst=Catherine&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Toward+a+Hybrid+Model+for+Effective+Organizing+in+Communities+of+Color&amp;rft.au=Bradshaw%2C+Catherine%3BSoifer%2C+Steven%3BGutierrez%2C+Lorraine&amp;rft.aulast=Bradshaw&amp;rft.aufirst=Catherine&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 7 of 487

Community Planning That Is "Caught" and "Taught": Experiential Learning from Town Meetings

Author: Alcorn, Sandra1; Morrison, John D1 George Williams Coll Aurora U, IL 60506

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61595972?accountid=14667

Abstract: Generalist practice models have become more important in social work education, but the attention in these models needs to be to community practice rather than practice at lower level client systems. In illustration of this model, a social work program at the Aurora U School of Social Work (IL) that focuses on community practice, the use of experiential learning, & a community strengths perspective is described. Three town meetings were designed & led by a team of community leaders, students, & faculty to engage the community in planning efforts. Students played the roles of enablers & brokers, participated as group leaders, & wrote reports. For further experiential learning in generalist practice, it is suggested that students conduct community surveys, specific community action projects, or campus-based projects to improve the status of the student community. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Planning+That+Is+%22Caught%22+and+%22Taught%22%3A+Experiential+Learning+from+Town+Meetings&amp;rft.au=Alcorn%2C+Sandra%3BMorrison%2C+John+D&amp;rft.aulast=Alcorn&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Planning+That+Is+%22Caught%22+and+%22Taught%22%3A+Experiential+Learning+from+Town+Meetings&amp;rft.au=Alcorn%2C+Sandra%3BMorrison%2C+John+D&amp;rft.aulast=Alcorn&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 8 of 487

Integrated Program Development: A Model for Meeting the Complex Needs of Homeless Persons

Author: Johnson, Alice K1; Castengera, Alice Rollins1 Mandel School Applied Social Sciences Case Western Reserve U, Cleveland OH 44106-7164

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61627143?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reviews case management & group work practice with homeless persons, arguing that effective social work practice must incorporate both intervention methods. Integrated program development, a program framework for shelter services, is presented, & a pilot project at the Salvation Army Family Haven in Saint Louis, MO, is described that illustrates the costs & benefits of empowerment-oriented group work with homeless persons. Three approaches for establishing group work for homeless people are suggested. 1 Figure, 40 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Integrated+Program+Development%3A+A+Model+for+Meeting+the+Complex+Needs+of+Homeless+Persons&amp;rft.au=Johnson%2C+Alice+K%3BCastengera%2C+Alice+Rollins&amp;rft.aulast=Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=Alice&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=29&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 9 of 487

Community Self-Help as Strategy and Outcome: The Examination of an Israeli Experience

Author: Lauffer, Armand11 School Social Work U Michigan, Ann Arbor 48109-1285

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61611089?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community self-help associations (CSAs) are locally based organizations in which professional service providers & planners share responsibilities with citizens & members for decision making & action. Here, the Israeli experience with CSAs is described, focusing on how mediating structures work & comparing social problem-solving approaches to social development strategies. 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 10 of 487

Commitment to Social Change: Voices from the Feminist Movement

Author: Hyde, Cheryl11 School Social Work Boston U, MA 02215

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61376526?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines commitment as it relates to the pursuit of social change through case studies of nine feminist social movement organizations. An analysis of the accounts by veterans reveals stories of commitment in language that might be used to describe an intimate relationship. The collective voice suggests considerable sacrifice & dedication, & reveals a deep belief by participants that they were betrayed by movement beneficiaries. This sense of betrayal is rooted in the expectation that movement commitment would increase as attacks by the new Right rose. The relevancy of studying commitment to social change for both micro & macro social work theory & practice is discussed. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Commitment+to+Social+Change%3A+Voices+from+the+Feminist+Movement&amp;rft.au=Hyde%2C+Cheryl&amp;rft.aulast=Hyde&amp;rft.aufirst=Cheryl&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 11 of 487

Child Abuse Prevention: The Community as Co-Worker

Author: Rosenthal, Seymour J1; Cairns, June M1 Center Social Policy & Community Development Temple U, Philadelphia PA 19121

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61631741?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on the mid-point of a federally funded child abuse prevention project, described here are the roles of worker & community as colleagues in an effort to enhance the community's capacity to shape its own values & behaviors to reduce child abuse & neglect. A challenge is posed to the social work education community to be more responsive to the potential of becoming a coworker with the community, & to enhance the social worker's skills in defining strengths rather than weaknesses of communities. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 12 of 487

Advocating for Community Services Coordination: An Empowerment Perspective for Planning AIDS Services

Author: Mancoske, Ronald J1; Hunzeker, Jeanne M1 School Social Work Southern U, New Orleans LA 70126

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61608808?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports on an educational program using an empowerment-based community practice model in responding to the AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) crisis. This service planning coordination effort included compiling a comprehensive directory & profile of local services, measuring practitioner knowledge & attitudes toward working with persons affected by AIDS, & analyzing planning policies of HIV (human immunodeficiency virus) service agencies. This joint work included faculty, students, & community service providers. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 13 of 487

African American and White Managers: A Comparison in One Agency

Author: Daly, Alfrieda11 School Social Work Rutgers U, New Brunswick NJ 08903-3550

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61578441?accountid=14667

Abstract: Questionnaires completed by staff members (total N = 890) are used to compare differences in management styles in 8 local social service agency offices managed by African Americans & 8 managed by whites. When the environment was turbulent, white managers responded by becoming more supportive of staff, while African-American managers increased problem-solving communications. Staff in African-American offices in turbulent environments had higher levels of job satisfaction than either white offices or African Americans in nonturbulent environments. 8 Figures, 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=African+American+and+White+Managers%3A+A+Comparison+in+One+Agency&amp;rft.au=Daly%2C+Alfrieda&amp;rft.aulast=Daly&amp;rft.aufirst=Alfrieda&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 15 of 487

Linking Professionalism and Community Organization: A Scholar/Advocate Approach

Author: Johnson, Alice K11 Mandel School Applied Social Sciences Case Western Reserve U, Cleveland OH 44106

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61342574?accountid=14667

Abstract: Proposes a scholar/advocate approach to forge a link between professionals & community organizations in community practice. Such an approach faciliates social change, provides an opportunity for social work professionals to participate in community organizing, & empowers grass-roots groups. The benefits & limitations of this method for professionals & community groups are illustrated by its application to three community organizations concerned about the urban poor & homeless. 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

A Wholistic Ethno-Cultural Paradigm: A New Model for Community Organization Teaching and Practice

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61633532?accountid=14667

Document 17 of 487

Classroom and Advocacy: A Project on the Working Poor in St. Louis

Author: Weiler, Mary T1; Sherraden, Michael1 George Warren Brown School Social Work Washington U, Saint Louis MO 63130-4899

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61603980?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes a social work seminar on employment issues devoted to a research-based advocacy project on the working poor in St. Louis, MO. All class members participated in data gathering, interviewing, & writing a report incorporating national, state, & local data on the working poor population. Particular attention was given to single mothers, the homeless, & health care issues. The project resulted in a published report, which was presented in a well-attended forum & resulted in considerable media coverage. Altogether, the project provides a successful example of combining academic work & informational advocacy. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Classroom+and+Advocacy%3A+A+Project+on+the+Working+Poor+in+St.+Louis&amp;rft.au=Weiler%2C+Mary+T%3BSherraden%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Weiler&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=99&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 18 of 487

Mentoring the Hmong: A Practice Outlet for Teaching Faculty and a Possible Community Development Tool

Author: Mowry, Donald D11 Dept Social Work U Wisconsin, Eau Claire 54702-4004

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61578382?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summarizes the personal experiences of a social work educator who became a mentor for a Hmong family in Eau Claire, WI, who had immigrated from the Highlands of Laos. The benefits of the mentoring experience for the educator, the curriculum, the learning climate, the Hmong, & the majority community are discussed. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 20 of 487

Social Action and the Canadian Social Worker: A Study in the Political Economy of the Profession

Author: Hardina, Donna11 Dept Social Work Education California State U, Fresno 93740-0102

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61620118?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reviews factors in the political economy of the social work profession that may inhibit or encourage social action activities among its members. In Canada, the prevalence of government funding for advocacy organizations, a high level of unionization among social workers, & professional commitment to social action are factors that affect the profession's capacity to engage in social action. 42 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Action+and+the+Canadian+Social+Worker%3A+A+Study+in+the+Political+Economy+of+the+Profession&amp;rft.au=Hardina%2C+Donna&amp;rft.aulast=Hardina&amp;rft.aufirst=Donna&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 21 of 487

Linking Disaster Preparedness and Organizational Response Effectiveness

Author: Banerjee, Mahasweta M1; Gillespie, David F1 School Social Welfare U Kansas, Lawrence 66045

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61374389?accountid=14667

Abstract: An analytical model is developed to specify the relationship between organizational disaster preparedness & effective disaster response. The model shows how the concept of disaster preparedness applies to a broad range of social services when circumstances overwhelm the usual means of responding to problems. The viability of the model is illustrated with data from a Key Resource Chapter of the American Red Cross. The paradoxical nature of organizational effectiveness suggests the need for empirical studies to further sharpen the analytical connection between preparedness & effectiveness. 1 Figure, 54 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Linking+Disaster+Preparedness+and+Organizational+Response+Effectiveness&amp;rft.au=Banerjee%2C+Mahasweta+M%3BGillespie%2C+David+F&amp;rft.aulast=Banerjee&amp;rft.aufirst=Mahasweta&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 22 of 487

Project Homeless: A Model for Student Involvement in Community Change

Author: Alexander, Gloria11 Southern Vermont Coll, Bennington 05201

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626826?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes how students activated community awareness & involvement in the problem of homelessness in their rural area by participating in Project Homeless, a community organization & planning course at Southern Vermont Coll. Students reviewed literature & newspaper articles on homelessness & collected data by interviewing service providers to discover met & unmet needs, problems, & available resources. As a result of their findings, the community mental health center sponsored a task force on homelessness. 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Project+Homeless%3A+A+Model+for+Student+Involvement+in+Community+Change&amp;rft.au=Alexander%2C+Gloria&amp;rft.aulast=Alexander&amp;rft.aufirst=Gloria&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft.volume=1&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=143&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 23 of 487

Is Community Organizing "The Greatest Job" One Could Have? Findings from a Survey of Chicago Organizers

Author: O'Donnell, Sandra M11 Public Administration Roosevelt U, Chicago IL 60605

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61603100?accountid=14667

Abstract: Mail survey data were obtained in 1992 from 41 career community organizers in Chicago (IL) in an attempt to build a knowledge base on organizing careers. Findings confirm the widespread impression that organizing is characterized by long hours, modest salaries (median of $33,215) given the demands of the jobs, & few fringe benefits. However, it is also characterized by great job satisfaction, considerable autonomy, & a strong sense of professional solidarity. Implications of these findings for social work education are discusesd. 3 Tables, 1 Appendix, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Is+Community+Organizing+%22The+Greatest+Job%22+One+Could+Have%3F+Findings+from+a+Survey+of+Chicago+Organizers&amp;rft.au=O%27Donnell%2C+Sandra+M&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Donnell&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 24 of 487

Community Organizing and Community-Based Redevelopment in Cedar-Riverside and East Toledo: A Comparative Study

Author: Stoecker, Randy11 Dept Sociology/Anthropology/Social Work U Toledo, OH 43606

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61496485?accountid=14667

Abstract: Analyzes the relationship between community organizing & community-based redevelopment in a comparative case study of 2 communities in Minneapolis, MN, & Toledo, OH, using interviews, archival files, organizational records, media reports, & secondary sources. Both neighborhoods evidence the recent historical shift from militant community organizing to community-based redevelopment movements. It is argued that community organizing is an important prerequisite for successful community-based redevelopment, but that redevelopment procedures can undermine needed community solidarity. Community-based redevelopment requires cooperation with the institutions fought against in community organizing & is thereby subject to the partisan influences of financial & political support. Further, redevelopment demands a degree of attention to detail that is difficult to achieve using the volunteer labor of community groups. It is concluded that community organizing & community-based redevelopment must be made separate & accountable institutions in order to maintain the solidarity & productivity of the individual movements. 53 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Organizing+and+Community-Based+Redevelopment+in+Cedar-Riverside+and+East+Toledo%3A+A+Comparative+Study&amp;rft.au=Stoecker%2C+Randy&amp;rft.aulast=Stoecker&amp;rft.aufirst=Randy&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Organizing+and+Community-Based+Redevelopment+in+Cedar-Riverside+and+East+Toledo%3A+A+Comparative+Study&amp;rft.au=Stoecker%2C+Randy&amp;rft.aulast=Stoecker&amp;rft.aufirst=Randy&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 25 of 487

Introduction

Author: Wernet, Stephen P11 School Social Work Loyola U, Chicago IL 60611

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61596455?accountid=14667

Abstract: An introduction to a special journal issue (see related abstracts in SOPODA 18:1) of conference papers sharing a common theme: the importance of constructed & ascribed meaning within community practice. The papers reflect the idea that construction of meaning is a vital & central component in community practice & research, & set out a common approach to knowledge-building for community practice-case study research. It is argued that scholars & practitioners must understand how meaning is created, how it serves to mobilize a community, & under what conditions meaning undercuts mobilizing work. Also described are an agenda & challenges for future work in research & theory-building in community practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction&amp;rft.au=Wernet%2C+Stephen+P&amp;rft.aulast=Wernet&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 26 of 487

A Resource Mobilization Analysis of a Failed Environment Protest

Author: Kaminstein, Dana S11 School Social Work U Pennsylvania, Philadelphia 19104-6214

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61404287?accountid=14667

Abstract: A case study of a failed protest in Pitman, NJ, the community with the number one toxic waste dump in the US. The factors that favored mobilization (opportunities to challenge elites, ability to mobilize resources, organizational coherency, & recognition by those in power) & factors that worked against mobilization (investment in the system, tactics, emphasis on expertise, & opposition from elites) are examined. Discussed is why the protest by the grass-roots group in this town failed to garner widespread community support. Implications for environmental protests in other middle-class communities are discussed. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Resource+Mobilization+Analysis+of+a+Failed+Environment+Protest&amp;rft.au=Kaminstein%2C+Dana+S&amp;rft.aulast=Kaminstein&amp;rft.aufirst=Dana&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 27 of 487

Urban African American Community Development in the Progressive Era

Author: O'Donnell, Sandra M11 Public Administration Roosevelt U, Chicago IL 60605

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61522106?accountid=14667

Abstract: Development efforts in urban African-American communities in the Progressive Era, are recounted, emphasizing the work of Ida B. Wells-Barnett, who mobilized people to protest for equal rights & justice, & Lugenia Burns Hope, whose Neighborhood Union in Atlanta, GA, was a model of organization for social support & policy change. Other efforts for social betterment & social protest are also described to demonstrate how African-American community activism was distinguished by its emphases on community building -- encompassing physical, human, & social capital -- & on securing justice for black citizens. Implications for modern community organization/development theory & practice are discussed. 50 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Urban+African+American+Community+Development+in+the+Progressive+Era&amp;rft.au=O%27Donnell%2C+Sandra+M&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Donnell&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=7&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 28 of 487

Community-Based Consortia: One Model for Creation and Development

Author: Bailey, Darlyne1; Koney, Kelly McNally1 Mandel School Applied Social Sciences Case Western Reserve U, Cleveland OH 44106-7164

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61597327?accountid=14667

Abstract: In a contribution to the organizational & interorganizational literature, a four-phase framework for community-based consortia development is presented. Currently being used in a midwestern metropolitan area, this framework identifies critical process & content issues & themes that occur within & between a consortium's developmental phases. Key leadership competencies & skills are noted also. Implementation of these skills & practices by social workers & other professionals interested in community practice facilitates effective utilization of the consortium structure to meet the increasingly numerous & complex challenges facing today's communities. 49 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 29 of 487

George and Birdye Haynes' Legacy to Community Practice

Author: Carlton-LaNey, Iris11 School Social Work U North Carolina, Chapel Hill 27599-3550

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61490692?accountid=14667

Abstract: Chronicles the careers of George Edmund Haynes & his younger sister Birdye Henrietta Haynes during the Progressive Era & their legacy to community practice. Both were professionally trained social workers & graduates from two pioneer schools of social work, George from the New York School of Philanthropy & Birdye from the Chicago (IL) School of Civics & Philanthropy. They each made significant contributions to the development of the profession & to practice in the African-American community. Their professional experiences are recounted, focusing on their "race work" & the community practice strategies & approaches they used. 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=George+and+Birdye+Haynes%27+Legacy+to+Community+Practice&amp;rft.au=Carlton-LaNey%2C+Iris&amp;rft.aulast=Carlton-LaNey&amp;rft.aufirst=Iris&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 30 of 487

Conflict and Conflict Resolution in Citizen Participation Programs: A Case Study of the Lipari Landfill Superfund Site

Author: Kauffman, Stephen E11 Center Social Work Education Widener U, Chester PA 19103

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61620509?accountid=14667

Abstract: Conflicts between governmental agencies & individuals are common in citizen participation programs. One source of these conflicts is barriers to full participation in decision making. These barriers are examined, demonstrating via a case study from NJ of citizen participation in a campaign to clean up a landfill how conflict may be reduced through their removal. Implications for program changes & community organizers are discussed. 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Children+as+Citizens&amp;rft.au=Golombek%2C+Silvia+Blitzer&amp;rft.aulast=Golombek&amp;rft.aufirst=Silvia&amp;rft.date=2006-01-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=11&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n01_02

Document 33 of 487

Lawrence Oxley and Locality Development: Black Self-Help in North Carolina 1925-1928

Author: Burwell, N Yolanda11 School Social Work East Carolina U, Greenville NC 27858

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61431298?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the career of African-American social worker Lieutenant Lawrence Oxley & his use of locality development strategies & emphasis on self-help within the African-American community in NC during the 1920s. Oxley demonstrated that black citizens could organize themselves to work on local community betterment initiatives such as establishing a social welfare agency directed to the needs of blacks, organizing citizens to address social welfare needs at the local level, & promoting social work education & training through public welfare institutions. In this context, Oxley's community organization efforts in Alamance, Wake, & New Hanover counties are discussed, demonstrating how his ability to organize blacks to act in their own self-interest was affected by five factors: the social service needs of blacks; the assistance of white officials; the cooperation of resource systems & the helping tradition among blacks; the participation of black citizens in county affairs; & the development & influence of black advisory committees. It is concluded that Oxley's strong belief in self-help was an act of solidarity & community power that serves as a reminder of the power of community action. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Lawrence+Oxley+and+Locality+Development%3A+Black+Self-Help+in+North+Carolina+1925-1928&amp;rft.au=Burwell%2C+N+Yolanda&amp;rft.aulast=Burwell&amp;rft.aufirst=N&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Lawrence+Oxley+and+Locality+Development%3A+Black+Self-Help+in+North+Carolina+1925-1928&amp;rft.au=Burwell%2C+N+Yolanda&amp;rft.aulast=Burwell&amp;rft.aufirst=N&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 34 of 487

Coordinating Theory, Evidence, and Practice: Toxic Waste Exposure in Communities

Author: Rogge, Mary E11 George Warren Brown School Social Work Washington U, Saint Louis MO 63130

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61615623?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes key concepts derived from theories used to examine collective action in response to the threat of toxic exposure. These concepts are defined, synthesized into a theoretical framework, & illustrated. The framework provides an organizing perspective that social workers can use to respond to the problem of toxic exposure, & offers a first step toward advancing theory & research for organizing communities to respond to toxic exposure & other social problems when collective action is a viable response. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 79 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 36 of 487

A Leadership Role for Social Work in the Mental Health Transition to Local Care

Author: Morris, John A, Jr11 PO Box 45, Columbia SC 29202

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61590604?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reviews the literature on current philosophy, policy, & practice with regard to care of persons with serious mental illnesses, focusing on the movement that is usually called deinstitutionalization. Past efforts & future trends are discussed within the context of public mental health systems at the state level. An argument is developed for a greater leadership role for social work in providing mental health care in local communities, because of the social work tradition of client empowerment, family involvement, & systems intervention. 58 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 38 of 487

State Promotion of Community Advocacy Organizations: A Comparative Analysis of Four Case Studies in Georgia

Author: MacNair, Ray H1; Gross, Josephine; Daniels, Maurice Charles1 School Social Work U Georgia, Athens 30602

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61614076?accountid=14667

Abstract: A convenience sample of four case studies in which state human service bureaucracies created & promoted community advocacy organizations in GA is used to investigate the resulting patterns of relationship. Analysis focuses on the design & authorization of the state promotion effort, the state's purposes in promoting the organization, the strategies used to assure quality & control of outcomes, & the experiences of the state office in promoting the organization. A typology illustrating the interaction of community advocacy organizations & state bureaucracies under different conditions is developed. It is demonstrated that loosely bounded bureaucracies are consistent with the promotion of autonomous community advocacy organizations, & tightly bounded bureaucracies are consistent with the generation of dependent & closely coordinated community advocacy organizations. 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=State+Promotion+of+Community+Advocacy+Organizations%3A+A+Comparative+Analysis+of+Four+Case+Studies+in+Georgia&amp;rft.au=MacNair%2C+Ray+H%3BGross%2C+Josephine%3BDaniels%2C+Maurice+Charles&amp;rft.aulast=MacNair&amp;rft.aufirst=Ray&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=77&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 39 of 487

Developmental Disability Services to Caribbean Americans in New York City

Author: Smith, Marcia A. Bayne1; Mason, Marco A1 Queens Coll City U New York, Flushing 11367

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61594184?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interviews with 75 black Caribbean Americans living in the New York City area regarding the need for developmental disability service, experiences with service utilization, & recommendations for increased service use reveal that 50% of the respondents suffer from multiple disabilities that require ongoing medical care. The data also indicate that type & amount of care received are closely related to type of insurance. Since service underutilization is usually the result of barriers in both the service delivery system & the cultural perceptions of the target group, the need for cultural sensitivity training among providers & health education programs designed specifically for Caribbean immigrants is also discussed. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Developmental+Disability+Services+to+Caribbean+Americans+in+New+York+City&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Marcia+A.+Bayne%3BMason%2C+Marco+A&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Marcia+A.&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 40 of 487

Redirecting the Lives of Urban Black Males: An Assessment of Milwaukee's Midnight Basketball League

Author: Farrell, Walter C, Jr1; Johnson, James H, Jr; Sapp, Marty; Pumphrey, Roger M; Freeman, Shirley1 Dept Educational Policy & Community Studies U Wisconsin, Milwaukee 53201

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61407678?accountid=14667

Abstract: Survey data from 96 participants in Milwaukee's (WI) Midnight Basketball League indicate that the returns on the money invested in the program are far greater than those on the enormously popular punitive & paternalistic policies & programs currently advocated at all levels of government. During the first year, the program (1) reduced crime rates by 30% in the target area, (2) created a safe haven in which participants (& fans) could engage in positive social activities, (3) channeled the energy of gang members in a positive direction, & (4) significantly improved the educational & career aspirations of participants. Nearly all of the participants indicate that such leagues should be developed throughout the city. 7 Tables, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Redirecting+the+Lives+of+Urban+Black+Males%3A+An+Assessment+of+Milwaukee%27s+Midnight+Basketball+League&amp;rft.au=Farrell%2C+Walter+C%2C+Jr%3BJohnson%2C+James+H%2C+Jr%3BSapp%2C+Marty%3BPumphrey%2C+Roger+M%3BFreeman%2C+Shirley&amp;rft.aulast=Farrell&amp;rft.aufirst=Walter&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Redirecting+the+Lives+of+Urban+Black+Males%3A+An+Assessment+of+Milwaukee%27s+Midnight+Basketball+League&amp;rft.au=Farrell%2C+Walter+C%2C+Jr%3BJohnson%2C+James+H%2C+Jr%3BSapp%2C+Marty%3BPumphrey%2C+Roger+M%3BFreeman%2C+Shirley&amp;rft.aulast=Farrell&amp;rft.aufirst=Walter&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 41 of 487

Do Canadian Social Workers Practice Advocacy?

Author: Hardina, Donna11 Dept Social Work Education California State U, Fresno 93740-0102

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61600967?accountid=14667

Abstract: Advocacy & social action activities by direct practitioners as well as community organizers are essential if social workers are to develop the capacity to oppose economic & social oppression. The prevalence of case, self-help, & class advocacy practice among social workers in southwestern Ontario was examined in a 1991 mail questionnaire survey (N = 69 usable responses). The prevalence of social action-related activities (lobbying for legislation, protests, & involvement in politics) is also assessed. 5 Tables, 1 Figure, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Non-Custodial African American Fatherhood: A Case Study Research Approach

Author: Rasheed, Janice Matthews1; Johnson, Waldo E, Jr1 School Social Work Loyola U, Chicago IL 60611

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61566537?accountid=14667

Abstract: A conceptual foundation for the use of a research approach in exploring program & policy issues associated with empowering poor, young, noncustodial African-American fathers is described. A postpositivist, ecological, Afrocentric, bicultural research perspective, using the case study method, is proposed as the most effective means of understanding this population & for developing appropriate interventions. Methodological & substantive issues & dilemmas are discussed. It is argued that the case study methodology may point up important policy & programming implications. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Non-Custodial+African+American+Fatherhood%3A+A+Case+Study+Research+Approach&amp;rft.au=Rasheed%2C+Janice+Matthews%3BJohnson%2C+Waldo+E%2C+Jr&amp;rft.aulast=Rasheed&amp;rft.aufirst=Janice&amp;rft.date=1995-01-01&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=99&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

A Research Methodology for Community Practice

Author: MacNair, Ray H11 School Social Work U Georgia, Athens 30602

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61443900?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reviews the basic community practice research methods by examining comparative & quantitative analysis, qualitative study, & historical research methods. A systematic description & analysis of nine specific research methods, including their purpose, stage of knowledge development, & feasibility are provided. Documentation of this history of creative & feasible research methods should serve to stimulate further work on community practice research methods. 1 Table, 51 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 44 of 487

Community Policing and Community Organization: Assessment and Consensus Development Strategies

Author: Wiatrowski, Michael D1; Campoverde, Cecilia1 c/o Campoverde -- Dept Social Work Florida Atlantic U, Boca Raton 33431-0991

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61597596?accountid=14667

Abstract: Compares community policing & the more traditional policing models using real world examples of a group problem-solving technique applied by community police officers to establish a relationship with community members & to assist the community in developing a plan to confront its problems. In one, an adaptation of the nominal group technique was used in a FL community to allow 52 residents the chance to address common concerns. The role of the facilitator was key to growth & cohesion. This empowerment process built dialogue, enhanced the relationship between the police & community members, & facilitated community participation & consensus in problem identification, program development, & problem prevention-oriented policing. 3 Tables, 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Policing+and+Community+Organization%3A+Assessment+and+Consensus+Development+Strategies&amp;rft.au=Wiatrowski%2C+Michael+D%3BCampoverde%2C+Cecilia&amp;rft.aulast=Wiatrowski&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Policing+and+Community+Organization%3A+Assessment+and+Consensus+Development+Strategies&amp;rft.au=Wiatrowski%2C+Michael+D%3BCampoverde%2C+Cecilia&amp;rft.aulast=Wiatrowski&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 45 of 487

Model Development in Community Practice: An Historical Perspective

Author: Weil, Marie11 School Social Work U North Carolina, Chapel Hill 27599-3550

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61503527?accountid=14667

Abstract: A historical account investigates the original sources & later developments of models of community practice, 1890s-1990s. Basic strategies aimed at creating positive results in the field of social work are outlined, eg, social & economic development, political & social action, & social planning. Analysis concludes that although models are successful in guiding the research, they are not fixed elements; they will continue to evolve in conjunction with the environmental shifts of the society. Additionally, findings concurs with Jack Rothman's (1979) suggestion that these models be practiced in combination to maximize their development, organizing, planning, & change function. 2 Tables, 146 References. A. Durward

Document 46 of 487

Public Opinions about What a Citizen Can Do to Help Abused and Neglected Children in Addictive Families

Author: Andrews, Arlene Bowers11 Coll Social Work U South Carolina, Columbia 29208

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61590740?accountid=14667

Abstract: A statewide telephone survey of 809 adults in SC investigated public opinions about how to help abused & neglected children in families where substance abuse is a problem. Although most respondents (Rs) said they were highly likely to help such families, their probable actions were detached rather than involved. Qualitative analysis of open-ended questions revealed that Rs were likely to rely on authorities such as child protection or law enforcement agencies. Only a small minority was willing to befriend the family. These findings suggest that policies & programs need to focus on potential caregivers if the vision of more protective & competent communities is to be realized. 3 Tables, 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Public+Opinions+about+What+a+Citizen+Can+Do+to+Help+Abused+and+Neglected+Children+in+Addictive+Families&amp;rft.au=Andrews%2C+Arlene+Bowers&amp;rft.aulast=Andrews&amp;rft.aufirst=Arlene&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 47 of 487

The Community Child Placement Budget: An Empowerment Strategy

Author: Litzelfelner, Pat1; Poertner, John1 School Social Welfare U Kansas, Lawrence 66045

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553148?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents a mechanism for empowering communities to take reponsibility for their vulnerable children. The community placement budget is based on the daily living costs associated with state custodial care of children. Based on child-placement agency data, a case example budget is presented delineating where these children are living, the cost associated with these placements, & who is paying. Strategies are suggested that will help community groups compare ideas about what they want for children in their community & identify possible areas for change. 2 Tables, 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 48 of 487

Neighborhood Organization and Local Social Action: A Case Study

Author: Li, Yuhui11 Dept Sociology Rowan Coll New Jersey, Glassboro 08028

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61497090?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the history, structure, & social, economic, & political changes of an urban neighborhood in OH, & how local social actors & organizations affect those changes, based on personal interviews, newspaper articles, & other documentation. This case study shows that (1) individual social actors are the most important factors in bringing about change consistent with the local social action system; (2) there is a significant & positive relationship between the economic condition of the neighborhood & the success of the changes in the neighborhood; (3) changes consistent with the local social action system are most effectively induced when organizations & social groups are organized independently, but are associated through coalition activities; & (4) the larger urban system -- political & economic -- in which the neighborhood is located can have strong influence on the neighborhood change. 2 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Neighborhood+Organization+and+Local+Social+Action%3A+A+Case+Study&amp;rft.au=Li%2C+Yuhui&amp;rft.aulast=Li&amp;rft.aufirst=Yuhui&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59740417?accountid=14667

Document 50 of 487

Puerto Rican Food Establishments as Social Service Organizations: Results of an Asset Assessment

Author: Delgado, Melvin11 School Social Work Boston U, MA 02215

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61574483?accountid=14667

Abstract: The role that Puerto Rican restaurants & grocery stores play in providing social services to the Puerto Rican community in Holyoke, MA, was examined through survey, using Spanish & English questionnaires. Results reveal that Puerto Rican restaurants & grocery stores are relatively new, open six-seven days a week for an average of 12 hours per day, & provide three primary social services: (1) integration of the lonely in the community through community-staff connections, opportunities for leisure within the establishment, & delivery of food & services to the isolated; (2) provision of interpreter services for those with limited English proficiency; & (3) community leadership through such activities as sponsoring events, donations to organizations, & owner/staff participation on agency boards & advisory committees. The value of an asset model for social work outreach to communities of color is discussed. 2 Tables, 1 Appendix, 53 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Puerto+Rican+Food+Establishments+as+Social+Service+Organizations%3A+Results+of+an+Asset+Assessment&amp;rft.au=Delgado%2C+Melvin&amp;rft.aulast=Delgado&amp;rft.aufirst=Melvin&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 52 of 487

The Interweaving of Community Intervention Approaches

Author: Rothman, Jack11 Dept Social Welfare U California, Los Angeles 90024-1452

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61600171?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents the revised version of the three-pronged model of community intervention -- locality development, social action, & social planning/policy -- introduced by the author in 1968. A recent elaboration of that model into a paradigm of community intervention that illustrates the interweaving of the basic models & the types of interventions resulting from the mixed forms is provided. Dilemmas inherent in each core model are analyzed. 1 Table, 8 Figures, 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Interweaving+of+Community+Intervention+Approaches&amp;rft.au=Rothman%2C+Jack&amp;rft.aulast=Rothman&amp;rft.aufirst=Jack&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Interweaving+of+Community+Intervention+Approaches&amp;rft.au=Rothman%2C+Jack&amp;rft.aulast=Rothman&amp;rft.aufirst=Jack&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Title: The Interweaving of Community Intervention Approaches

Document 53 of 487

Neighbourhood Committee Roles and the Sense of Community

Author: Itzhaky, Haya1; York, Alan S1 School Social Work Bar-Ilan U, Ramat-Gan IL-52900 Israel

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619973?accountid=14667

Abstract: Draws on interview data from 93 members of neighborhood committees from 31 urban, mainly lower-class neighborhoods in the greater Tel-Aviv, Israel, area to examine the expressive & instrumental roles played by neighborhood representative organizations. Following A. Wandersman (1981), the correlation of these roles with environmental factors & personal & participational variables is analyzed. Generally, the Wandersman model fits the data, but the use of the expressive-instrumental division allows for some refinement & extension, & sheds light on the way community activists see themselves as residents & as parents. 2 Tables, 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Neighbourhood+Committee+Roles+and+the+Sense+of+Community&amp;rft.au=Itzhaky%2C+Haya%3BYork%2C+Alan+S&amp;rft.aulast=Itzhaky&amp;rft.aufirst=Haya&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 54 of 487

Training Student Volunteers for Community Service: A Model Collaboration

Author: Leeds, Jeremy11 School Education New York U, NY 10003-6674

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61585479?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the development of training for undergraduate volunteers in youth programs in community agencies. The trainers, from the Dept of Applied Psychology at New York U, conceptualized the task as giving psychology away -- providing psychological knowledge to nonprofessionals who can benefit from it. The key concept in the training is the helping alliance, an idea from psychotherapy theory modified for the specific context of volunteer helpers. Implementation of the program, preliminary evaluations, & further projects & implications are discussed. 7 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Training+Student+Volunteers+for+Community+Service%3A+A+Model+Collaboration&amp;rft.au=Leeds%2C+Jeremy&amp;rft.aulast=Leeds&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeremy&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=95&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 55 of 487

Modelling Community Work: An Analytic Framework for Practice

Author: Jeffries, Ann11 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U Plymouth, Devon PL4 8AA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61579100?accountid=14667

Abstract: A critique of Jack Rothman's (1970) models for community practice identifies his primary & most applicable technique, which has been neglected by subsequent investigations of social work models. His approach is clarified as encompassing modes that are applied to the result of the specific modeling activity that they dictate. The objective of a model is defined, & strategies that have evolved since Rothman's original study are identified. These strategies are included in a four-square model applied in case examples from Ann Arbor, MI, & the UK. 6 Figures, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Modelling+Community+Work%3A+An+Analytic+Framework+for+Practice&amp;rft.au=Jeffries%2C+Ann&amp;rft.aulast=Jeffries&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=101&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 56 of 487

A Feminist Response to Rothman's "The Interweaving of Community Intervention Approaches"

Author: Hylde, Cheryl11 School Social Work Boston U, MA 02215

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61600134?accountid=14667

Abstract: Responds to Jack Rothman's "The Interweaving of Community Intervention Approaches" (see abstract 97W26442) from a feminist perspective. A feminist version of his intervention typology, using a wide range of exemplars, is constructed, suggesting the scope of feminism not recognized in his account & illuminating problems inherent in such a categorical approach to community practice. It is argued that much would be gained by recognizing the dimensions of ideology, longitudinal development, & commitment in community intervention & incorporating social movement literature into practice analyses. 1 Table, 44 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Feminist+Response+to+Rothman%27s+%22The+Interweaving+of+Community+Intervention+Approaches%22&amp;rft.au=Hylde%2C+Cheryl&amp;rft.aulast=Hylde&amp;rft.aufirst=Cheryl&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=127&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 57 of 487

Community Work: British Models

Author: Popple, Keith11 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U Plymouth, Devon PL4 8AA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550848?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents a typology of models of community work currently extant in the UK, focusing on clarifying theoretical points. Community care, community organization, community development, social/community planning, community education, & community action are reviewed, along with developing models of feminist, black, & antiracist community work. The typology is organized on a continuum from models focused on care to those focusing on action. Each model is analyzed in relation to the following characteristics: strategy, workers' main roles, & typical agencies & examples of work. Selected critical texts treating each model are documented. The models are compared with each other, particularly regarding techniques, skills, & ideological traditions. 1 Table, 179 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Work%3A+British+Models&amp;rft.au=Popple%2C+Keith&amp;rft.aulast=Popple&amp;rft.aufirst=Keith&amp;rft.date=1996-01-01&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 58 of 487

Theory for Community Practice in Social Work: The Example of Ecological Community Practice

Author: MacNair, Ray H11 School Social Work U Georgia, Athens 30602

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61491503?accountid=14667

Abstract: Ecological theory is used to identify a generic model of community practice & analyze member cohesion in the three traditional modalities. The theory of energy in human ecology is developed to set the stage for an energy assessment & selection of strategic energy patterns in phases of organizing. Theoretical propositions with practice implications are offered for research on the relationship among strategic energy patterns of organizing, energy costs, specialization of function, & styles of intervention. 3 Tables, 2 Figures, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 59 of 487

Introduction: Models of Community Practice in Action

Author: Weil, Marie11 School Social Work U North Carolina, Chapel Hill 27599

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61543147?accountid=14667

Abstract: An introduction to special journal issue on models of community practice (see abstracts of related articles). The following topics are discussed: (1) models as the simplification or abstraction of reality; (2) use of models to formulate & synthesize complex ideas; (3) model specification of comparative characteristics; (4) the lack of purity or total differentiation in community practice models; (5) the nonisolating or permeable boundary characteristic of models; & (6) the use of models to move practice activities beyond reaction to proaction. Three basic community practice models are highlighted: (A) community organization; (B) community economic development; & (C) coalition building. 16 References. D. Generoli

Process evaluation of primary health care projects: a mid-term evaluation of a primary health care project in Northern India

Author: Pandey, Shanta; and others

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59796435?accountid=14667

Abstract: Assesses implementation process of a PHC project, the Himalayan Rural Health Development Project (HRHDP), in the state of Uttar Pradesh; evaluation conducted Spring 1994.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apais&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Process+evaluation+of+primary+health+care+projects%3A+a+mid-term+evaluation+of+a+primary+health+care+project+in+Northern+India&amp;rft.au=Pandey%2C+Shanta%3Band+others&amp;rft.aulast=Pandey&amp;rft.aufirst=Shanta&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 61 of 487

The YWCA Women's Advocacy Program: A Case Study of Domestic Violence and Sexual Assault Services

Author: Gilson, Stephen French11 School Social Work Virginia Commonwealth U, Richmond 23284-2027

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61520998?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents a case study of the Women's Advocacy Program, an alternative service program with a feminist focus structured within the Young Women's Christian Assoc (YWCA) of Richmond, VA. A qualitative program evaluation -- based on reviews of written materials, site examinations, & interviews with stakeholder group representatives -- found that women who seek domestic violence &/or sexual assault services believe that their safety & security are essential. Further, women frequently found personal strength & support through their association with others who shared their experiences, feelings, & struggles. Alternative service programs such as this one sometimes find it challenging to maintain an ideological commitment to consensual decision making, political focus, & structural change efforts, & focus on empowerment, & self-determination while maintaining a link to the host organization. 1 Table, 40 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+YWCA+Women%27s+Advocacy+Program%3A+A+Case+Study+of+Domestic+Violence+and+Sexual+Assault+Services&amp;rft.au=Gilson%2C+Stephen+French&amp;rft.aulast=Gilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 62 of 487

Transforming Human Services Organizations through Empowerment of Neighbors

Author: Colby, Ira C11 School Social Work U Central Florida, Orlando 32816

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587179?accountid=14667

Abstract: Details the needs assessment process of a multicultural, community-based substance abuse project to organize alcohol & other drug abuse prevention activities in four diverse communities in Fort Worth, TX, & describes how the neighborhood needs assessment contributed to the empowerment process, drawing on evaluative data from the interview process (N = 34 neighborhood youth data collectors & 220 completed interviews) regarding refusal rate & survey errors. This innovative process builds on the strengths perspective & documents that a neighborhood group is able to direct rather than be directed by a project. Findings indicate that traditions of distrust & alienation between neighborhoods & social institutions, fostered over years of failed attempts in social welfare programming, can be offset by a neighborhood participation ownership model. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Transforming+Human+Services+Organizations+through+Empowerment+of+Neighbors&amp;rft.au=Colby%2C+Ira+C&amp;rft.aulast=Colby&amp;rft.aufirst=Ira&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Core Concepts for Community Change

Author: Checkoway, Barry11 School Social Work U Michigan, Ann Arbor 48109

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540880?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents several core principles for creating community change. Perspectives on change as a process of strengthening community & joining variable strategies & skills are examined, drawing on previous research in social work & related fields, & on practice in community development in industrial countries & developing areas worldwide. Belief, empowerment, & multiculturalism as components of community change are discussed. 66 References. Adapted from the source document.
