Document 64 of 487

The Significance of Planned Community Participation in Problem Solving and Developing a Viable Community Capability

Author: Abatena, Hailu11 School Social Work U Nevada, Las Vegas 89154

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61541338?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that grassroots participation in community problem-solving (development) is essential because it facilitates (1) proper problem diagnosis & needs assessment, (2) sound decision making regarding choice of relevant & feasible goals/solutions, & (3) successful program implementation. Recent literature & empirical case studies suggest that voluntary & planned grassroots participation fosters these conditions &, as a result, is a potent vehicle for promoting local, regional, & national development. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 65 of 487

The Great Flood of 1993: Response and Recovery in Five Communities

Author: Sherraden, Margaret Sherrard1; Fox, Ellen1 Dept Social Work U Missouri, Saint Louis 63121

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540423?accountid=14667

Abstract: In 1993, the US Midwest endured a "one-hundred year flood." Although aid was available from public & private sources, some communities were much less successful than others in obtaining assistance & resources. Here, response & recovery from the flood in five communities is compared, drawing on data collected in the year following the disaster via formal interviews with 58 flooded-out residents & 10 community leaders, as well as informal conversations & observations. Immediate assistance in the response phase was available in the five communities, but recovery varied considerably across them. Findings focus on the importance of consensus on recovery goals, presence of local leaders & local organizations, socioeconomic resources, & political voice. Implications for community social work in postdisaster situations are discussed, including the importance of basic organization, advocacy skills, & understanding household & community economics. 3 Tables, 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Great+Flood+of+1993%3A+Response+and+Recovery+in+Five+Communities&amp;rft.au=Sherraden%2C+Margaret+Sherrard%3BFox%2C+Ellen&amp;rft.aulast=Sherraden&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 66 of 487

Interactive Strategic Planning and Community Development: The Northern Ireland Experience

Author: Murray, Michael R1; Greer, John V1 U Ulster, Coleraine Londonderry BT37 0QB Northern Ireland

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61520952?accountid=14667

Abstract: A model of community development practice that involves an interactive relationship between organized rural residents & outside technical facilitators is discussed, arguing that a strategic plan in a multicommunity planning situation benefits from a series of specific community development inputs. The discussion draws on a case study in Northern Ireland where, in a deeply divided society, community-led rural development not only contributes to social & economic change, but also helps promote mutual understanding & reconciliation between contesting cultural traditions. Three key issues of wider interest are identified: engaging in strategic planning, supporting multicommunity activity, & forging new partnership arrangements. 2 Figures, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 67 of 487

Public Life in Gulfton: Multiple Publics and Models of Community Organization

Author: Taaffe, Lisa1; Fisher, Robert1 c/o Fisher -- Graduate School Social Work U Houston, TX 77204-4492

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540820?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on case studies of 6 community organizations in Gulfton, a Houston, TX, neighborhood, since the 1960s, it is argued that community organization models need to consider that highly diverse & often contentious efforts within a single community reflect the context of life in contemporary heterogeneous urban neighborhoods. The diversity of organizational efforts, & even the tensions among them, are generally positive, representing a vibrant form of public life in a privatizing world. Rethinking the diversity of community organizations as multiple publics in a privatizing context demonstrates the importance & value of community organization within schools of social work & the larger society. 1 Table, 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Public+Life+in+Gulfton%3A+Multiple+Publics+and+Models+of+Community+Organization&amp;rft.au=Taaffe%2C+Lisa%3BFisher%2C+Robert&amp;rft.aulast=Taaffe&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=31&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 68 of 487

Transforming Human Services Organizations through Empowerment of Staff

Author: Cohen, Burton J1; Austin, Michael J1 Center Study Youth Policy, 4200 Pine St 2nd Floor Philadelphia PA 19104

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540688?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the prevailing model of worker involvement in organizational change in human services organizations, suggesting revisions in light of new demands & understanding of organizational change. Main assumptions of this approach are challenged, & a new model in which worker involvement is formally sanctioned & viewed as part of the professional social worker's role is proposed. It is also viewed as part of a continuous process of organizational learning & improvement. Examples of this model of staff empowerment applied in actual agency settings are presented. Implications of the model in relation to social work education & social work research are discussed. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Transforming+Human+Services+Organizations+through+Empowerment+of+Staff&amp;rft.au=Cohen%2C+Burton+J%3BAustin%2C+Michael+J&amp;rft.aulast=Cohen&amp;rft.aufirst=Burton&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Revitalizing families: a communitarian agenda for social work

Author: Boettcher, Richard E

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59787372?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explains the social philosophy of the communitarian movement, and shows how this philosophy, when applied to social programs and the practice of social work, can lead to a revitalization of American families, however they may be defined; US. Movement emphasizes individual responsibility over individual rights.

Document 70 of 487

A Matrix for Decision Analysis in Macro-Practices

Author: Imbrogno, Salvatore11 Coll Social Work Ohio State U, Columbus 43210

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61520906?accountid=14667

Abstract: A decision matrix to the knowledge foundation of macropractice is introduced as a (1) strategy to highlight the idiosyncratic & parochial perspectives to key decision models available to the practitioner, demonstrating the benefits of an alternative perspective that integrates a variety of decision models, & (2) classification of decision schemata to modes of intervention. The primary goal is to show the significance of horizontal & vertical information transfer for social policy planning & development, social programming & management, & social project planning & operations. From this emerges a macropractitioner engaged in human creative & rational activity. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Matrix+for+Decision+Analysis+in+Macro-Practices&amp;rft.au=Imbrogno%2C+Salvatore&amp;rft.aulast=Imbrogno&amp;rft.aufirst=Salvatore&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 71 of 487

Empowering Students for Community Organization Practice: Teaching Confrontation Tactics

Author: Hardina, Donna11 Dept Social Work Education California State U, Fresno 93740-0102

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61574746?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines community organization education, contending that social work students do not receive appropriate training in confrontation tactics & power analysis. It is suggested that the community organization field lacks theories & teaching methodologies on the use of confrontation in seeking social change; traditional community organization models fail to illustrate oppression & resulting power relationships & the centrality of decision-making power. Classroom methods for teaching power analysis & confrontation politics are offered, eg, examining social service systems from the consumer's perspective, discussing oppression experiences & ethics of confrontation, & role-playing community forums. Questionnaire data obtained in 1994 from 12 students indicate that these classroom techniques can empower students to develop appropriate strategies to facilitate change via confrontation if necessary. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Empowering+Students+for+Community+Organization+Practice%3A+Teaching+Confrontation+Tactics&amp;rft.au=Hardina%2C+Donna&amp;rft.aulast=Hardina&amp;rft.aufirst=Donna&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 72 of 487

Being a Conscience and a Carpenter: Interpretations of the Community-Based Development Model

Author: Rubin, Herbert J11 Dept Sociology Northern Illinois U, DeKalb 60115

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61508407?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines claims that community-based development organizations ignore or neglect advocacy work &/or minimize social service efforts. Case study material comprising 250 interviews with leaders, employees, & supporters of 60 projects in the US is used to argue that community-based development organizations succeed by linking together developmental, advocacy, & social service practices. An organic theory of community development is presented. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Author: Latting, Jean Kantambu; Blanchard, Angela

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59795190?accountid=14667

(NCI), a medium-sized human service organization in Houston, Texas that underwent a change from a "poverty/limited resources" culture to one that emphasized staff empowerment and material comfort; late 1980s. Document 74 of 487

Helen Hall and the Settlement House Movement's Response to Unemployment: Reaching Out to the Community

Author: Andrews, Janice11 Mail #LOR 405 2115 Summit Ave, Saint Paul MN 55105

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61539707?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the role played by the National Federation of Settlements in the 1920s & 1930s in response to the unemployment crisis experienced by the US worker, reviewing & analyzing the 1928 Unemployment Study (N = 150 case studies) & Helen Hall's work on behalf of the federation. The model of community outreach practiced by the settlement houses & how they mobilized to help the unemployed are underscored. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Helen+Hall+and+the+Settlement+House+Movement%27s+Response+to+Unemployment%3A+Reaching+Out+to+the+Community&amp;rft.au=Andrews%2C+Janice&amp;rft.aulast=Andrews&amp;rft.aufirst=Janice&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 75 of 487

Houston Homeless Street Outreach

Author: Wuenschel, Peter C11 Graduate School Social Work U Houston, University Park TX 77004

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61520863?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the Homeless Street Outreach program developed in Houston, TX, as a collaborative project of several service agencies. The project's outcome indicates that a coordinated effort can effect delivery of more comprehensive services to the homeless population. The principles that emerge from the outreach include involvement of the homeless in planning & development, service agencies taking ownership of the project, & agency flexibility in delivering services. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 76 of 487

Achieving National Health Goals in Prevention with Community Organization: The "Bottom Up" Approach

Author: Poole, Dennis11 School Social Work U Central Florida, Orlando 32826

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61574705?accountid=14667

Abstract: Demonstrates that achieving national health goals in prevention requires reform from the bottom up through community organization & innovation. The case of the Healthy Kids project shows how citizens in OK formed community structures that took ownership of problems in Medicaid's Early & Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, & Treatment program, reformed local health services, & made the program work for children in their community. The project can be replicated by other communities seeking to improve child access to health care through Medicaid & other public health programs. 2 Figures, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Achieving+National+Health+Goals+in+Prevention+with+Community+Organization%3A+The+%22Bottom+Up%22+Approach&amp;rft.au=Poole%2C+Dennis&amp;rft.aulast=Poole&amp;rft.aufirst=Dennis&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=77&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 79 of 487

Conceptual Framework of Coalitions in an Organizational Context

Author: Roberts-DeGennaro, Maria11 School Social Work San Diego State U, CA 92182

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61575402?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using the political-economy perspective, a conceptual framework of coalitions in organizational settings is presented. Faced with a decline in resources, organizational actors will continue to coalesce because of their compelling interests to serve disadvantaged populations. Case illustrations of five models -- information & resource sharing, technical assistance, self-regulating, planning & coordination of services, & advocacy -- are discussed. It is concluded that various perspectives & models of coalition building are needed to provide direction for organizational groups. 1 Table, 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Conceptual+Framework+of+Coalitions+in+an+Organizational+Context&amp;rft.au=Roberts-DeGennaro%2C+Maria&amp;rft.aulast=Roberts-DeGennaro&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=1997-01-01&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 80 of 487

Leadership: Realizing Concepts through Creative Process

Author: Kahn, Si11 Grassroots Leadership, PO Box 36006 Charlotte NC 28236

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540756?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the history, context, & theory for community organizing, focusing on major concepts of culture, community, & power. It is contended that community organizing must stress both changing structures of power & political education. A leadership development exercise designed to confirm experience & provide affirmation & inspiration for continued organizing work is discussed. It is argued that the exercise validates participatory leadership & promotes shared creativity. 69 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 81 of 487

"A Whole Lot of Organizing Going On": The Status and Needs of Organizers in Community-Based Organizations

Author: Mizrahi, Terry1; Rosenthal, Beth1 School Social Work, Hunter Coll, New York, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61663563?accountid=14667

Abstract: Assesses the status & needs of grantees of a major foundation in New York City with respect to their experiences with & opportunities for community organizing. The New York Foundation's decision to support community organizing skills & resources was consistent with its goals to empower the socially & economically disadvantaged, strengthen the city's neighborhoods, increase the influence of target populations in public debates on issues of pressing social concern, & sharpen its agenda for action & change. The 97 organizational grantees surveyed were involved at all levels of the organizing spectrum & used a range of organizing & advocacy strategies: advocating on behalf of a community or constituency; influencing policymakers; developing supporters, advocates, & allies; increasing visibility, communication, & outreach; collaborating & building coalitions; & mobilizing & training the community to advocate on its own behalf. Most of the organizing is specific to an issue or neighborhood. Although many respondents organize or advocate in more than one program area, there appeared to be few efforts linking local activities to broader issues or goals. 8 Tables, 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%22A+Whole+Lot+of+Organizing+Going+On%22%3A+The+Status+and+Needs+of+Organizers+in+Community-Based+Organizations&amp;rft.au=Mizrahi%2C+Terry%3BRosenthal%2C+Beth&amp;rft.aulast=Mizrahi&amp;rft.aufirst=Terry&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%22A+Whole+Lot+of+Organizing+Going+On%22%3A+The+Status+and+Needs+of+Organizers+in+Community-Based+Organizations&amp;rft.au=Mizrahi%2C+Terry%3BRosenthal%2C+Beth&amp;rft.aulast=Mizrahi&amp;rft.aufirst=Terry&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 82 of 487

A Rural Tenant Organizing Model: The Case of TUFF-Vermont

Author: Soifer, Steven11 School of Social Work, U of Maryland at Baltimore, 525 West Redwood St, Baltimore, MD 21201

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61637172?accountid=14667

Abstract: Provides a case example of rural-based community-organizing practice in VT, which combined several different community-organizing models. The success of this statewide tenant-organizing effort -- Tenants United for Fairness (TUFF) -- can yield important lessons for rural community practitioners. 36 References. Jobs, Wealth, or Place: The Faces of Community Economic Development

Author: Giloth, Robert P11 Annie E. Casey Foundation

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61642200?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores six metaphors with relevance for community economic development: plugging the leaks, brokering connections, asset management, building ladders & webs, creating level playing fields, & enhancing markets. Social adaptation and welfare planning in the post-nomadic urban environment: the case of the Israeli Negev Bedouin

Author: Dinero, Steven C

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59776947?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores social change and socialization of this formerly nomadic community since the new town resettlement program began in the mid-1960s in which the government encouraged permanent relocation to seven new towns; roles played by social workers and community planners in adjustment to town life; Israel. Based on interviews with government officials, social workers, and community members and a public opinion survey conducted in the town of Segev Shalom, 1993.

Mobile Home Park Lot "Rent Control": A Successful Rural Legislative Campaign

Author: Soifer, Steven11 U Maryland, Baltimore

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61657033?accountid=14667

Abstract: Successful legislative campaigns, especially those in rural areas, are not often reported in the literature, despite the many lessons to be learned from them. Explored here as a case example is a significant legislative victory by an organization called Tenants United for Fairness-Vermont. Several different community organizing models are applied to analyze the campaign. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Social Capital and Local Economic Development: Implications for Community Social Work Practice

Author: Midgley, James1; Livermore, Michelle1 School of Social Welfare, U of California at Berkeley

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61632842?accountid=14667

Abstract: Defines the concept of social capital, traces the development of social capital theory, & examines how community social workers can promote local economic development by enhancing social capital. It is contended that community social workers can make a major contribution to local economic development by implementing projects that mobilize social capital & promote the material well-being of local people. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 88 of 487

The Revitalization of Community Practice: Characteristics, Competencies, and Curricula for Community-Based Services

Author: Johnson, Alice K11 Mandel School of Applied Social Sciences, Case Western Reserve U, 10900 Euclid Ave, Cleveland, OH 44106-7164 akj3@po.cwru.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61603254?accountid=14667

Abstract: A computerized word search was used to review the community practice & community organization literature to develop a working definition of community-based practice. The extensive review yielded six characteristics of community-based service delivery: (1) neighborhood-based & family-focused; (2) strengths- & empowerment-oriented; (3) cultural sensitivity & multicultural competency; (4) comprehensive services; (5) access to integrated services & supports; & (6) teamwork & leadership skills. What scholars have recommended in each of these areas is explored as a way of understanding the characteristics of community-based service delivery & the skills needed by direct practitioners working in community-based programs. Innovative curricula & specific courses that demonstrate ways to teach community skills to direct practice workers are summarized. Future work for community practice scholars & educators is recommended. 91 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Revitalization+of+Community+Practice%3A+Characteristics%2C+Competencies%2C+and+Curricula+for+Community-Based+Services&amp;rft.au=Johnson%2C+Alice+K&amp;rft.aulast=Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=Alice&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Community Residents as Lay Health Educators in a Neighborhood Cancer Prevention Program

Author: Lowe, Jane Isaacs1; Barg, Frances K; Stephens, Kay1 School Social Work, U Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61629831?accountid=14667

Self-Employment as a Social and Economic Development Intervention for Recipients of AFDC

Author: Raheim, Salome1; Alter, Catherine F1 School of Social Work, 308 North Hall, U of Iowa, Iowa City, IA 52242-1223 salome-raheim@uiowa.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61610152?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports findings from program evaluations of the Self-Employment Investment Demonstration (SEID) & Rivercities of Iowa/Illinois Self-Employment Program (RISE) designed to (1) test self-employment as a social & economic development strategy for recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) & (2) identify policy barriers to improving the economic well-being of this population. Data were collected via interviews with program participants & operators, operators' management information systems, & state Dept of Human Services electronic files. Program results showed that self-employment is a viable social & economic development strategy for self-selected welfare recipients who receive business training & assistance in locating operating capital. Implications are discussed for social work practice, education, & research. 5 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Self-Employment+as+a+Social+and+Economic+Development+Intervention+for+Recipients+of+AFDC&amp;rft.au=Raheim%2C+Salome%3BAlter%2C+Catherine+F&amp;rft.aulast=Raheim&amp;rft.aufirst=Salome&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Self-Employment+as+a+Social+and+Economic+Development+Intervention+for+Recipients+of+AFDC&amp;rft.au=Raheim%2C+Salome%3BAlter%2C+Catherine+F&amp;rft.aulast=Raheim&amp;rft.aufirst=Salome&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 91 of 487

Rising from the Ashes of Cutback, Political Warfare and Degraded Services: Strategic Considerations for Community Building: An Editorial Essay

Author: Fabricant, Michael1; Burghardt, Steve1 School Social Work, Hunter Coll, New York, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61663601?accountid=14667

Abstract: The economic & social decline of the white middle class over the last 20 years, fueled by intense economic shifts in global capital formation & worldwide market competition, has led to a conservative politics of the 1990s that harbingers a further erosion of the welfare state. Defined here are some of the critical areas that progressives must carefully examine if they are to counter conservative arguments more effectively, including a realistic assessment of the global economy, the role that poor communities can play in social transformation, the need to reconfigure social services in today's politicized environment, the use of services as an economic investment in community, & the importance of expanding organizing activities throughout the field. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Rising+from+the+Ashes+of+Cutback%2C+Political+Warfare+and+Degraded+Services%3A+Strategic+Considerations+for+Community+Building%3A+An+Editorial+Essay&amp;rft.au=Fabricant%2C+Michael%3BBurghardt%2C+Steve&amp;rft.aulast=Fabricant&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=53&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 92 of 487

Micro-Enterprise Development: A Response to Poverty

Author: Banerjee, Mahasweta M11 School of Social Welfare, U of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045 mahaswetab@sw1.socwel.ukans.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61674748?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the viability of microenterprise development initiatives as a response to poverty, using interview data from 40 slum-dwellers, 17 of whom had taken out a loan for a microenterprise, during a field study in Calcutta, India, 1995. Analysis demonstrates the crucial elements of the Grameen model of microlending. Findings show a significant difference in income of borrowers vs nonborrowers, & that microenterprises create a culture that has rippling effects on the community. Lessons learned are relevant for US social workers promoting microenterprises for community economic development. 1 Table, 44 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Micro-Enterprise+Development%3A+A+Response+to+Poverty&amp;rft.au=Banerjee%2C+Mahasweta+M&amp;rft.aulast=Banerjee&amp;rft.aufirst=Mahasweta&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 93 of 487

Middle Class Asian American Neighborhoods: Resident and Practitioner Perceptions

Author: Greenberg, Michael1; Schneider, Dona; Singh, Veena1 New Jersey Graduate Program in Public Health, Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning & Policy, Rutgers U, New Brunswick, NJ

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61586874?accountid=14667

Abstract: A survey was conducted of 422 Asian Indian & Korean American residents of NJ to determine how middle-income Asian Americans rated their neighborhood environments compared to non-Asians living in the same or similar environments, & to identify the issues that affected their neighborhood ratings. In addition, interviews were conducted with 27 practitioners (eg, architects, developers, realtors) in these same communities, examining their perceptions of their interactions with Asian Americans. Based on results, suggestions are made for practitioners interacting with Asian American clients on a proposed land use change. 2 Tables, 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 94 of 487

Time Series Analysis: Concepts and Techniques for Community Practitioners

Author: Dattalo, Patrick11 School Social Work, Virginia Commonwealth U, Richmond

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619105?accountid=14667

Abstract: Introduces community practitioners to important concepts & issues related to time-series analysis. The basic components of a time series -- trend, cycle, seasonal variation, & stochastic -- are described, together with the related issues of sampling rate, autocorrelation, length, & missing observations. A community practice example demonstrates the use of a basic two-step analytical technique. An understanding of these concepts & techniques can encourage practitioners to conduct preliminary analyses of time series, & help them evaluate the need for additional, more complex procedures. 6 Figures, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Time+Series+Analysis%3A+Concepts+and+Techniques+for+Community+Practitioners&amp;rft.au=Dattalo%2C+Patrick&amp;rft.aulast=Dattalo&amp;rft.aufirst=Patrick&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Southeastern Women's Involvement in Sustainable Development Efforts: Their Roles and Concerns

Author: Lack, Evonne1; Gamble, Dorothy N1 U of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61615992?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores women's roles in sustainable development, drawing on semistructured interview data from 59 representatives of southeastern US grassroots organizations that were working on community development projects. Results indicate a sustainable development focus in grassroots women's development efforts as well as a need for networking, skills training, & opportunities to share project experience. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 96 of 487

Development of Capital in Poor, Inner-City Neighborhoods

Author: Fellin, Phillip11 School of Social Work, The U of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61606579?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work practice in poor, inner-city neighborhoods can be enhanced through assessment of individual & community needs that takes into account various forms of capital, ie, financial, human, social, cultural, environmental, & political. These forms of capital are defined & illustrated, based on a review of social science studies of the social problems in inner-city neighborhoods. Examples are provided of community interventions that focus on capital development & community building for residents in areas of extreme poverty. 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Development+of+Capital+in+Poor%2C+Inner-City+Neighborhoods&amp;rft.au=Fellin%2C+Phillip&amp;rft.aulast=Fellin&amp;rft.aufirst=Phillip&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 97 of 487

Social Workers and PACs: An Examination of National Association of Social Workers P.A.C.E. Committees

Author: Colby, Ira C1; Buffum, William E1 School Social Work, U Central Florida, Orlando

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61670786?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the role of state Political Action for Candidate Election (PACE) committees (aka known as political action committees [PACs]) during the 1992 election cycle & assesses the extent to which these state committees carried out their identified purpose. Data from a questionnaire survey of 33 state chapters' executive directors are used to examine the structure of the PACE units & the activities they undertook, & assess the overall level of effectiveness of PACE efforts at the state level. While PACE activities were significant, considerable development is needed at the local, state, & national levels to increase the impact of social workers relative to other interest groups. 3 Tables, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 98 of 487

The Grameen Bank in Bangladesh: Helping Poor Women with Credit for Self-Employment

Author: Jansen, Golie1; Pippard, James L1 School of Social Work & Human Services, MS-19, 526 5th St, Eastern Washington U, Cheney, WA 99004-2431 gjansen@ewu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61633740?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that social work with poor women should include options for self-employment as avenues out of poverty. Here, the Grameen Bank of Bangladesh is examined as an example of one microlending strategy to overcome traditional barriers & assist very poor women to earn an income & participate in the local economy. Credit lending principles combined with social development goals are highlighted, & the impact of this model is discussed in terms of its success in alleviating poverty. Transferability of the model to the US is discussed, & implications for social work are offered. 73 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Grameen+Bank+in+Bangladesh%3A+Helping+Poor+Women+with+Credit+for+Self-Employment&amp;rft.au=Jansen%2C+Golie%3BPippard%2C+James+L&amp;rft.aulast=Jansen&amp;rft.aufirst=Golie&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=103&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 99 of 487

Community Economic Development Organizations in Montreal

Author: Fontan, Jean-Marc1; Shragge, Eric1 U du Quebec a Montreal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61612878?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores dilemmas facing community economic development intermediary organizations as vehicles for progressive social change via an analysis of an urban Canadian model from Quebec, the corporations de developement economique communautaire (CDEC), using existing literature. CDECs are democratically controlled, not-for-profit, local development organizations that oversee & support community economic development efforts on three main levels: (1) job skills development & employability services; (2) business development; & (3) development of innovative partnerships among diverse groups to plan & coordinate community economic development strategies in their communities. Analysis shows that, in such organizations, contradictory practices & directions coexist because of pressures exerted simultaneously by market, state, & community forces. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Economic+Development+Organizations+in+Montreal&amp;rft.au=Fontan%2C+Jean-Marc%3BShragge%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Fontan&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean-Marc&amp;rft.date=1998-01-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=125&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Community-Based Research in Policy Planning: A Case Study -- Addressing Poverty in the Texas-Mexico Border Region

Author: Padilla, Yolanda C1; Lein, Laura; Cruz, Monica1 School Social Work, Center Mexican American Studies, U Texas, Austin

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61661343?accountid=14667

Abstract: Illustrates, via interview data (N = 50), joint efforts of state policy analysts, university researchers, & community service providers in the TX-Mexico border region to address local conditions of poverty. The case study demonstrates the firsthand perspective that the community, through the involvement of local service providers, can bring to policy planning at a state level. 1 Table, 47 References. Document 101 of 487

Social Workers as Municipal Legislators: Potholes, Garbage, and Social Activism

Author: Rose, Susan J11 School Social Welfare, U Wisconsin, Milwaukee sjrose@csd.uwm.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61620806?accountid=14667

Abstract: Asserts that social workers, as legislators in municipal government, are a legitimate yet neglected area of community practice. As federal & state governmental systems are abandoning more of their functions in the wake of devolution, responsibility for traditional human service needs is falling on municipal government, making it increasingly important for social workers to run for municipal office. Traditional social work skills are linked to those useful in political life; specifically, connections to campaigning & governing in municipalities are made. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Workers+as+Municipal+Legislators%3A+Potholes%2C+Garbage%2C+and+Social+Activism&amp;rft.au=Rose%2C+Susan+J&amp;rft.aulast=Rose&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 102 of 487

The Campaign to Restore the Disability Assistance and Loan Program in the State of Maryland

Author: Soifer, Steven1; Singer, Jeff1 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61616272?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes a successful nonviolent social action campaign launched in 1995 to restore MD's Disability Assistance & Loan Program (DALP) to low-income citizens with medical disabilities. In an era of state & federal attacks on the social wage, the active involvement of graduate social work students through projects in their social action & community organizing classes ultimately helped restore the program. 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 103 of 487

Some Ethical Standards to Guide Community Practice and an Example of an Ethical Dilemma from the Field

Author: Julian, David A11 United Way Franklin County, Columbus, OH

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61657797?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes a survey research project designed to assist local United Way volunteers in making decisions about the extent to which contributor input should influence United Way allocation decisions, reviews ethical issues inherent in projects with implications for the community at large, & articulates ethical standards that might be used as guidelines for planning & implementing community interventions. These ethical standards are applied to issues raised by the Franklin County (OH) United Way project. The value of the ethical standards defined herein as guides to planning & implementing community interventions is discussed. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

The Internet and demystifying power differentials: a few women on-line and the housing authority

Author: Blundo, Robert G; and others

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59782364?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines emergence of a "critical consciousness" and action by women residents of a public housing project in southeastern North Carolina by creating a home page; includes historical and social context of relationship with local community.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apais&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Internet+and+demystifying+power+differentials%3A+a+few+women+on-line+and+the+housing+authority&amp;rft.au=Blundo%2C+Robert+G%3Band+others&amp;rft.aulast=Blundo&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=11&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 105 of 487

Interventions to Developing Community Partnerships for HIV Prevention Planning: Successful Macro Applications of Social Work Principles

Author: Cornelius, Llewellyn J1; Battle, Mark; Kryder-Coe, Julee H; Hu, Debbie1 Social Work Community Outreach Service, School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61663521?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since 1985, the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC) have entered into a series of cooperative agreements with US states & territories to find human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevention activities. In 1994, the CDC mandate shifted from using a central entity to plan HIV prevention programs throughout its jurisdictions to fostering partnerships among a central state or territorial agency, health departments in local counties, & community-based organizations. Discussed here is the application of a model developed by social workers to facilitate HIV prevention community planning at the local level. The model emphasizes the use of the social principles of empowerment, self-determination, ownership, & inclusion to foster the development of community-relevant HIV prevention plans. This approach resulted in the completion of a successful HIV prevention plan, & application for continuing & supplemental funds from the CDC for HIV prevention efforts, the continued use of the model in HIV prevention planning, & the ability to use the principles of the model as a basis for providing future technical assistance in community planning. 2 Tables, 69 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Interventions+to+Developing+Community+Partnerships+for+HIV+Prevention+Planning%3A+Successful+Macro+Applications+of+Social+Work+Principles&amp;rft.au=Cornelius%2C+Llewellyn+J%3BBattle%2C+Mark%3BKryder-Coe%2C+Julee+H%3BHu%2C+Debbie&amp;rft.aulast=Cornelius&amp;rft.aufirst=Llewellyn&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Interventions+to+Developing+Community+Partnerships+for+HIV+Prevention+Planning%3A+Successful+Macro+Applications+of+Social+Work+Principles&amp;rft.au=Cornelius%2C+Llewellyn+J%3BBattle%2C+Mark%3BKryder-Coe%2C+Julee+H%3BHu%2C+Debbie&amp;rft.aulast=Cornelius&amp;rft.aufirst=Llewellyn&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 106 of 487

Measuring Rational and Organizational-Political Planning Activities of Community Organization Workers

Author: Boehm, Amnon1; Litwin, Howard1 Faculty Social Welfare & Health Studies, School Social Work, Mount Carmel, Haifa, Israel

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61667246?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social planning in community organization work reflects two dominant planning styles -- rational & organizational-political. Here, indices for the measurement of both rational & organizational-political planning activities are applied to investigate the patterns of planning activities for 138 community organization workers in Israel. Structured questionnaire data gathered in 1992 show varying tendencies of workers in implementing planning activities & indicate a lack of homogeneous consolidated task patterns. Further, workers were found to focus more on traditional planning activities than on activities based on new knowledge. Findings underscore the importance of identifying factors that influence the tendency of workers to engage in planning activities in rational or organizational-political styles. 4 Tables, 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Measuring+Rational+and+Organizational-Political+Planning+Activities+of+Community+Organization+Workers&amp;rft.au=Boehm%2C+Amnon%3BLitwin%2C+Howard&amp;rft.aulast=Boehm&amp;rft.aufirst=Amnon&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=17&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 107 of 487

Where Have All the Organizers Gone? The Career Paths of Community Organizing Social Work Alumni

Author: Starr, Rose1; Mizrahi, Terry; Gurzinsky, Ellen1 School Social Work, Hunter Coll, New York, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61644579?accountid=14667

Abstract: In light of current fiscal constraints & political conservatism, it is essential that graduate schools of social work recruit & prepare professional practitioners skilled in community organizing & planning (CO&P) to play a role in improving the social conditions of functional & geographic communities. To develop a strategy for the future, an urban graduate school with a 25-year history of educating social workers with a community organization specialization studied the career paths & perspectives of its CO&P alumni. Reported here, based on mail questionnaire data, are the views of 100+ graduates of Master of Social Work (MSW) programs on their pre- & post-MSW values, jobs, work activities, & professional identification. Findings suggest both value-based & career-enhancement motivations for pursuing graduate professional education in CO&P social work; however, prior CO work experience was a better predictor of pursuing a CO&P career track. There is a need for concerted efforts by educators & practitioners to promote & support CO&P as a valued component of professional social work. 5 Tables, 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Where+Have+All+the+Organizers+Gone%3F+The+Career+Paths+of+Community+Organizing+Social+Work+Alumni&amp;rft.au=Starr%2C+Rose%3BMizrahi%2C+Terry%3BGurzinsky%2C+Ellen&amp;rft.aulast=Starr&amp;rft.aufirst=Rose&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 108 of 487

Challenges of Interdisciplinary Collaboration: A Faculty Consortium's Initial Attempts to Model Collaborative Practice

Author: Powell, John1; Dosser, David; Handron, Dorothea; McCammon, Susan; Evans Temkin, Margaret; Kaufman, Martha1 School Social Work & Criminal Justice Studies, East Carolina U, Greenville, NC

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61668484?accountid=14667

Abstract: Evaluates the first year of the Social Sciences Training Consortium (SSTC), a graduate-level, interdisciplinary academic program at East Carolina U (Greenville, NC) that trains & supports service providers & families, & prepares master's level graduates to work in innovative programs, drawing on interview data from SSTC faculty. One such program is PEN-PAL (Pitt-Edgecombe-Nash [three NC counties] Public Academic Liaison), a university/interagency collaborative effort that works in partnership with families to coordinate public & community services into a seamless system of care for children with severe emotional disturbances. The successes & difficulties encountered by faculty in the first year of a 5-year collaborative process are chronicled. 2 Figures, 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Challenges+of+Interdisciplinary+Collaboration%3A+A+Faculty+Consortium%27s+Initial+Attempts+to+Model+Collaborative+Practice&amp;rft.au=Powell%2C+John%3BDosser%2C+David%3BHandron%2C+Dorothea%3BMcCammon%2C+Susan%3BEvans+Temkin%2C+Margaret%3BKaufman%2C+Martha&amp;rft.aulast=Powell&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 109 of 487

Four Months to System Change: Teaching Baccalaureate Students to Affect Policy

Author: Moore, Linda S1; Dietz, Tracy J1 Social Work Program, Texas Christian U, Fort Worth

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61670734?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the process through which students in a community intervention class brought about change in the policy of a private, church-related university to recognize Martin Luther King, Jr.'s birthday as a university holiday. Focus is on tactics & strategies used to influence decisionmakers, educate the community, & empower the minority community on the campus. Important lessons for students include the political nature of system change, issues of power & stratification, & the impact of successful tactics on the opposition. This project was able to bring about change in a system that was initially unwilling to change. In today's social climate, that is often what social workers must do. Experiencing the process of system change during the educational process allows the lessons of one class to be applied to larger systems of service delivery in professional practice. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Four+Months+to+System+Change%3A+Teaching+Baccalaureate+Students+to+Affect+Policy&amp;rft.au=Moore%2C+Linda+S%3BDietz%2C+Tracy+J&amp;rft.aulast=Moore&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=33&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 110 of 487

Challenges and Dilemmas in Community Development

Author: Arches, Joan L11 Coll Public & Community Service, U Massachusetts, Boston

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61628994?accountid=14667

Abstract: When community development begins in low-income communities, resident involvement in revitalizing activities frequently falters. The community is often excluded from development decisions & may feel betrayed as its input is ignored. Here, dilemmas that arose when a Community Development Corp began building two units of affordable housing in a New England city & received 80 applications are described. Suggestions for addressing the dilemmas & implications for community practice rely on integrating grassroots community organizing throughout the development process while engaging in an ethnically sensitive, empowerment-oriented approach using coalitions & interagency collaboration. 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Challenges+and+Dilemmas+in+Community+Development&amp;rft.au=Arches%2C+Joan+L&amp;rft.aulast=Arches&amp;rft.aufirst=Joan&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 111 of 487

Finding Our Way: A Community Needs Assessment on Violence in Native Families in Canada

Author: Durst, Douglas1; MacDonald, Josephine; Parsons, Dawn1 Faculty Social Work, U Regina, Saskatchewan

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61629800?accountid=14667

Abstract: In fall 1992, a community needs assessment on the problem of family violence was completed in the Canadian aboriginal community of Conne River, Newfoundland. Community participation was a critical component of all aspects of the assessment, which was based on multiple data sources, including face-to-face interviews with key informants (community experts) & consumers/potential consumers of services, focus groups with youth & women, & informal contact & discussion with interested members of the community, some of them professionals. Findings indicate that residents were knowledgeable about the types of family violence occurring in the community & the various sources of support & help. There was also a high level of interest in the topic & a genuine hope that some positive action would result from this assessment. The assessment identified the need for more supports for women with families in crisis, not just crisis intervention during incidents of violence but a more holistic network of supports, community-based & operating with existing agencies. The study identified the need for a community-based committee to undertake the planning of emergency services for women & families in crisis & long-term planning for a support network &/or community center for women. 1 Table, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Finding+Our+Way%3A+A+Community+Needs+Assessment+on+Violence+in+Native+Families+in+Canada&amp;rft.au=Durst%2C+Douglas%3BMacDonald%2C+Josephine%3BParsons%2C+Dawn&amp;rft.aulast=Durst&amp;rft.aufirst=Douglas&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Finding+Our+Way%3A+A+Community+Needs+Assessment+on+Violence+in+Native+Families+in+Canada&amp;rft.au=Durst%2C+Douglas%3BMacDonald%2C+Josephine%3BParsons%2C+Dawn&amp;rft.aulast=Durst&amp;rft.aufirst=Douglas&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 112 of 487

Some Methodological Concerns When Estimating the Size of Organizing Activities

Author: Swank, Eric1; Clapp, John D1 Dept Sociology & Social Work, Morehead State U, MN

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61665790?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data collection on social movements is examined, using previous media research & two case studies (protests in San Diego [CA] against the Gulf War & street crime) to illustrate the problems associated with the most frequently used data sources of event size. Several research strategies that might enhance the accuracy of studies attempting to trace the protest cycles of community organizing efforts are suggested. 2 Tables, 64 References. Adapted from the source document.

Ethical and Racial Conflicts in Urban-Based Action Research

Author: Reisch, Michael1; Rivera, Felix1 School Social Work, U Pennsylvania, Philadelphia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622431?accountid=14667

Abstract: Case study data from a joint faculty-student research project at a public housing complex in San Francisco, CA, are used to describe how community-based action research, policy analysis, & community organizing can be synthesized in work with low-income communities. Potential implications for both community practice & social work education are outlined. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 114 of 487

Community Development as a Public Sector Agenda

Author: Perlmutter, Felice Davidson1; Cnaan, Ram A1 School Social Administration, Temple U, Narberth, PA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61660831?accountid=14667

Abstract: Documents how the Philadelphia, PA, Dept of Recreation underwent a planned change effort, which transformed some 196 site managers into active community organizers, drawing on questionnaire data from 60 of them. Based on the philosophy of a dynamic new commissioner (a former community organizer), city employees enhanced local civic participation & forged a partnership between the public & private sectors as well as with local residents. 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 115 of 487

Community Oriented Primary Care and Macro Social Work Practice

Author: Staples, Lee H11 School Social Work, Boston U, MA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625233?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community-oriented primary care (COPC), an approach based on community-professional partnerships & incorporating the principles of empowerment, links medicine, public health, & macro social work practice through interdisciplinary teams. The steps of the COPC model systematically identify, prioritize, & address health problems. This process works by forming "cluster committees" of public health stakeholders & draws heavily on skills associated with community organizing, task-oriented group work, planning, program development, & participatory evaluation. It shows great promise for both improving public health practice & increasing the role of macro social work in this process. 1 Figure, 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Oriented+Primary+Care+and+Macro+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Staples%2C+Lee+H&amp;rft.aulast=Staples&amp;rft.aufirst=Lee&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=61&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Nurturing the Seeds of Restorative Justice

Author: Holtquist, Susanne E11 School Social Welfare, U Kansas, Lawrence

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61654670?accountid=14667

Abstract: Restorative justice emphasizes the restoration of relationships & community peace that are damaged by crime. Here, 1995 mail survey questionnaire data from 330 households in the midwestern US are drawn on to evaluate public attitudes toward restorative justice as an alternative to the "get tough" or rehabilitative approaches to crime deterrence. 5 Tables, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59787241?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes approach used by the University of Texas at Arlington, which consists of an elective course in social work and politics and the Legislative Internship Program (LIP), a field practica in state legislators' district offices as constituent caseworkers and policy analysts.

Document 118 of 487

Paticipatory Education as a Community Practice Method: A Case Example from a Comprehensive Head Start Program

Author: Castelloe, Paul1; Watson, Thomas1 School Social Work, U North Carolina, Chapel Hill

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61619054?accountid=14667

Abstract: Provides an introduction to Freirean participatory education as a method for developing & implementing community practice interventions. The goal of participatory education is to help groups of people learn to use reflections on their everyday experiences to analyze the sociopolitical context in which they live & develop a sense that they can work effectively to change that context. The aims here are to discuss relations between participatory education & community practice; review the literature on the theory & practice of participatory education; & present a case example of the WAGES (Wayne Action Group for Economic Solvency) project, a participatory education project in a comprehensive Head Start program in Wayne County, NC. 2 Tables, 2 Figures, 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 119 of 487

Living Room Assessment

Author: Farmer, Rosemary1; Walsh, Joseph1 School Social Work, Virginia Commonwealth U, Richmond

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61620838?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community living room programs, initially developed as part of the settlement house movement, strive to maintain a safe & welcoming atmosphere for clients with basic needs who can then be linked to concrete services. These rare programs do not generally include formal intake & termination criteria & are thus difficult to assess by quantitative means. Here, the Community Oriented Programs Environment Scale is used to perform a social climate assessment of a living room program at an urban homeless shelter (N = 166 members & 35 staff) in Richmond, VA. The agency board & staff were concerned that expanding numbers of clientele might deter potential & current members from participation & thus defeat the program's major purpose. Social climate perceptions of staff & members underpin recommendations for agency program adjustments. This type of evaluation has implications for macropractice in determining whether nontraditional programs can be shown to meet certain human needs that complement those addressed by the broader social service system. 2 Tables, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Living+Room+Assessment&amp;rft.au=Farmer%2C+Rosemary%3BWalsh%2C+Joseph&amp;rft.aulast=Farmer&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosemary&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=79&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Living+Room+Assessment&amp;rft.au=Farmer%2C+Rosemary%3BWalsh%2C+Joseph&amp;rft.aulast=Farmer&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosemary&amp;rft.date=1999-01-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=79&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Building a comprehensive agency-university partnership: a case study of the Bay Area Social Services Consortium

Author: Austin, Michael J; and others

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59777949?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the BASSC, a mediating institution established in 1987 between four universities, twelve county social service agencies, and two foundations, to address shared concerns in the community.

Document 121 of 487

Community Capacity: Antecedents and Consequences

Author: Bowen, Gary L1; Martin, James A; Mancini, Jay A; Nelson, John P1 School Social Work, U North Carolina, Chapel Hill

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61466347?accountid=14667

Abstract: Traditional practice models of family support often lack a community focus. Increasingly, human service professionals who work with families focus their intervention & prevention efforts on the communities in which families live & work. The Family Advocacy Division of the US Air Force recently revised its program standards to address community issues in an effort to strengthen families through community-based prevention activities. This article presents a basic framework designed to inform this expanded practice initiative. Key terms are defined for understanding communities as a context for family life, including community results, community capacity, & social capital. The model is considered to have implications for informing community-oriented interventions in both military & civilian communities. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 57 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 122 of 487

A Community-Based Study of Family-Friendly Workplaces

Author: Secret, Mary; Sprang, Ginny; Rompf, Elizabeth Lewis; Anderson, Dinah G

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61505545?accountid=14667

Abstract: This applied research study is part of a collaborative effort by local government representatives, business leaders, & social work researchers to investigate workplace support for family needs. It is one of the first to report findings about family-friendly workplace policies & practices across different size & sector work organizations in one community. The prevalence & distribution of these policies & practices are investigated because they can enhance the quality of life for individuals & families & thus should be accessible to all members of the workforce. Findings from a sample of 88 small, medium, & large work organizations within the private & public sectors reveal that many employers offer flexible work arrangements while few provide child care services; large organizations as well as organizations in the public or nonprofit sectors provide more work-family stress management benefits than smaller organizations or those in the for-profit sector; large organizations also provide more leave time & more dependent care services. Comparability with other studies, future research needs, & implications for community practice are discussed. 5 Tables, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Community-Based+Study+of+Family-Friendly+Workplaces&amp;rft.au=Secret%2C+Mary%3BSprang%2C+Ginny%3BRompf%2C+Elizabeth+Lewis%3BAnderson%2C+Dinah+G&amp;rft.aulast=Secret&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Community-Based+Study+of+Family-Friendly+Workplaces&amp;rft.au=Secret%2C+Mary%3BSprang%2C+Ginny%3BRompf%2C+Elizabeth+Lewis%3BAnderson%2C+Dinah+G&amp;rft.aulast=Secret&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 123 of 487

Challenging Community Organizing: Facing the 21st Century

Author: Fisher, Robert1; Shragge, Eric1 Graduate School Social Work, U Houston, TX

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61439072?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article examines two approaches to community organizing: the social action model & the community development/community building model. From the early 1960s to the mid-1970s, the first model predominated; its advocates included Saul Alinsky & various organizations in the New Left & women's movements. Starting in the late 1970s, the community movement shifted toward advocacy & representation rather than organization per se. Corporations largely replaced people as the agents of social change, & governments attacked the power of trade unions & low-income people. The authors interpret these changes as obstacles to social action, & propose a blending of the two models, as illustrated by examples in Canada & the US. Recent resistance to an undemocratic global economic demonstrate the need for effective community organizing, if the goal of a democratic society is to succeed. 42 References. J. R. Callahan

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Challenging+Community+Organizing%3A+Facing+the+21st+Century&amp;rft.au=Fisher%2C+Robert%3BShragge%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Challenging+Community+Organizing%3A+Facing+the+21st+Century&amp;rft.au=Fisher%2C+Robert%3BShragge%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Mobilizing Church Communities to Prevent Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse: A Model Strategy and Its Evaluation

Author: Johnson, Knowlton1; Noe, Tim; Collins, David; Strader, Ted; Bucholtz, Gregory1 Community Systems Research Instit, Inc., Louisville, KY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61657005?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents a community mobilization strategy that focuses on the dynamics of organizing church communities to implement & evaluate alcohol & other drug abuse prevention programs. A model community mobilization strategy is described that highlights the involvement of church congregations in family recruitment, retention, & replication of alcohol & other drug prevention programs. The evaluation of the strategy provides evidence of the success in rural, suburban, & urban settings. Key lessons are presented to stimulate implementation of the model mobilization strategy in other church communities. 4 Tables, 1 Figure, 72 References. Adapted from the source document.
