Document 125 of 487

A case study of community collaboration: Georgia's experience with local governance and system reform

Author: Gillespie, Deanna M; Nackerud, Larry

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59838837?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the Georgia Policy Council for Children and Families, which has a mandate to increase local governance and reform the system of human service delivery; case study of implementation in Dawson County.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apais&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+case+study+of+community+collaboration%3A+Georgia%27s+experience+with+local+governance+and+system+reform&amp;rft.au=Gillespie%2C+Deanna+M%3BNackerud%2C+Larry&amp;rft.aulast=Gillespie&amp;rft.aufirst=Deanna&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 127 of 487

Models and Tactics Taught in Community Organization Courses: Findings from a Survey of Practice Instructors

Author: Hardina, Donna11 Dept Social Work Education, California State U, Fresno

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622529?accountid=14667

Abstract: In a mail questionnaire survey, most of the 58 responding members of the Assoc for Community Organization & Social Administration who teach community practice courses reported that social action was the model of practice discussed in class. More than 33% expressed a personal preference for this model. Strategies taught in the classroom included collaboration, campaign, & confrontation. Respondents were most likely to express a personal preference for collaboration & least likely to prefer confrontation. 6 Tables, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Models+and+Tactics+Taught+in+Community+Organization+Courses%3A+Findings+from+a+Survey+of+Practice+Instructors&amp;rft.au=Hardina%2C+Donna&amp;rft.aulast=Hardina&amp;rft.aufirst=Donna&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 128 of 487

The Community Practice Pilot Project: Integrating Methods, Field, Community Assessment, and Experiential Learning

Author: Johnson, Alice K11 Jane Addams Coll Social Work, U Illinois, Chicago akj@uic.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467260?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Community Practice Pilot Project tested an approach for preparing students for work in organizations in which no social workers were employed. Field placements were clustered in a small geographic area. Classroom learning was linked with field instruction, advising, & experiential learning. Goals included integrating content on community-based practice into the foundation curriculum, exposing students to community building initiatives, & influencing the master's curriculum. The project provided some evidence that early exposure to community initiatives has a positive influence on increasing student enrollment in macro concentrations & courses. Implications for social work include viewing the "environment-surrounding-the-person" as a starting point for instruction in foundation methods courses. 3 Tables, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Community+Practice+Pilot+Project%3A+Integrating+Methods%2C+Field%2C+Community+Assessment%2C+and+Experiential+Learning&amp;rft.au=Johnson%2C+Alice+K&amp;rft.aulast=Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=Alice&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Freire's Message for Social Workers: Looking Back, Looking Ahead

Author: Carroll, Julie1; Minkler, Meredith1 U California, Berkeley

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458868?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper re-examines key concepts in Paulo Freire's popular education approach & their compatibility with social work philosophy & practice on the group & community levels. Freire's vision of the field of social work is explored, & two case studies are utilized to illustrate the application of this approach & its promise for community practice at the dawn of a new century. 59 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 131 of 487

A Community Building Perspective in Social Work Education

Author: Hendricks, Carmen Ortiz1; Rudich, Glynn1 School Social Work, Hunter Coll, City U, New York, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61466504?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper presents a community-building perspective as integral to all aspects of social work education. Community-building theories have existed for many years but community-building practice approaches are just beginning to emerge. Organizational studies have primarily looked at community building in suburban or rural areas & for prevention of child abuse & neglect (Earls, McGuire, & Shay 1994; Garbarino & Kostelny, 1992; Glisson & James, 1992; Halpern, 1996; Mulroy & Shay, 1997; Shay, 1995) or in youth leadership development (Finn & Checkoway, 1998; Lerner, 1996). These studies demonstrate the basic principles of community-building practice. These include involving community residents as partners rather than clients as they establish community or neighborhood networks that use empowerment strategies & a community asset approach (Naparstek & Dooley, 1997). This paper examines incorporating community-building practice into graduate social work education primarily through field education & eventually throughout the foundation & specialization curriculum. The authors will address the viability of integrating a community-building perspective into social work education with the goal of developing practice approaches in community building, which social work educators can use & integrate into the classroom & field teaching. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Community+Building+Perspective+in+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Hendricks%2C+Carmen+Ortiz%3BRudich%2C+Glynn&amp;rft.aulast=Hendricks&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmen&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Community+Building+Perspective+in+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Hendricks%2C+Carmen+Ortiz%3BRudich%2C+Glynn&amp;rft.aulast=Hendricks&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmen&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 132 of 487

Educating Students for Community-Based Partnerships

Author: Margolis, Lewis H1; Stevens, Rachel; Laraia, Barbara; Ammerman, Alice; Harlan, Chris; Dodds, Janice; Eng, Eugenia; Pollard, Margaret1 U North Carolina, Chapel Hill

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457096?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many courses for students in professional schools may expect or require a learning experience "in the community." Simple placement in a community does not assure, however, that students will develop competencies from a community-based perspective, that is, competencies that enable professionals to (1) enhance the capacity of community members to serve in partnership endeavors, (2) appreciate the role of participation by underrepresented or underserved populations, & (3) develop skills for mobilizing community resources to address community-defined priorities. This article describes six domains -- course goals, partners, exposure, product, classroom activities, & disciplines -- to characterize courses & other learning experiences in order to assess the extent to which they promote community-based competencies. 1 Table, 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 133 of 487

Passing a Mental Health Levy: Lessons for the Community Practice Professional

Author: Allen, Janenne1; Boettcher, Richard1 Coll Social Work, Ohio State U, Columbus

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61493173?accountid=14667

Abstract: The "devolution revolution" has decreased federal & state roles in the funding of social services & increased the burden on local sources, both public & private. Focus here is on how a OH community passed an initially unpopular property tax levy earmarked to support local drug, alcohol, & mental health services, illustrating how social workers, employing specific community practice knowledge, provided leadership to the successful campaign. This example of community practice leadership includes building & maintaining coalitions, managing group tension & conflict, & demonstrating fundamental social work values. 1 Table, 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 134 of 487

The Politics of Knowledge in Theory and Practice: Collective Research and Political Action in a Grassroots Community Organization

Author: Kline, Michael1; Dolgon, Corey; Dresser, Laura1 Shipley School, Bryn Mawr, PA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61466894?accountid=14667

Abstract: The authors, former graduate students at the U of Michigan in Ann Arbor, discuss their work with a grassroots community organization (the Homeless Action Committee) engaged in direct action organizing around issues of homelessness, poverty & economic development in Ann Arbor between 1989 & 1994. They find that the group developed an innovative approach to collective intellectual work as an integral part of its political activity. The work of the Homeless Action Committee is put forward as a model for progressive intellectuals seeking engagement with the theory & practice of Freirean pedagogy, emphasizing critical consciousness & political action challenging oppression. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 135 of 487

Starting Small: Strategy and the Evolution of Structure in a Community-Based Collaboration

Author: Mulroy, Elizabeth A11 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61505640?accountid=14667

Abstract: Comprehensive multisector community initiatives are currently regarded as the preferred strategy to use when trying to address social problems at the local level. However, this article suggests that faced with political uncertainty, low-income communities may derive benefits from the strategy of starting small. Findings are presented from an organizational analysis of a seven-member community-based collaboration formed to reduce child abuse & neglect. They suggest that starting small allowed the interorganizational structure to evolve over time in three phases of access, differentiation, & connectiveness. The characteristics & impacts of each phase will be described & analyzed. The article draws four lessons for community-based organizations interested in collaborating: flexible structure matters; neighborhoods differ; a strong nonprofit sector is needed; & collaborating is a learned behavior. Finally, implications are drawn for human services management & community practice. 3 Figures, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Starting+Small%3A+Strategy+and+the+Evolution+of+Structure+in+a+Community-Based+Collaboration&amp;rft.au=Mulroy%2C+Elizabeth+A&amp;rft.aulast=Mulroy&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Urban Community Action Planning Inspires Teenagers to Transform Their Community and Their Identity

Author: Ross, Laurie1; Coleman, Mardia1 Public Policy Dept, U Massachusetts, Boston

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61643060?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses how a participatory community development technique, Urban Community Action Planning (UCAP), transformed a group of city teenagers into community planners. This teen group, Teen Inspirators, On the Move, formed in response to a community need for more youth activities & programming that was identified during a community planning initiative sponsored by the Oak Hill Community Development Corp in Worcester, MA. The Teen Inspirators committed themselves to revitalizing their community & changing their own image in the neighborhood. Participatory planning techniques gave youth the voice, power, & tools to accomplish these goals. 2 Tables, 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

What Conferences Accomplish for Social Change Organizations: Illustrations from the Community-Based Development Movement

Author: Rubin, Herbert J11 Dept Sociology, Northern Illinois U, DeKalb

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61422351?accountid=14667

Abstract: Conferences allow activists & their supporters to share information, seek out technical help, & create supportive networks. At conferences, participants discuss the values that guide their work & by doing so agree on a shared meaning of their social change organizations. Conferences are focusing events that help create a social movement. 1 Table, 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 138 of 487

Mentoring At-Risk Chicano Children and Their Parents: The Role of Community: Theory and Practice

Author: Barron-McKeagney, Theresa1; Woody, Jane D; D'Souza, Henry J1 School Social Work, U Nebraska, Omaha theresa@unomaha.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61500868?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses a mentoring project aimed at preventing youth violence & attributes initial success to principles of community practice. The program was unique in being housed in the community targeting young Chicano children for long-term mentoring, & providing support for the non-English-speaking parents. Focus is on three theoretical elements -- mentoring, empowerment, & multicultural consciousness -- all of which implicitly embody concepts of community. Discussion centers on how these concepts played a role in the day-to-day challenges of implementation & in meeting initial program goals. This article offers insights to those wishing to duplicate this mentoring effort with Chicano or other multicultural clients. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Mentoring+At-Risk+Chicano+Children+and+Their+Parents%3A+The+Role+of+Community%3A+Theory+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Barron-McKeagney%2C+Theresa%3BWoody%2C+Jane+D%3BD%27Souza%2C+Henry+J&amp;rft.aulast=Barron-McKeagney&amp;rft.aufirst=Theresa&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 139 of 487

Use of the Internet for Community Practice: A Delphi Study

Author: Nartz, Matthew1; Schoech, Dick1 c/o Schoech -- School Social Work, U Texas, Arlington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61459217?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Internet is a relatively new community practice tool with immense potential for more effective & efficient delivery of services. The lack of research about Internet community practice is an obstacle to the effective & efficient use of Internet tools. This research used the Delphi technique to elicit the opinions of experts on how the Internet tools of email, newsgroups, text, listservs, search engines, & chat are used by the four primary models of community practice found on the Internet (information dissemination, organization building, mobilization, & community planning). Findings show that a substantial number of people use community practice sites. The most useful Internet tools for the four Internet community practice models studied were text presentation & email. The least useful tools were newsgroups & chat. Barriers to Internet community practice include quality & currency of information, bandwidth, staff time, agency support, rapid technological change, marketing, browser consistency, user skills, & the lack of Internet access by potential users. The study concluded that Internet community practice is effective & will continue to grow as society enters the information age. The findings are particularly relevant for community practice agencies interested in setting up or enhancing an agency Web site to help provide services. 4 Figures, 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 140 of 487

Bridging Science and Practice: The Integrated Model of Community-Based Evaluation (IMCBE)

Author: Telfair, Joseph1; Mulvihill, Beverly A1 Dept Maternal & Child Health & Pediatrics, Schools Public Health & Medicine, U Alabama, Birmingham

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457075?accountid=14667

Abstract: A trend in community-based evaluation studies is to include everyone affected by the work -- the community, administrators, & participants -- in their design & implementation. This concept has been accepted by communities & community evaluators, but a concern persists that the scientific integrity, reliability, & validity of these studies are compromised. To address these concerns, presented here are both the multiconceptual & hands-on practical aspects of the Integrated Model of Community-Based Evaluation (IMCBE). The utility of the IMCBE is illustrated with the case example of the Sickle Cell Disease Assoc of the Piedmont (Greensboro, NC) Home Health Study. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 81 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Bridging+Science+and+Practice%3A+The+Integrated+Model+of+Community-Based+Evaluation+%28IMCBE%29&amp;rft.au=Telfair%2C+Joseph%3BMulvihill%2C+Beverly+A&amp;rft.aulast=Telfair&amp;rft.aufirst=Joseph&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 141 of 487

Educating Students for Multicultural Community Practice

Author: Gutierrez, Lorraine1; Alvarez, Ann Rosegrant1 School Social Work, U Michigan, Ann Arbor

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61648919?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the concept of multicultural community organizing & the issues involved in educating for this form of practice. After outlining the development of a course on multicultural community organizing, described are experiences in teaching it; specific teaching strategies & methodologies, including exercises & assignments; & outcomes for students, educators, & communities. Social work educators are encouraged to consider how to incorporate these & similar perspectives, methods, & exercises throughout the community practice curriculum, so that an awareness of multicultural dynamics & issues can be part of understanding & determining the use of tactics. 2 Tables, 44 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 142 of 487

Coordinated Service Delivery and Children's Well-Being: Community Resource Coordination Groups of Texas

Author: Springer, David W1; Sharp, Deborah Stokes; Foy, Theresa A1 School Social Work, U Texas, Austin

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61490118?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interagency collaborations are uniquely suited to meeting the increased needs of communities in today's environment of reduced federal funding & devolution of services to the state & local levels (Gore, 1993). In TX, interagency collaborations take place through Community Resource Coordination Groups (CRCGs), which were created by the Texas Legislature to coordinate local service delivery for children & their families who often "fall through the cracks" due to having multiple needs. This article presents an evaluation of CRCG operations, with a focus on identified best practices, related obstacles, & suggestions for improvement. The researchers visited CRCG sites, & conducted semistructured face-to-face interviews, as well as a mail survey, with CRCG staff. Overall, CRCGs appear to effectively enhance the delivery of coordinated services in an effort to meet the multiple needs of the children & families that they serve. Recommendations for policy & practice are discussed, such as spearheading community action structures (Poole, 1997) that may help CRCGs more effectively meet the needs of their respective local communities. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Coordinated+Service+Delivery+and+Children%27s+Well-Being%3A+Community+Resource+Coordination+Groups+of+Texas&amp;rft.au=Springer%2C+David+W%3BSharp%2C+Deborah+Stokes%3BFoy%2C+Theresa+A&amp;rft.aulast=Springer&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=39&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 145 of 487

The Group-Centered BSW Curriculum for Community Practice: An Essay

Author: Gardella, Lorrie Greenhouse11 Dept Social Work, Saint Joseph Coll, CT lggardella@sjc.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61466364?accountid=14667

Abstract: The "mundane extreme environment" of racism & poverty follows us into the new millennium (McAdoo, 1986). In response, I propose a group-centered curriculum for community practice as the professional foundation for social work education. Shifting the curricular focus from individual development to social development & from a domestic perspective to an international human rights perspective, the group-centered curriculum would teach social group work, intergroup work, & interprofessional practice as methods for promoting social & economic justice. 56 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 147 of 487

Product and Process Dialectic: Developing an Indigenous Approach to Community Development Training

Author: Wint, Eleanor1; Sewpaul, Vishantie1 School Social & Community Studies, U Natal, Republic South Africa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61668200?accountid=14667

Abstract: An appreciation of constructivist theory guides the authors' understanding of the circular nature of community development training & learning, particularly in a society in transition from division to unification. Focus here is on the process of indigenization of a community development curriculum, emphasizing the consequential empowerment of both self & community as the students become involved in creating an environment for social & economic change in the new South Africa. The teaching innovations examined include learning beyond the classroom & peer-mediated video learning. Students were from black, Indian, white, & colored, middle-income African families & carried out their community development task in a selected low-income black community. The teaching/learning innovations are discussed in light of N. Gokarn's (1994) three competencies: development of self-awareness, knowledge about the learner, & use of the small-group technology of education. 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Product+and+Process+Dialectic%3A+Developing+an+Indigenous+Approach+to+Community+Development+Training&amp;rft.au=Wint%2C+Eleanor%3BSewpaul%2C+Vishantie&amp;rft.aulast=Wint&amp;rft.aufirst=Eleanor&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 148 of 487

Re-Uniting African American Scholars, Practitioners and the Community: A Model and Case Study

Author: Mitchell, Jacquelyn1; Lynch, Rufus Sylvester1 School Social Work, U Southern Mississippi, Hattiesburg j.mitchell@usm.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61466746?accountid=14667

Abstract: That African American communities are too often desolate places where it seems, in Hurston's words, "life has been & gone," argues for increasingly creative community development strategies. This paper presents a historically based, corporate empowerment model designed to address the desolation, by reuniting scholars, practitioners, & other community stakeholders for collective benefit & empowerment. Through an African-centered evaluative discussion, the authors assume the professional risk of sharing an outcome that may be viewed as a failure. The efficacy of the model, juxtaposed against the continued powerlessness of African American scholars, practitioners, & communities, is explored. Practice challenges & implications are discussed. 61 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Re-Uniting+African+American+Scholars%2C+Practitioners+and+the+Community%3A+A+Model+and+Case+Study&amp;rft.au=Mitchell%2C+Jacquelyn%3BLynch%2C+Rufus+Sylvester&amp;rft.aulast=Mitchell&amp;rft.aufirst=Jacquelyn&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 149 of 487

Community Participation: Old Wine in New Bottles?

Author: Daley, John Michael1; Marsiglia, Flavio Francisco1 c/o Marsiglia -- School Social Work, Arizona State U, Tempe

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458883?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports a study conducted on a citywide partnership seeking to mobilize community members, city government, & other partners toward substance abuse prevention. This community development effort attained mixed results during its planning phase. This study's mixed qualitative/quantitative research design is imbedded in the citizen/community participation literature. The views of community members & agency representatives about their experiences & the meanings they attach to their involvement provide insightful information about community participation in a large southwestern city. Different community participation themes are identified & presented as lessons learned, suggesting ways in which practitioners & researchers can support communities as they organize through partnerships. 2 Tables, 53 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 150 of 487

Transformative Community Practice: Building a Model for Developing Extremely Low Income African-American Communities

Author: O'Donnell, Sandra M1; Karanja, Sokoni T1 Dept Public Administration, Roosevelt U, Chicago, IL

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457085?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines how well models & concepts of community practice fit their practice in an extremely low-income, urban, African American community. The authors describe the evolution of their Centers for New Horizons agency's response to community disinvestment in an area of Chicago, IL, over the past 30 years, ie, to create indigenous African-centered organizations that can transform how people see themselves, the community, & their futures. Early childhood education, social services, economic development, & leadership training & organizing are core programs. Model builders & educators are urged to include the concept of transformation as a community change goal, & to strengthen attention to institution building skills, "cultural work," & capital formation. 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Transformative+Community+Practice%3A+Building+a+Model+for+Developing+Extremely+Low+Income+African-American+Communities&amp;rft.au=O%27Donnell%2C+Sandra+M%3BKaranja%2C+Sokoni+T&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Donnell&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 151 of 487

Welfare Reform and Community-Based Organizations: Implications for Policy, Practice, and Education

Author: Bischoff, Ursula M1; Reisch, Michael S1 Human Services Agency, San Mateo County, CA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467276?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses the effects of welfare reform on the ability of CBOs to respond to client & community needs. A stratified sample of 64 organizations providing youth, job training, behavioral health, shelter, & nutritional services in an urban neighborhood yielded 42 participants (response rate 66%). In-depth interviews of executive directors assessed changes in staffing, client population, program, funding, & interorganizational relationships. Content & summary statistical analyses of transcribed interviews & focus groups, & of documents provided by state & local welfare agencies describing efforts to involve nonprofit CBOs in welfare reform implementation were conducted. Social work curricula should reflect the changing practice environment. Under conditions of heightened uncertainty, students need competencies in community economic development; strategic & cooperative program planning; service network development & analysis; & advocacy. Field placements in CBOs can also stimulate collaborative action research projects responsive to legislative mandates. Offering part-time & continuing education programs can enhance opportunities for CBO administrators to gain skills necessary to manage change. Specific educational examples based on the authors' experience are discussed. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Welfare+Reform+and+Community-Based+Organizations%3A+Implications+for+Policy%2C+Practice%2C+and+Education&amp;rft.au=Bischoff%2C+Ursula+M%3BReisch%2C+Michael+S&amp;rft.aulast=Bischoff&amp;rft.aufirst=Ursula&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 152 of 487

Consumer Perceptions of Outreach and Marketing Strategies for Family Resource Centers

Author: O'Donnell, Julie1; Giovannoni, Jeanne M1 Dept Social Work, California State U, Long Beach

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61521671?accountid=14667

Abstract: Family Resource Centers (FRC) are designed to recruit, provide services to, & involve low-income residents in leadership roles. These centers should be accessible to all families in a community. However, it is often difficult to recruit residents who might be socially isolated or alienated from institutions to participate in services & program leadership. This study explored current, past, & potential consumers' perceptions of the methods of community outreach & reasons people might join or not join an FRC. Although the most commonly cited outreach strategy was "word-of-mouth" recruiting, a multifaceted outreach strategy is indicated. This strategy incorporates agency referral, community presentations, & use of the media. FRCs need to be aware of the reasons participants come to FRCs both to design appropriate services as well as to develop their recruiting plans & materials. Outreach strategies should also consider the fact that residents may fear a strange situation as well as the stigma of seeking services. Implications for practice are discussed. 7 Tables, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Consumer+Perceptions+of+Outreach+and+Marketing+Strategies+for+Family+Resource+Centers&amp;rft.au=O%27Donnell%2C+Julie%3BGiovannoni%2C+Jeanne+M&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Donnell&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 153 of 487

The Diversity Functions of Organizations That Confront Oppression: The Evolution of Three Social Movements

Author: MacNair, Ray H1; Fowler, Leigh; Harris, John1 School Social Work, U Georgia, Athens

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61648888?accountid=14667

Abstract: The 20th-century history of three identity movements is reviewed with reference to their approach toward their oppressors. The African American movement, the women's movement, & the lesbian-gay-bisexual movement appear to follow similar paths from accommodation-assimilation, to normative confrontation, disruptive confrontation, separatism, introspective self-help, & pluralistic integration. It is hypothesized & demonstrated that these paths are evolutionary, as each stance appears to encourage conditions for the next stage. The paths are not linear, however, & it is the movement as a whole, not any one organization, that is evolutionary. It is argued that social workers have distinct roles to play in each stage. 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Diversity+Functions+of+Organizations+That+Confront+Oppression%3A+The+Evolution+of+Three+Social+Movements&amp;rft.au=MacNair%2C+Ray+H%3BFowler%2C+Leigh%3BHarris%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=MacNair&amp;rft.aufirst=Ray&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Diversity+Functions+of+Organizations+That+Confront+Oppression%3A+The+Evolution+of+Three+Social+Movements&amp;rft.au=MacNair%2C+Ray+H%3BFowler%2C+Leigh%3BHarris%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=MacNair&amp;rft.aufirst=Ray&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: *Feminism; *Civil Rights Movements; *Political Culture; *Social Movements; *Organizations (Social); *Organizational Development; *Developmental Stages; *Social Identity; Ethnic Identity; Group Identity; Black Americans; Homosexuality

Classification: 6152: community development/organizing

Title: The Diversity Functions of Organizations That Confront Oppression: The Evolution of Three Social Movements

Document 154 of 487

Grassroots Leadership Training: A Case Study of an Effort to Integrate Theory and Method

Author: Zachary, Eric11 Instit Education & Social Policy, New York U, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61657052?accountid=14667

Abstract: The breakdown of community in poor & working-class urban neighborhoods is well documented. Most efforts to rebuild a sense of community assign a major role to indigenous leaders. The development of critically conscious group-centered leaders best fits the contemporary grassroots neighborhood context. The challenge for the teacher/trainer who embraces this approach is to align methodology & philosophy so that they reflect & reinforce each other. In a case study of one such program in New York City, the following methodological elements were identified as critical: rituals of engagement; the sharing of power; a culture of participation characterized by safety, respect, & high expectations; & skillful, yet humble, facilitation to create solidarity & equality within the group. These dimensions led to the emergence of a community of learners in which the participants took significant risks in their development as leaders. 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Grassroots+Leadership+Training%3A+A+Case+Study+of+an+Effort+to+Integrate+Theory+and+Method&amp;rft.au=Zachary%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Zachary&amp;rft.aufirst=Eric&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Grassroots+Leadership+Training%3A+A+Case+Study+of+an+Effort+to+Integrate+Theory+and+Method&amp;rft.au=Zachary%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Zachary&amp;rft.aufirst=Eric&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 155 of 487

The 79-Cent Campaign: The Use of On-Line Mailing Lists for Electronic Advocacy

Author: Menon, Goutham M11 Coll Social Work, U South Carolina, Columbia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467054?accountid=14667

Abstract: Online groups have carved a niche of much importance in today's "cyber-society." This case study exemplifies how one online group went beyond its primary function of being a discussion group, to be a more productive, empowering tool for electronic advocacy. By orchestrating an effective campaign to bring to the forefront issues affecting the lives of those living with severe mental illnesses, the work of this group can be seen as an example in the effective use of the Internet for advocacy & empowerment. 1 Appendix, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59834695?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the demographic characteristics of groups active in social welfare policy-making in Minnesota, Mississippi, Pennsylvania, and Texas, focusing on influence in the executive and legislative branches, and the groups' self-reported effectiveness; US.

Document 157 of 487

Building on Mutual Goals: The Intersection of Community Practice and Church-Based Organizing

Author: Staral, Janice M11 Dept Social & Cultural Sciences, Marquette U, Milwaukee, WI

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61457471?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this era of diminishing federal & state funds for social services, greater attention has been directed toward how social work & the religious sector can cooperate in providing services. It is suggested here that social workers should move beyond this focus & begin to identify & join in collective action with local congregations or faith-based organizations, which take an activist approach toward community needs. A case study of an activist central-city church in Milwaukee, WI, illustrates how churches can be involved in community change. Social workers are encouraged to consider all methods of collaboration with the religious sector that would lead to the mutual goal of community betterment. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Building+on+Mutual+Goals%3A+The+Intersection+of+Community+Practice+and+Church-Based+Organizing&amp;rft.au=Staral%2C+Janice+M&amp;rft.aulast=Staral&amp;rft.aufirst=Janice&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=85&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 158 of 487

Consensus Organizing: A Practice Model for Community Building

Author: Beck, Elizabeth L1; Eichler, Michael1 School Social Work, Georgia State U, Atlanta ebeck@GSU.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61424194?accountid=14667

Abstract: Through a case study, this paper explores consensus organizing as a community practice model explicating its core tenets, strategies, & tactics. The premises of consensus organizing make it different from conflict approaches. Specifically, consensus organizing believes that power does not have to be redistributed but it can be grown, mutual self-interest provides a powerful tool for change, people often behave in reasonable ways when given reasonable choices, & alliances that support social justice goals can be formed between people of divergent backgrounds. Consensus organizing should not be viewed as a replacement for other forms of community organizing & political activity, but rather as an additional tool for organizers. 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Consensus+Organizing%3A+A+Practice+Model+for+Community+Building&amp;rft.au=Beck%2C+Elizabeth+L%3BEichler%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Beck&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Consensus+Organizing%3A+A+Practice+Model+for+Community+Building&amp;rft.au=Beck%2C+Elizabeth+L%3BEichler%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Beck&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2000-01-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Collaborative Self-Help Community Development: When Is the Strategy Warranted?

Author: Rothman, Jack11 School Public Policy & Social Research, U California, Los Angeles

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61671499?accountid=14667

Abstract: Collaborative self-help has been the predominant approach to community development for a number of years. Here, the consensus strategy is revisited & contrasted with more recent approaches. Conditions under which it is still an appropriate model for community betterment are identified, & considerations for implementing community development considered. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Organizing Cyberspace: Strategies for Teaching about Community Practice and Technology

Author: McNutt, John11 School Social Work, Boston Coll, Chestnut Hill, MA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61625993?accountid=14667

Abstract: The coming millennium will bring new challenges & opportunities to those who struggle for the survival of communities. The incorporation of information technology is important to the conduct & teaching of community practice. Discussed here is how technology is changing community practice; implications for social work education are considered. Focus is on the role of information technology in changing the context for community practice; the incorporation of information technology into current & emergent community practice interventions; & ways in which these issues can be taught within the community practice curriculum. 1 Figure, 45 References. Document 161 of 487

Political activism of social work educators

Author: Mary, Nancy L

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59838507?accountid=14667

Abstract: Focuses on political involvement and political opportunities for social workers; based on a survey of 130 MSW (master's in social work) classroom and field educators from two metropolitan universities, one private and one public, in southwestern US.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apais&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Political+activism+of+social+work+educators&amp;rft.au=Mary%2C+Nancy+L&amp;rft.aulast=Mary&amp;rft.aufirst=Nancy&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 162 of 487

Highly Effective Human Services Interest Groups: Seven Key Practices

Author: Hoefer, Richard11 School Social Work, U Texas, Arlington rhoefer@utarlg.uta.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61523743?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on information collected from Washington, DC-based interest groups active in influencing social welfare policy, I have identified seven tactics that highly effective groups use more than least-effective groups. Highly effective groups work more often to develop consensus among experts, pursue issues in court, aid the election of particular candidates, participate in public hearings, bring current regulations to executive branch attention, take changes to proposed regulations to the issuing agency, & offer drafts of regulations prior to publication in The Federal Register. These results, by themselves & in conjunction with other research efforts, indicate more effective lobbying efforts & more empirically grounded policy practice by all social workers. 3 Tables, 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Highly+Effective+Human+Services+Interest+Groups%3A+Seven+Key+Practices&amp;rft.au=Hoefer%2C+Richard&amp;rft.aulast=Hoefer&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 163 of 487

Choosing to Do Participatory Research: An Example and Issues of Fit to Consider

Author: Alvarez, Ann Rosegrant1; Gutierrez, Lorraine M1 School Social Work, Wayne State U, Detroit, MI

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61495194?accountid=14667

Abstract: Participatory research is an increasingly popular approach, & considered by some to be synonymous with progressive social work research practice. It is important, however, to assess its suitability for both a given project & the people involved with it. Points to consider include fit of the approach with research(s), community, topic, organizational context, & constraints. This article describes a participatory research process through which community members collaborated in the design & implementation of a project to identify, learn about the work of, & develop training based on the perspectives of people doing multicultural community organizing in Detroit, MI. Discussion sections present value, costs, & limitations of this project, as well as issues & recommendations for those considering or using participatory research methods. 2 Tables, 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Choosing+to+Do+Participatory+Research%3A+An+Example+and+Issues+of+Fit+to+Consider&amp;rft.au=Alvarez%2C+Ann+Rosegrant%3BGutierrez%2C+Lorraine+M&amp;rft.aulast=Alvarez&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 166 of 487

Powerful Partnerships

Author: Arches, Joan11 Coll Public & Community Service, U Massachusetts, Boston

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61526735?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using a multicultural, intergenerational partnership model, undergraduate students participated in a service learning collaborative project with immigrant & refugee youths. Recognizing the multiple issues facing newcomers to this country, the collaborative attempted to teach community problem solving & cross-cultural leadership skills while promoting civic participation. The youths from Cape Verdian, Haitian, & Somalian community agencies identified a problem area: the public education system, specifically, accessing services & knowing one's rights. Both groups of students worked as partners conducting needs assessments, researching information & creating a booklet for use by parents & students. In addition to meeting specially identified needs, the project heightened ethnic pride & intergenerational understanding for all participants. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Powerful+Partnerships&amp;rft.au=Arches%2C+Joan&amp;rft.aulast=Arches&amp;rft.aufirst=Joan&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 167 of 487

Coalition Activity of Social Change Organizations in a Public Campaign: The Influence of Motives, Resources and Processes on Levels of Activity

Author: Kaufman, Roni11 Social Work Dept, Ben Gurion U, Beer-Sheva, Israel ronika@bgumail.bgu.ac.il

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61468389?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article focuses on the ways that various factors, conditions, & processes affected the creation of different levels of activity found in a coalition of 19 social change organizations that conducted a successful public campaign for tax reform in Israel during 1987/88. Eight of the organizations were active on behalf of widows & disabled people; five represented low-income neighborhoods; two promoted child welfare; & two dealt with women's issues. Other organizations were the National Social Worker's association, a senior citizen's organization, & a peace advocacy organization. Members attributed high levels of coalition activity among organizations to a combination of the following factors: an internal organizational situation that enabled organizations to invest resources in the joint activity; a representative with resources that fit well with the chosen coalition strategy; & conditions & processes on the coalition level that enabled, & even encouraged, the use of the organization's resources during the period of the coalition activity. The research finds how campaign coalitions that consist of a diverse group of social change organizations are developed & sustained. This knowledge can improve planning & operating of successful social change coalitions. 3 Tables, 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Coalition+Activity+of+Social+Change+Organizations+in+a+Public+Campaign%3A+The+Influence+of+Motives%2C+Resources+and+Processes+on+Levels+of+Activity&amp;rft.au=Kaufman%2C+Roni&amp;rft.aulast=Kaufman&amp;rft.aufirst=Roni&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Coalition+Activity+of+Social+Change+Organizations+in+a+Public+Campaign%3A+The+Influence+of+Motives%2C+Resources+and+Processes+on+Levels+of+Activity&amp;rft.au=Kaufman%2C+Roni&amp;rft.aulast=Kaufman&amp;rft.aufirst=Roni&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 168 of 487

Neighborhood Resiliency

Author: Breton, Margot11 Faculty Social Work, U Toronto, Ontario

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61473890?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper argues that a neighborhood's resiliency depends on the stability of its initial equilibrium state. A neighborhood that possesses a large stock of social & physical capital is not easily dislodged from its beneficial equilibrium, but if dislodged by adverse shocks, its reservoir of capital enables it to return to its initial equilibrium. In the opposite case, a neighborhood severely deprived of social & physical capital & which crosses a critical threshold is not easily dislodged from its harmful equilibrium. The paper first analyzes the properties of resilient neighborhoods, arguing that an increment in any one of them will increase resiliency. Then it argues that, ceteris paraibus, public & corporate policies that result in an increase in resources will strengthen these properties, while opposite policies will weaken them, & beyond a critical threshold, will result in a "lock-in" effect whereby the neighborhood loses its capacity to bounce back from adversity. 1 Figure, 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Neighborhood+Resiliency&amp;rft.au=Breton%2C+Margot&amp;rft.aulast=Breton&amp;rft.aufirst=Margot&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 169 of 487

Recruiting Participants for Community Practice Interventions: Merging Community Practice Theory and Social Movement Theory

Author: Castelloe, Paul1; Prokopy, Joshua1 Center Participatory Change, Asheville, NC

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61425199?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper focuses on recruiting participants for community practice interventions. We begin by presenting a case study of the recruitment methods used in a community-based development effort in the southeastern US. In the next sections, we review some key issues in recruitment as discussed in the community practice & social movement literatures, & use them to reflect on the case study. In the final section, we try to make social movement theory more accessible to community practitioners by developing a set of principles for use in recruitment. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

The implementation of a "work first" welfare-to-work program in a changing environment

Author: Cooney, Kate; Weaver, Dale

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59866527?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the federal 1996 Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act (PRWORA), and innovative welfare-to-work (WtW) program promoted by Goodwill Industries of Southern California (GISC) targeting a low-skill Spanish-speaking population; Los Angeles county, California. Based on a survey of 97 participants followed by interviews with managers, job developers, supervisors, and employment training.

Document 171 of 487

Community Practice Issues in the 21st Century: Questions and Challenges for Empowerment-Oriented Practitioners

Author: Cox, Enid Opal11 Graduate School Social Work, U Denver, CO

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61424848?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community practice has developed an increasing array of models & skills in response to environmental stimuli & the development of social work practice. The beginning of the 21st century is a period of rapid & complex change. This paper identifies key factors, as well as challenges, facing community practice advocates. This paper proposes that many models of community practice, often operating simultaneously & in conscious & close relationship to empowerment-oriented, new social movements, will be necessary to advance social justice values & the interests of oppressed populations in the coming decades. Finally, this paper raises special challenges in this environment for empowerment-oriented practitioners. 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Practice+Issues+in+the+21st+Century%3A+Questions+and+Challenges+for+Empowerment-Oriented+Practitioners&amp;rft.au=Cox%2C+Enid+Opal&amp;rft.aulast=Cox&amp;rft.aufirst=Enid&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 172 of 487

Graduate Education for Social Change: A Study of Political Social Workers

Author: Fisher, Robert1; Weedman, Anne; Alex, Glen; Stout, Karen D1 Graduate School Social Work, U Houston, TX

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61483398?accountid=14667

Abstract: Is it possible to conduct an effective, progressive, & politicized program for graduate students in our contemporary conservative context? This article evaluates the outcomes over seven years of a pioneering program in Political Social Work. Based on survey data of Political Social Work alumni, it addresses four outcome measures: enrollment, satisfaction with curriculum & field opportunities, job & career development, & persistence of political ideology & practice. While being "political" during the past decade is clearly different than it was in the 1960s, the evidence proposes that political content & practice can have a significant place in both social work education & the field. More specifically, the study demonstrates that politicized social workers in the 1990s were able after graduation to secure employment, sustain progressive values, & practice political social work. 4 Figures, 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Graduate+Education+for+Social+Change%3A+A+Study+of+Political+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Fisher%2C+Robert%3BWeedman%2C+Anne%3BAlex%2C+Glen%3BStout%2C+Karen+D&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=43&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 173 of 487

A Critical Look at a Contemporary Welfare-to-Work Program in the Light of the Historic Settlement Ideal

Author: Kreutziger, Sarah Sloan1; Ager, Richard; Lewis, Judith S; England, Suzanne1 School Social Work, Tulane U, New Orleans, LA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61522223?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores the differences & similarities between the historic settlements & a venture of two universities to develop supportive services in housing developments that promote financial & personal self-sufficiency for the residents. Our school of social work participates with a vision of a contemporary neighborhood ideal composed of such concepts as empowerment, participating consciousness, community building, the learning organization, & an asset/strengths perspective. Our experiences inform our curriculum & provide a perspective on what changes are needed if social work is to have a strong future in this type of community work. 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Participation and service integration in community-based initiatives

Author: Edelman, Ira

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/59836471?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the gap between promise and practice in CBIs, focusing on challenges in forming community links in dealing with school, family, work, and other social issues; includes experience of the Caring Communities program in Springfield, Missouri.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apais&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Participation+and+service+integration+in+community-based+initiatives&amp;rft.au=Edelman%2C+Ira&amp;rft.aulast=Edelman&amp;rft.aufirst=Ira&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 177 of 487

Civic Engagement and Sense of Community in the Military

Author: Bowen, Gary L1; Martin, James A; Mancini, Jay A; Nelson, John P1 U North Carolina, Chapel Hill

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61526779?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the context of current discussions among social commentators about the status & well-being of community in American society, this article examines the nature of civic engagement & sense of community in the US military. Framed by social disorganization theory, a conceptual model is developed & tested with a sample of married active duty Air Force (AF) members. Our analysis examines variations in perceptions of sense of community as a consequence of three indicators of civic engagement: community capacity, community connections, & community participation. The results suggest that community participation plays a particularly important role in influencing the sense of community that active duty members feel. Human service organizations & unit leaders are discussed as critical resources in promoting civic engagement & strengthening the sense of community among AF members. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 40 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Civic+Engagement+and+Sense+of+Community+in+the+Military&amp;rft.au=Bowen%2C+Gary+L%3BMartin%2C+James+A%3BMancini%2C+Jay+A%3BNelson%2C+John+P&amp;rft.aulast=Bowen&amp;rft.aufirst=Gary&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 179 of 487

What's Wrong with Them Is What's Wrong with Us

Author: Lawson, Michael A1; Alameda-Lawson, Tania1 Communities Schools Sacramento, Inc, CA mlawson@cis-sacramento.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61473912?accountid=14667

Abstract: Boundary maintaining exercises & processes appear to represent a primary barrier to both community social work practice & complex change initiatives alike. This article proposes that the ways community social workers frame the need for systemic change, systemic transformation, & social justice can mirror practices & processes that perpetuate the common gap between vulnerable populations & institutions. This article offers a conceptual framework to develop social work practices that address multilevel & multisystemic boundary-maintaining processes & activities. Implications for the advanced generalist perspective are explored. 1 Table, 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=What%27s+Wrong+with+Them+Is+What%27s+Wrong+with+Us&amp;rft.au=Lawson%2C+Michael+A%3BAlameda-Lawson%2C+Tania&amp;rft.aulast=Lawson&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2001-01-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=77&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 183 of 487

Getting the Word Out: Evaluating the Effectiveness of a Pregnancy Prevention Campaign for Pre-Teens

Author: Fischer, Robert L11 Mandel School Applied Social Sciences, Case Western Reserve U, Cleveland, OH rlf11@po.cwru.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61448780?accountid=14667

Abstract: This report assesses the available evidence on a community-wide pregnancy prevention campaign for preteens. In Jan 1997, a five-year media & educational campaign to combat pregnancy among preteens was launched in metropolitan Atlanta, combining an educational campaign in the media market with the distribution of educational materials in public school systems & youth-serving community organizations in two urban counties. The non-experimental evaluation of the campaign draws on feedback from multiple perspectives -- teachers who requested the campaign materials, the general population of adults & parents, & youth in the metro area. In addition, preliminary data on birth rates are presented. 4 Tables, 36 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 184 of 487

Agency Based Community Building in Low Income Neighborhoods: A Praxis Framework

Author: Fabricant, Michael1; Fisher, Robert1 School Social Work, Hunter Coll, City U New York, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61500445?accountid=14667

Abstract: The decline of community is a significant strain in recent social science literature. The concept of social capital has been used to describe the weakened state of communal structure. The most intense expressions of such decline have been experienced in poor communities. Relatively little attention, however, has been paid to the difficult task of social capital formation or rebuilding community. This paper attempts to address that imbalance. It develops a very preliminary praxis framework for community building & locates such practice work within nonprofit social service agencies. The framework was constructed from the practice literature & represents a first step in developing a holistic approach to agency-based community building. Critically, the paper also underscores a number of the dilemmas associated with implementing such a framework. 1 Table, 29 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 185 of 487

Community Building in Hard Times: A Post-Welfare View from the Streets

Author: Mulroy, Elizabeth A1; Lauber, Helenann1 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore emulroy@ssw.umaryland.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61485215?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is about the development & implementation of community building in public housing as a poverty-reduction, homeless prevention strategy. The case offers a view from the streets of a public housing project where a family support program in a large child & family agency worked with very poor residents squeezed by dual policy reforms in welfare & in affordable housing. The practice innovation was a model of non-categorical programming with four interactive domains: community improvement, family strengthening, education/life skills, & worker development. The case describes & analyzes (1) how the conceptual framework derived from "theories of change" & principles of the family support movement; (2) how the process was facilitated by a community-based location advantage & a commitment to teamwork; & (3) how inconsistent funding streams & the complexity, size, & scope of the program hindered implementation & sustainability. Finally, lessons are drawn to use the best of community building in hard times. 1 Figure, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Building+in+Hard+Times%3A+A+Post-Welfare+View+from+the+Streets&amp;rft.au=Mulroy%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BLauber%2C+Helenann&amp;rft.aulast=Mulroy&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2002-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 186 of 487

Participatory Change: An Integrative Approach to Community Practice

Author: Castelloe, Paul1; Watson, Thomas; White, Craig1 Center Participatory Change, Asheville, NC paul@cpcwnc.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498440?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article outlines a community practice methodology developed at the Center for Participatory Change, a nonprofit organization in the Appalachian mountains of western NC. This methodology, which we call participatory change, signals confluence of three practice approaches that have rarely been integrated: community organizing, popular education, & international participatory development or Participatory Rural Appraisal. The article provides an overview of these three practice approaches & discusses their strengths & limitations. Participatory change as a community practice approach is presented along with an introduction to the core values, attitudes, & behaviors that guide the use of the methodology. 1 Table, 62 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

The Social Work Outreach Service within a School of Social Work: A New Model for Collaboration with the Community

Author: Cook, Dick1; Bond, Ann Farley; Jones, Peter; Greif, Geoffrey L1 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61430423?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes a unique community outreach service that is designed specifically to meet the needs of the local community, provide training ground for social work students, & experiment with the development of new practice models. Located within a school of social work, the service was born in an atmosphere in which both the university & the school were being called upon to play a greater part in the community. Since its inception in 1992, it has successfully served the local community through direct service, community organization activities, & consultation. Despite these successes in outreach to the community, internal challenges continue to exist. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 188 of 487

Evaluation of a Training Curriculum for Inter-Agency Collaboration

Author: Jones, Loring1; Packard, Thomas; Nahrstedt, Kristen1 School Social Work, Coll Health & Human Services, San Diego State U, CA ljones@mail.sdsu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61496430?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports the activities & outcomes of one university-based training project that provided a five-day training series on interagency collaboration for public child welfare workers & staff in the fields of substance abuse, mental health, & domestic violence, & summarizes lessons learned in the project. The overarching goal of this program was the development of a cadre of child welfare practitioners & community professionals who have the ability to respond effectively to complex family problems of child abuse & neglect resulting from substance abuse, mental illness, & domestic violence. A quasi-experimental design using pre- & post-measures was used to test the impact of interdisciplinary training. The evaluation shows gains in trainee knowledge, positive attitudes toward collaboration, & the trainees reported more collaboration in their own practice between the pre- & post-tests that was sustained in a follow-up. The implications of these findings for administrative & community practice are discussed. 3 Tables, 33 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Revisiting the Relationship between Social Work and Law Enforcement

Author: Slaght, Evelyn F11 School Social Work, George Mason U, Fairfax, VA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515699?accountid=14667

Abstract: Increasingly, law enforcement officers are becoming involved in community roles that require knowledge & sensitivity to social problems beyond their normal training. Social workers can be involved in the training, education, & resource development necessary to prevent incarceration & the escalation of mental health problems officers encounter, especially in the wake of recent terrorist events. Innovative team efforts in the community are elaborated as a product of the inclusion of social work courses in the Administration of Justice major, where officers are instructed in collaborative responses to community crises. 19 References. Document 190 of 487

An Action Guide for Nonprofit Board Diversity

Author: Daley, John Michael11 School Social Work, Coll Public Programs, Arizona State U, Tempe john.daley@asu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61530872?accountid=14667

Abstract: Involvement on nonprofit organization boards provides a powerful opportunity to engage emerging leaders of historically marginalized groups in community life. Yet, many nonprofit boards reflect limited social diversity & board leaders are surprisingly passive & unreflective about diversity issues. This article outlines a planned process that community practitioners, agency administrators, & board leaders can use to enhance board social diversity. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.
