Managing Out: The Community Practice Dimensions of Effective Agency Management

Author: Austin, Michael J11 School Social Welfare, U California, Berkeley

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61509155?accountid=14667

Abstract: With the advent of welfare reform & managed care, the nature of managerial practice has increasingly shifted from a primary focus on internal operations to a more external, community focus that involves actively monitoring & managing the boundary between the external environment & internal organizational arrangements. This article explores the boundary-spanning aspects of community practice, the related theories of interorganizational relations, & the process of "managing out" by those in top management & middle management positions in human service organizations. 2 Figures, 25 References. Document 192 of 487

An Approach to Community Outreach Practice in the 21st Century

Author: Hatchett, Bonnie1; Duran, Daniel A1 Social Work Program, U Texas, El Paso hatchett@utep.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61505191?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents the findings of a study about knowledge, attitudes, & beliefs about AIDS held by older Hispanic adults. Members of the convenience sample provided responses that identify concerns about effective practice in outreach & information provision to older adults with regard to risky sexual practices. Intervention to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS among older adults needs to be culturally competent & to be attuned to social practices, traditions, community concerns, & generational perspectives with regard to serious health problems related to sexual behavior. The sample composition was primarily Hispanic (97.4%), Catholic (92.1%), & female (84.2%) with a mean age of 73.7 years. Approximately 28.2% of those surveyed stated that they felt that AIDS was an important problem for older adults. The majority, (76.3%) were aware of locations where health information & services were available if AIDS were a problem. Even though the majority indicated knowledge that AIDS is spread through sexual intercourse, more than one third, (36.8%) thought that sexually active adults 55+ never use condoms. A discussion of the implications for disease prevention programs & community practice is presented emphasizing the importance of empowerment strategies in health promotion programs & the strengthening of multidisciplinary collaborative efforts to effect positive community health changes. 1 Table, 56 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Approach+to+Community+Outreach+Practice+in+the+21st+Century&amp;rft.au=Hatchett%2C+Bonnie%3BDuran%2C+Daniel+A&amp;rft.aulast=Hatchett&amp;rft.aufirst=Bonnie&amp;rft.date=2002-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 193 of 487

Tailoring Organizational Characteristics for Empowerment: Accommodating Individual Economic Resources

Author: Peterson, N Andrew1; Hughey, Joseph1 Dept Community & Behavioral Health, Coll Public Health, U Iowa, Iowa City

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61448784?accountid=14667

Abstract: Empowerment is an important value orientation & intervention approach in social work & other disciplines. Viewed from an ecological perspective, a good fit between organizational characteristics & the life circumstances of individuals should provide empowerment benefits. By studying interaction effects of material resources & organizational characteristics on empowerment, this research sought to extend understanding of empowerment dynamics in community organizations. Using hierarchical regression analyses to investigate socioeconomic status (SES) in a moderator model, findings of the study demonstrated that, among a diverse group of participants in two different faith-based community organizations, perceptions of organizational characteristics were more strongly related to empowerment for participants of lower SES. A substantive implication of the study is that community practitioners should attend to the fit between specific organizational processes & economic circumstances of community-based organization participants. Strategies weighted toward attention to relationships among members linked to availability of & participation in a variety of organizational roles may be more salient for empowerment of the disadvantaged. Our findings are consistent with an ecological orientation to empowerment, & they add further support to the importance of ecological specificity in empowerment theory. 2 Tables, 60 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Tailoring+Organizational+Characteristics+for+Empowerment%3A+Accommodating+Individual+Economic+Resources&amp;rft.au=Peterson%2C+N+Andrew%3BHughey%2C+Joseph&amp;rft.aulast=Peterson&amp;rft.aufirst=N&amp;rft.date=2002-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 194 of 487

Cross Cultural Field Assignments in an Undergraduate Community Practice Course: Integrating Multimedia Documentation

Author: Salcido, Ramon M1; Ornelas, Vincent; Lee, Nani1 U Southern California, Los Angeles

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544098?accountid=14667

Abstract: An undergraduate social work course was developed around intensive field studies in culturally diverse neighborhoods. The article describes the development of the course, format, & methods. Cross-cultural fieldwork assignments are presented with details of each learning task. These tasks include photo documentation & the development of community proposals. The authors provide both quantitative & qualitative data on students' assessment of the course & learning assignments. Implications for integrating the reported field study assignments into course curriculum are presented. Cross-cultural assignments using photo documentation can be a catalyst for developing cultural sensitivity, in-depth knowledge of neighborhood diversity & resources. 1 Table, 24 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Using a Stakeholder Participatory Model in a Community-Wide Service Needs Assessment of Elderly Residents: A Case Study

Author: Balaswamy, Shantha1; Dabelko, Holly I1 Coll Social Work, Ohio State U, Columbus

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61513407?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses a collaborative approach to a community-wide needs assessment in a county in OH. A neighborhood service provider for elderly residents in the community initiated the research project. To promote ownership in the evaluation process & to conserve resources, the evaluators used a stakeholder participatory approach. This effort not only resulted in increased cooperation among all parties involved (stakeholders, evaluators, community agencies), but culminated in the acceptance & utilization of controversial findings. 1 Chart, 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Document 197 of 487

Strengths and Pathological Perspectives in Community Social Work

Author: Itzhaky, Haya1; Bustin, Edna1 School Social Work, Bar-Ilan U, Ramat Gan, Israel

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61497800?accountid=14667

Abstract: Current social work theory distinguishes between the traditional pathology-oriented perspective & the strengths perspective. This paper posits that the working model of community social workers is grounded in a strengths perspective, which, in relation to community work, is compatible with & supplementary to empowerment models, providing a methodological base for the values & practice of the macro method of social work. The current study aimed to assess the prevalence of each of these two perspectives toward community activity, & to examine the differences between them regarding the sense of empowerment & professional skills acknowledged by community social workers in Israel. The findings revealed that while the majority of community social workers adopt a strengths perspective in their work, they experience a greater sense of empowerment & of professional skills when adopting a pathology-oriented perspective. 1 Table, 31 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 198 of 487

Institutionalizing Activism: The History of the Sherman Park Community Association

Author: Padgett, Deborah L11 Helen Bader School Social Welfare, U Wisconsin, Milwaukee dpadgett@uwm.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61541663?accountid=14667

Abstract: The story of the Sherman Park Community Assoc illustrates how concurrent commitments to ideology, community, & organizational viability pose challenges to a community-based organization. Information was gathered from public documents, archived records, & retrospective, audiotaped interviews to review the history of an organization's survival through twenty-five years of changing demographics & public policies. Institutionalization, professionalization, funding, & goals & strategies were identified as tensions that surfaced periodically throughout the history of the organization. Considerations for macro practice are presented. 39 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 199 of 487

Engaging Students in Community-Based Research: A Model for Teaching Social Work Research

Author: Anderson, Steven G11 School Social Work, U Illinois, Urbana sandersn@uiuc.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61536734?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper presents a model for teaching social work research courses that features collaboration between social service agencies & MSW students on community-based research projects. The model encourages student interest & skill development through experiential learning, empowerment in decision making, group interaction, & application of research principles & techniques. It also fosters community development & linkages between community agencies & universities by responding to agency research needs, & has the longer-term goal of contributing to the research skill base in communities. The processes for implementing the model are discussed, including the roles of instructors, students, & agency staff. Examples of completed research projects also are described. Student evaluations of the model are presented, as are the implications of the model for the development of community-based research. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 22 References. Document 200 of 487

Teaching Successful Community Practice in Social Work: An Integrative Approach

Author: Freund, Anat11 School Social Work, U Haifa, Mount Carmel, Israel afreund@research.haifa.ac.il

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61501343?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article identifies & addresses a severe problem in the management of community practice projects of students in their second & third year in the undergraduate social work program at the U of Haifa School of Social Work; namely, the current binary evaluation method based on total success or failure of the project. Using a systems approach, this study creates a framework by which to ensure effective & positive outcomes for community practice projects carried out by undergraduate social work students (Freund, Arkin & Saltman, 1999). This framework is unique in that it draws on knowledge gained from organizational & community theories, as well as instructional theories for teaching social work practice. The proposed framework includes three components that describe the factors necessary to help transform the student's learning experience: the organization's characteristics, the student's resources, & the evaluative measures. This inter-conceptual approach enhances the ability of the instructor, the student, & the organization to build an appropriate organizational foundation for students operating communal programs. The underlying assumption is that an integrative approach promotes a better understanding of the components essential for building & evaluating social plans conducted by social work students. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 59 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 201 of 487

Community Participation Reconsidered: Feminist Participatory Action Research with Hmong Women

Author: Yoshihama, Mieko1; Carr, E Summerson1 School Social Work, U Michigan, Ann Arbor miekoy@umich.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61475434?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes the process of planning, developing, & implementing a community-based project with Hmong women in a large midwestern city. Combining action & research to forge relationships, identify common goals, & garner resources, the Hmong Women's Project applied principles of both feminist & participatory action research (PAR). In light of the successes & challenges of this ongoing project, we critically evaluate the oft-encouraged goal of "maximum community participation" in PAR projects by questioning common definitions of "community" & "participation." We argue that the parameters of what constitutes a "community" & what counts for "participation" are inherently unstable, requiring constant negotiation of ideas, values, identities, & interests among all who participate in a PAR project. 38 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Participation+Reconsidered%3A+Feminist+Participatory+Action+Research+with+Hmong+Women&amp;rft.au=Yoshihama%2C+Mieko%3BCarr%2C+E+Summerson&amp;rft.aulast=Yoshihama&amp;rft.aufirst=Mieko&amp;rft.date=2002-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=85&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Linking Citizen Participation to Empowerment Practice: A Historical Overview

Author: Hardina, Donna11 Dept Social Work Education, California State U, Fresno donna_hardina@csufrenso.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61509846?accountid=14667

Abstract: The author examines the social work literature on citizen participation & empowerment in order to identify key concepts that can be used to define empowerment-oriented community practice. A historical overview of the emergence of citizen participation & empowerment in the practice literature is presented, along with an overview of similar innovations & concepts related to social service delivery: the use of informal help & the Independent Living Movement. This literature is used to develop a model of empowerment practice that focuses on the importance of participatory decision-making structures in community-based organizations. 1 Table, 1 Figure, 79 References. Document 204 of 487

Create a Crisis and Pray: A Narrative Interview with Richard Cloward

Author: Cloward, Richard

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61450834?accountid=14667

Abstract: This is the second of three narrative interviews conducted with Richard Cloward. This interview covers Cloward's work at Mobilization for Youth, his antipoverty efforts, relationship with welfare rights organizations & his work with Frances Fox Piven that culminated in the "motor voter" act. Cloward reflects on his essential ideas & seminal articles published with Piven in the 1960s that were developed in their major books, such as Regulating the Poor & Poor People's Movements. 19 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 208 of 487

Neighborhood Games as a Community-Building Strategy

Author: Berkowitz, Bill11 Dept Psychology, U Massachusetts, Lowell Bill_Berkowitz@uml.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61534771?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses the use of neighborhood games & contests as an alternative approach to community building, & as a complement to traditional issue or interest organizing. It places these activities within the broader contexts of celebration & festivity, noting the relative lack of such events within modern American secular culture. The planning, implementation, & results of two neighborhood-wide games & contests are then described, as carried out in a representative suburban neighborhood. Though full & accurate evaluation is challenging, the community-building promise of these activities is documented. The prospects for future development & use of similar community events are then considered. 16 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 209 of 487

Emerging Ethnic Agencies: Building Capacity to Build Community

Author: Holley, Lynn C11 School Social Work, Coll Public Programs, Arizona State U, Tempe holley@asu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560307?accountid=14667

Abstract: Ethnic agencies are important components of multicultural community systems, providing vehicles for community empowerment & self-determination in communities of color. Based on data from a qualitative study of emerging ethnic agencies, this paper explores the communities-building activities of ethnic agencies, describes the characteristics of ethnic agencies that position them to be effective in building communities, & describes what emerging agency leaders perceive they need in order to strengthen their organizations. Recommendations are offered for ways in which mainstream organizations can assist in building the capacities of emerging agencies so that they can become full partners in community-building efforts. 37 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 211 of 487

Majority-Based Neighborhood Organizing and Its Role in Contemporary Community Practice

Author: Grossman, Susan F1; Gumz, Edward J1 School Social Work, Loyola U Chicago, IL

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61508068?accountid=14667

Abstract: Neighborhood organizing has been an important aspect of community organization over the last 50 years. However, as individuals identify less with geographic communities & community-organizing efforts become simply issue-based, as opposed to locality issue-based, the viability of neighborhood-focused organizing efforts becomes more uncertain. This article describes one model of neighborhood organizing that uses a majority-based approach that is being implemented in Chicago, IL, & Milwaukee, WI. The philosophy & methodology of this approach are described, & examples of specific organizing efforts are included. The article concludes with an analysis of the strengths & weaknesses of this model. 18 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Majority-Based+Neighborhood+Organizing+and+Its+Role+in+Contemporary+Community+Practice&amp;rft.au=Grossman%2C+Susan+F%3BGumz%2C+Edward+J&amp;rft.aulast=Grossman&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=47&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n02_04

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Majority-Based+Neighborhood+Organizing+and+Its+Role+in+Contemporary+Community+Practice&amp;rft.au=Grossman%2C+Susan+F%3BGumz%2C+Edward+J&amp;rft.aulast=Grossman&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=47&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n02_04

Subject: *Neighborhoods; *Community Development; *Social Action; *Community Organizations; Chicago, Illinois; Wisconsin

Document 212 of 487

Community Readiness: A Promising Tool for Domestic Violence Prevention Programs in the Korean Community

Author: Han, Meekyung11 School Social Welfare, U California, Berkeley mkhan30@uclink.berkeley.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61502040?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores domestic violence in the Korean community & the importance of community readiness for a promising implementation of prevention programs. Community readiness is the extent to which a community is adequately prepared to implement a domestic violence program. A prevention program should address not only the scope of domestic violence itself but also the relevant cultural aspects of the population segments being targeted for the prevention efforts. In order to make a domestic violence prevention program work, practitioners have to acknowledge that the community must have the support & commitment of its members along with resources to implement an effective prevention effort. 1 Table, 38 References. Document 213 of 487

Neighborhood Reactions toward Facilities for Residential Care: A Swedish Survey Study

Author: Gerdner, Arne1; Borell, Klas1 Dept Social Work, Mid-Sweden U, Ostersund e-mail:arne.gerdner@mh.se

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61434164?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although a substantial body of research on community hostility toward the establishment of human services facilities now exists, researchers as well as community practitioners have identified a need for a more naturalistic & systematic approach to the issue. As a step in that direction, this paper focuses on a nationally representative sample of facilities for residential care in Sweden, with the objective of identifying patterns of hostile NIMBY (Not In My Back Yard) reactions & institutional as well as community predictive factors. Approximately 16% of these facilities studied experienced NIMBY reactions. In contradiction to many previous studies, which try to explain the neighborhood reactions in terms of attitudes toward special client groups, the findings of this study indicate that the characteristics of the facility itself & of the community in which it is placed seem to be the most significant factors. The study suggests that there is also significant community support for the facilities & that interaction with the community can provide the facilities with positive resources. 3 Tables, 19 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Neighborhood+Reactions+toward+Facilities+for+Residential+Care%3A+A+Swedish+Survey+Study&amp;rft.au=Gerdner%2C+Arne%3BBorell%2C+Klas&amp;rft.aulast=Gerdner&amp;rft.aufirst=Arne&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=59&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n04_04

Document 214 of 487

The Challenge of Two-Tiered Evaluation in Community Initiatives

Author: Chaskin, Robert J11 School Social Service Administration, Chapin Hall Center Children, U Chicago Robert@chmail.uchicago.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61515516?accountid=14667

Abstract: Evaluations of community initiatives have often been problematic, caught between performing a variety of different roles that are sometimes at odds with one another, struggling to speak to a range of different audiences simultaneously, & often falling short of providing either sound evidence of impact or sufficiently timely feedback. These challenges can be particularly complex in multisite initiatives, where the requirements for local learning & cross-site evaluation may differ. This article explores the attempt to address these challenges through a two-tiered evaluation design, by reviewing the experience of a ten-year, multi-site demonstration, the Neighborhood & Family Initiative (NFI). In doing so, it highlights the contextual, political, & organizational influences that shaped evaluation choices & activities, & draws some practical conclusions regarding how to promote evaluation that is both responsive to local needs & provides for broader knowledge building in the field. 1 Figure, 49 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Challenge+of+Two-Tiered+Evaluation+in+Community+Initiatives&amp;rft.au=Chaskin%2C+Robert+J&amp;rft.aulast=Chaskin&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=61&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 215 of 487

Organizational Change -- Too Much, Too Soon?

Author: Golensky, Martha1; Walker, Margaret1 School Social Work, Grand Valley State U, Grand Rapids, MI

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61508099?accountid=14667

Abstract: Recent changes in government policies & practices, especially managed care, have led many nonprofit organizations to embrace collaboration as a competitive strategy. This article presents a case study of a large human service agency that has adopted a management service organization (MSO) model, a type of collaboration particularly suited to handling third-party contracts, at the urging of the founding CEO. A new governance model was also adopted. Using chronology as an analytical approach, the case examines key decisions made by professional & lay leaders during four distinct stages of organizational development. The actions taken by the board of directors to restore financial stability & protect the organization's reputation after learning from the CEO of the existence of a significant deficit demonstrate the need for strategic planning & better communication among all relevant parties involved in a collaboration. 2 Figures, 23 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 216 of 487

Exploring Citizenship in Contemporary Community Work Practice

Author: George, Usha1; Lee, Bill; McGrath, Susan; Moffatt, Ken1 Faculty Social Work, U Toronto, Ontario u.george@utoronto.ca

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553322?accountid=14667

Abstract: The notion of citizenship as a triangular relationship between civil, political, & social rights has received a great deal of attention by social scientists. However, the exploration of the relevance of the notion for community practice is relatively new. Interviews with a nonrandom sample of community workers in southern Ontario explored the meaning of citizenship to the practitioners. The findings suggest that satisfaction of basic human rights is a prerequisite for exercising citizenship; therefore, social rights are seen as the basis for the ability to exercise civil & political rights. The participants of the study stated that all the elements of citizenship -- rights & responsibilities, inclusion & belonging -- are linked & evolve into a reciprocal relationship between the state & individuals. 51 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Citizenship+in+Contemporary+Community+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=George%2C+Usha%3BLee%2C+Bill%3BMcGrath%2C+Susan%3BMoffatt%2C+Ken&amp;rft.aulast=George&amp;rft.aufirst=Usha&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n03_05

Document 217 of 487

Class Action Lawsuits and Community Empowerment

Author: Banach, Mary1; Hamilton, Deborah; Perri, Penelope M1 Dept Social Work, School Health & Human Services, U New Hampshire, Durham mbanach@hopper.unh.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61541638?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the results of a qualitative study exploring community members' perceptions of the effects of a class action lawsuit challenging inequitable funding for adequate education initiated by a small city in NH. The extent to which the community was empowered as a result of the lawsuit & the effects on the community in general, were explored. Although respondents had mixed views about the effects of the lawsuit on the community, actions that the community had taken & responses within various groups indicate degrees of community empowerment. Respondents also articulated suggestions for use of class action lawsuits. An analysis of community members' perceptions in the aftermath of a class action lawsuit points to implications for social work practitioners involved in community work & legal actions on behalf of social justice. 41 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 218 of 487

A Pioneer's Perspective: Arthur Dunham on Community Organization Work in 1949

Author: Alvarez, Ann Rosegrant11 c/o Journal of Community Practice

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61451463?accountid=14667

Abstract: A biographical description of Dunham, especially of his work at the U of Michigan & his significance to the field of community organization, serves to introduce a paper by Dunham published in 1949. 1 Reference. Document 219 of 487

Icons of Conformity: The Marketing of Social Work Education

Author: Corvo, Kenneth1; Selmi, Patrick; Montemaro, Sarah M1 Coll Social Work, U South Carolina

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61530774?accountid=14667

Abstract: This exploratory study examines how graduate schools of social work market social work generally & macro social work specifically. Recruitment materials from 48 graduate schools of social work were examined for photo imagery & curricula descriptions. Authors conclude that graduate social work program marketing materials emphasize a one-dimensional image of social work as a profession defined by therapeutic activities. Implications for social work education are delineated along with a set of potential questions for future research. 5 Tables, 29 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 220 of 487

What Is the Job of the Community Organization Worker?

Author: Dunham, Arthur

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498873?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper, originally published in the Proceedings of the National Conference of Social Work, Selected Papers, Seventy-Fifth Anniversary Meeting in Atlantic City, NJ, Apr 17-23 1948, explores the job of the community organization worker, defining it as creating an interface between social welfare needs & social welfare resources in a given location or organization. Its responsibilities include fact-finding, public relations & interpretation, fund-raising, & social action. Six aspects of the job are discussed: (1) the functions of the community organization worker; (2) the types of jobs he or she may hold; (3) characteristics of the worker; (4) role of the community organization worker; (5) equipment of the community organization worker; & (6) professional development. The community organization worker, as a servant of democracy, performs an essential function in producing & conserving social values. L. A. Hoffman

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=What+Is+the+Job+of+the+Community+Organization+Worker%3F&amp;rft.au=Dunham%2C+Arthur&amp;rft.aulast=Dunham&amp;rft.aufirst=Arthur&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n02_07

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=What+Is+the+Job+of+the+Community+Organization+Worker%3F&amp;rft.au=Dunham%2C+Arthur&amp;rft.aulast=Dunham&amp;rft.aufirst=Arthur&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n02_07

Document 221 of 487

When Is Community Organization Social Work Practice?

Author: Pray, Kenneth L M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61497802?accountid=14667

Abstract: (Published in 1948 in the Proceedings of the National Conference of Social Work, Selected Papers, Seventy-Fourth Annual Meeting, San Francisco, California, Apr 13-19, 1947 [pp 194-204] New York: Columbia U Press.) Explores the nature of social work practice as a generic whole & attempts to determine where community organization fits within this schema. The kinds of problems with which social work practice deals are examined, & its basic methods & skills, specific objectives, & underlying philosophy are explicated. From this analysis, a working definition of generic social work practice is developed, & the relation of community organization practice to it is considered. K. Hyatt Stewart

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=When+Is+Community+Organization+Social+Work+Practice%3F&amp;rft.au=Pray%2C+Kenneth+L+M&amp;rft.aulast=Pray&amp;rft.aufirst=Kenneth+L&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n03_07

Document 222 of 487

Identifying Essential Techniques for Social Work Community Practice

Author: Pippard, James L1; Bjorklund, Robert W1 School Social Work & Human Services, Eastern Washington U

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61517154?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community practice techniques have been neglected by social work educators & authors, reflecting a lack of fit with real world practice needs. Community practice is defined as including community organizing, community development, & social planning. To sharpen the debate, the authors identify five techniques that are helpful, if not essential for community practice: (1) Force Field Analysis; (2) Program Evaluation Review Technique; (3) Nominal Group Technique; (4) Delphi; & (5) Q-Sort. It is anticipated that this proposal could spark a dialogue leading ultimately to a universally accepted set of community practice techniques in social work curricula. 22 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Books on Higher Education and Their Implications for Community Practice: A Reflective Essay

Author: Moxley, David P

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61519063?accountid=14667

Abstract: After exploring civic engagement as a critical function & "social responsibility" of the contemporary university, several books that describe the role of social work & community practice in higher education are reviewed. Particular attention is given to (1) D. J. Maurrasse, Beyond the Campus: How Colleges and Universities Form Partnerships with Their Comunities (New York: Routledge, 2001; & (2) W. M. McDonald & Associates, Creating Campus Community: In Search of Ernest Boyer's Legacy (San Francisco: Jossey-Bass, 2002). 7 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

Document 224 of 487

The Field of Community Organization: Report of Discussions within Section III of the National Conference of Social Work

Author: Lane, Robert P

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61548771?accountid=14667

Abstract: A report originally published in Proceedings of the National Conference of Social Work (Selected Papers, Sixty-Sixth Annual Conference, Buffalo, NY, June 18-24, 1939, pp 495-511) reviews the processes & objectives of the "field of community organizations" as determined by six discussions groups held in six different cities during 1938/39. There was no consensus on a formal definition of "community organization" but it was agreed that the term refers to the process of organizing a community, or parts of a community, that occurs within the area of social work. It was also agreed that the general aim of community organization is to induce & maintain an "effective adjustment between social-welfare resources & social-welfare needs." Secondary objectives, methods, composition, & personnel requirements of community organization are described & the appropriateness/inappropriateness of the name, "community organization," is discussed. Although it was concluded that the community-organization process is important & should be continued, it was recommended that certain aspects of the process should be critically evaluated. J. Lindroth

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Field+of+Community+Organization%3A+Report+of+Discussions+within+Section+III+of+the+National+Conference+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Lane%2C+Robert+P&amp;rft.aulast=Lane&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=105&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Field+of+Community+Organization%3A+Report+of+Discussions+within+Section+III+of+the+National+Conference+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Lane%2C+Robert+P&amp;rft.aulast=Lane&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=105&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Document 225 of 487

Action Research in Community Planning

Author: Carter, Genevieve W

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61434162?accountid=14667

Abstract: A reprint of an article originally published in Social Work Journal, 1952, January, pp 23-28.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Action+Research+in+Community+Planning&amp;rft.au=Carter%2C+Genevieve+W&amp;rft.aulast=Carter&amp;rft.aufirst=Genevieve&amp;rft.date=2003-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v11n04_08

Document 227 of 487

Community-Based Program Research: Context, Program Readiness, and Evaluation Usefulness

Author: Mancini, Jay A1; Marek, Lydia I; Byrne, Richard A W; Huebner, Angela J1 Virginia Polytechnic Instit & State U, Blacksburg mancini@vt.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61548348?accountid=14667

Abstract: At first glance, the worlds of program professionals & evaluators may seem quite separate. However, there are common issues whose resolution will enhance both program development & research on programs. Program professionals & evaluators have a great deal to learn from each other. As that learning occurs, both program delivery & evaluation research will benefit. Both are concerned about matters of validity, whether it pertains to the nature of the program intervention itself or to the nature of the assessment of the program intervention. To reinforce the development of program evaluation in partnership, this paper discusses key points about evaluation research relevant to both program professionals & researchers. These include the contextual influences on a program, the "readiness" of a program for evaluation, & whether the evaluation research "works" for the program. Underlying our discussion is a call for the development of partnerships around research on programs. In that light, this article elaborates the process steps that should be taken to build program evaluation partnerships, including a discussion of what evaluators & program professionals need to know about each other, & their respective values, interests, & professional perspectives. 27 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 228 of 487

Understanding Contemporary University-Community Connections: Context, Practice, and Challenges

Author: Fisher, Robert1; Fabricant, Michael; Simmons, Louise1 School Social Work, U Connecticut, West Hartford robert.fisher@uconn.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433566?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article contextualizes the contemporary phenomenon of university-community partnership initiatives. Because changes in the university must always be understood in context, recent efforts to build & strengthen relationships between institutions of higher education & communities must be situated in the broader social sites that produce them. To that end the article surveys the university-community intersect through an historical lens which emphasizes the relationship between the larger political-economy & civic engagement efforts. Subsequently, types of contemporary initiatives are broadly & selectively discussed. Lastly, challenges to both universities & communities embodied in the current initiatives are posed. 37 References. Adapted from the source document. Neighborhood and community organizing in Colonias: a case study in the development and use of promotoras

Author: Arizmendi, Lydia Gonzalez; Ortiz, Larry

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/58861993?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the role of promotores in neighborhood and community organization, focusing on basic principles and organizational background; based on a case study in the colonia of Las Lomas; US-Mexican border. Colonias: Spanish for neighborhoods, rural unincorporated subdivisions located along the US-Mexico border; these residential neighborhoods are found in Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, and California.

Document 230 of 487

University Civic Engagement with Community-Based Organizations: Dispersed or Coordinated Models?

Author: Mulroy, Elizabeth A11 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore emulroy@umaryland.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61514073?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article compares & contrasts two case studies of large research universities involved in civic engagement projects with urban nonprofit community-based organizations & neighborhood associations. The article uses a community building framework in which organizational, interorganizational, & community-level features are examined. The study found that each university used a different approach through which to achieve a university-community partnership. A dispersed model favored an entrepreneurial approach for individual faculty & student involvement, while the coordinated model requested faculty & students from different departments to work together toward a community-driven goal. The extent to which these different models of civic engagement delivered what community organizations wanted was based on five factors: (1) the university's geographic proximity to a target low-income neighborhood, (2) leadership for institutional social commitment, (3) use of community-based research, (4) funding as a social strategy, & (5) a flexible curriculum. Challenges faced by faculty, students, & practitioners are addressed, & directions for future research are suggested. 30 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=University+Civic+Engagement+with+Community-Based+Organizations%3A+Dispersed+or+Coordinated+Models%3F&amp;rft.au=Mulroy%2C+Elizabeth+A&amp;rft.aulast=Mulroy&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2004-01-01&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v12n03_03

Document 231 of 487

Home of Your Own Programs: Models of Creative Collaboration

Author: Quinn, Peggy11 School Social Work, U Texas, Arlington

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61528020?accountid=14667

Abstract: This description of Home of Your Own (HOYO) programs offers strategies for community collaboration that benefit people with disabilities. As more people with disabilities choose to live in the community rather than in institutions & as the population of the US ages, community practitioners need to understand their needs as well as the resources available to assist them. HOYO programs involve home buyers, financial institutions, realtors, & organizations such as Centers for Independent Living, in locating properties, training clients, & publicizing the program. Practitioners & instructors can utilize HOYO programs to illustrate the positive results of cooperation between federal, state, & local agencies. 8 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 232 of 487

Bridging the Fragmented Community: Revitalizing Settlement Houses in the Global Era

Author: Yan, Miu Chung11 School Social Work & Family Studies, U British Columbia, Vancouver miu.yan@ubc.ca

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61517848?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the global era, with the retrenchment of welfare states, people have to turn to their community, a major component of civil society, for support. In this paper, a fluid concept of community is proposed in response to the fragmentation & diversity caused by globalization in the local community. It is argued that to bridge different interests in the community, settlement houses, as a third sector organization in the community, is an effective community-building mechanism. This paper provides a brief history of the success of the settlement house in building solidarity & generating social capital in the local community. The author identifies implications for the role of the social work profession in revitalizing the settlement house as a community-building approach. 64 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Bridging+the+Fragmented+Community%3A+Revitalizing+Settlement+Houses+in+the+Global+Era&amp;rft.au=Yan%2C+Miu+Chung&amp;rft.aulast=Yan&amp;rft.aufirst=Miu&amp;rft.date=2004-01-01&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v12n01_05

Document 233 of 487

Connecting a University to a Distant Neighborhood: Three Stages of Learning and Adaptation

Author: Arbuckle, Margaret Bourdeaux1; DeHoog, Ruth Hoogland1 Center Youth/Family/Community Partnerships, U North Carolina, Greensboro

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507746?accountid=14667

Abstract: The willingness on the part of university participants to listen attentively to community representatives is of great importance to successful collaborations. This article presents three phases of a university-community partnership between the Macedonia neighborhood in High Point, North Carolina, & the Center for the Study of Social Issues (CSSI) at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. Although no professional network & neighborhood contacts were in place prior to this collaboration, the partnership addressed community needs by obtaining federal grant funding & by listening to the residents' concerns. Staff, students, & faculty overcame the challenges of inexperience & the difficulty of working with a neighborhood that was not located near the university. In various phases, the partnership moved away from a technical assistance approach to a self-help model. By actively engaging neighborhood residents through the Community Outreach Partnership Center (COPC), a learning & adaptation process occurred that resulted in successful university-community collaboration. 6 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 234 of 487

The Role of Evaluation in Developing Community-Based Interventions: A COPC Project

Author: Doe, Sondra SeungJa1; Lowery, Daniel1 Social Work Program, School Public & Environmental Affairs, Indiana U, Gary sdoe@lasierra.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61555981?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Community Outreach Partnership Center (COPC) program sponsored by the US Department of Housing & Urban Development (HUD) is designed to support the development of partnerships between universities & colleges & the communities in which they reside. This manuscript reports on the initial stages of the evaluation of a COPC initiative in an impoverished neighborhood surrounding Indiana University Northwest (IUN) in Gary, Indiana. Four distinct projects of the initiative are described, including education, neighborhood revitalization, community organizing, & economic development. The paper shows how logic models & baseline telephone surveys can be used to evaluate broad-scale capacity-building initiatives that are expected to evolve & change over time as a result of participation from community members.`. 1 Table, 2 Figures, 25 References. Document 235 of 487

A Collaborative Approach to Service, Learning, and Scholarship: A Community-Based Research Course

Author: Hyde, Cheryl A1; Meyer, Megan1 School Social Work, U Maryland, Baltimore chyde@ssw.umaryland.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61542487?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes a research course that was a collaborative endeavor between a school of social work & a community organization. This project was guided by learning, service & scholarship goals. Specifically, the participants in this course provided a pro-bono evaluation for a community benefits district. The benefits district solicited assistance from the authors, with the caveat that district members not be involved in the data collection & analysis. The authors situate this project on a continuum of traditional vs participatory research, & propose a "mixed" model for collaborative university-community efforts. The authors suggest ways of engaging students in "real world" research that benefits the community & facilitates their own training as macro social work practitioners. Factors that facilitate & hinder such a project are also discussed. 3 Tables, 1 Figure, 26 References. Adapted from the source document. Document 236 of 487

Seven Ways of Teaching and Learning: University-Community Partnerships at Baccalaureate Institutions

Author: Timmermans, Steven R1; Bouman, Jeffrey P1 c/o Bouman -- Service Learning Center, Calvin Coll, Grand Rapids, MI

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61529822?accountid=14667

Abstract: The vast majority of Community Outreach Partnership Center (COPC) grantees are institutions with both undergraduate & graduate programs. Consequently, baccalaureate institutions are underrepresented in university-community partnerships. Although the current emphasis on partnership & engagement arose out of an examination of the scholarly direction of higher education, this history should not preclude institutions with primary teaching-learning activities. Results from one baccalaureate institution show a range of activities appropriate for the involvement of undergraduate institutions in university-community partnerships. This article reviews recent thought & vision to demonstrate the potential advantages of partnership. Seven methods of engagement that can be used by baccalaureate institutions are described. Two important ways include service-learning courses & academically-based service-learning. This article provides examples of these approaches for helping baccalaureate educational institutions become engaged with their communities through their teaching missions. 14 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 238 of 487

University-Community Partnership Centers: An Important Link for Social Work Education

Author: Rogge, Mary E1; Rocha, Cynthia J1 Coll Social Work, U Tennessee, Knoxville mrogge@utk.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61514241?accountid=14667

Abstract: In academic settings, community research, & the service that goes along with it, is often not valued as much as other methods of research. The more qualitative & labor intensive nature of applied research often raises concerns about whether pre-tenured faculty can publish the sufficient quantity & quality of work necessary to achieve tenure. This paper describes successful collaborations through a university-based Community Partnership Center with members of community-based organizations in low-income inner-city neighborhoods, social work students, & faculty. Two case examples illustrate the co-authors' involvement with the Center as pre-tenured faculty. The article outlines the challenges & benefits of involvement with an established center for university-community partnerships. With careful planning & coordination, such centers can be excellent vehicles through which to achieve important mutual benefits for community-based organizations, student learning, & faculty responsibilities in research, teaching & service. 51 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 239 of 487

A Two-Level Community Intervention Model for Homeless Mothers with Mental Health or Substance Abuse Disorders

Author: Kim, Mimi M1; Calloway, Michael O; Selz-Campbell, Laurie1 U North Carolina, Chapel Hill

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557664?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes a two-tiered community intervention model in response to a call from the Center for Mental Health Services for the development of best-practice strategies for homeless mothers with mental health &/or substance use disorders & their children. This model incorporates best practice principles gained from previous research projects pitched at the system & client levels. The model has been conceptualized, presented, & funded by CMHS & is currently being implemented in a local community. This model is unique in that it develops an intervention that addresses both levels of service delivery (ie, system & client) in a single project. Blending systems integration/wraparound service philosophy & consumer-driven/ strength-based development approaches provides a model that encompasses interventions at the individual client level via supported case management, & improved coordination & collaboration at the service system level. While this model was developed for a specific community population, the approach is general in its applicability to other areas of practice. 25 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 240 of 487

Coalition-Based Social Change Initiatives: Conceptualization of a Model and Assessment of Its Generalizability

Author: Waysman, Mark1; Savaya, Riki1 Center Evaluation Human Services, Rishon Lezion, Israel markwaysman@013.net.il

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61548226?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper presents a model for establishing & maintaining social change coalitions. The model, based on the authors' study of a successful coalition-based social change initiative, highlights the potential contribution of a neutral, external support agency whose goal is to help a group of organizations collaborate in an effort to promote change in social policy in an area of shared concern. The external agency brings knowledge & experience in working with coalitions, needs to be trusted by all the coalition partners, & should be perceived as not competing for recognition or resources, & as having only the common goal in mind. The components of the model & the methodology employed to develop it are presented, followed by assessment of its generalizability to other settings. Experts, from different disciplines, countries, & ethnic backgrounds, advised that this model has great potential for solving social problems in many different areas. 1 Table, 3 Figures, 26 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Community Partnerships: An Innovative Model of Social Work Education and Practice

Author: Wertheimer, Mindy R1; Beck, Elizabeth L; Brooks, Fred; Wolk, James1 School Social Work, Georgia State U, Atlanta mwertheimer@gsu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61514204?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community challenges force human service agencies to collaborate in providing services. Such collaborations require practitioners to have skills not found in mainstream social work curricula. This paper explores how a new MSW program evolved through dialog with community leaders & resulted in a curriculum with a sole concentration of community partnerships. 2 Figures, 45 References. The Collaborative Research Education Partnership: Community, Faculty, and Student Partnerships in Practice Evaluation

Author: Berg-Weger, Marla1; Tebb, Susan S; Cook, Cynthia A. Loveland; Gallagher, Mary Beth; Flory, Barbara; Cruce, Ashley1 Saint Louis U, MO

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61514034?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses the founding & operation of the Emmett J. & Mary Martha Doerr Center for Social Justice Education & Research, an endowed nonprofit organization located within the School of Social Service at Saint Louis University. The nonprofit Center provides a creative mechanism for facilitating university-community agency research. The Research Education Partnership (REP) model creates a partnership among students, community agency personnel, & faculty in funded practice research & program evaluation. Four collaborations, their benefits & challenges, are described. Students are prepared to integrate research into practice. The Center promotes & supports faculty-community partnerships for social justice. 2 Tables, 37 References. Adapted from the source document. Document 243 of 487

The Past, Present, and Future of International Social Work

Author: Johnson, Alice K11 Jane Addams Coll Social Work, U Illinois, Chicago

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498103?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reviews the work of three scholars in international social work in terms of their contribution to understanding the past, present, & future of the field. Challenge and Change in Social Work Education: Toward a World View (2003) is a collection of Herman D. Stein's 1955-1984 writing that provides some perspective on the current status & future direction of international social work. Progress in the discipline since his observations is said to not reflect the kind of cooperative international research he envisioned. Lynne M. Healy's International Social Work: Professional Action in an Interdependent World (2001) assesses the current state of social work. Her definition of international social work & concept of "global interdependence" are discussed. Jim Ife's Human Rights and Social Work: Towards a Rights-based Practice (2001) advocates a human rights-based approach to social work, which is articulated here, with practice implications touched on. 8 References. J. Zendejas

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Past%2C+Present%2C+and+Future+of+International+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Johnson%2C+Alice+K&amp;rft.aulast=Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=Alice&amp;rft.date=2004-01-01&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=145&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v12n01_10

Document 244 of 487

Are Movements for Social and Economic Justice Growing? Reports on Protest and Social Action in the United States and Israel

Author: Mizrahi, Terry11 Hunter Coll, City U New York

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557633?accountid=14667

Abstract: Provides an overview of 2003 US & Israeli mobilization against their conservative governments. In the US, the poor protested for economic rights & immigrants mobilized for their rights by participating in the Immigrant Workers Freedom Ride. Israel saw action from single mothers instigated by Vikki Knafo's protest of government cutbacks. Lessons learned are outlined along with the impact of the "seven D's of Defense" on the Israeli grassroots movement. Implications for achieving social justice through mobilizations such as those in 2003 are touched on. J. Zendejas

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Are+Movements+for+Social+and+Economic+Justice+Growing%3F+Reports+on+Protest+and+Social+Action+in+the+United+States+and+Israel&amp;rft.au=Mizrahi%2C+Terry&amp;rft.aulast=Mizrahi&amp;rft.aufirst=Terry&amp;rft.date=2004-01-01&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=155&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v12n01_11

Document 245 of 487

A University-Community Partnership to Change Public Policy: Pre-Conditions and Processes

Author: Kaufman, Roni11 Social Work Dept, Ben-Gurion U, Beer-Sheva, Israel ronika@bgumail.bgu.ac.il

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61535007?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes a project aimed at promoting major change in government policy toward the growing problem of food insecurity in Israel. The project was initiated by Ben-Gurion University in collaboration with community service & social advocacy organizations. This joint action led to a dramatic change in government activity. The problem of food insecurity moved from a state of obfuscation to the establishment of a special ministerial committee mandated to develop policy guidelines for a national school lunch program. For higher education to contribute to the community, necessary preconditions must exist: Is the faculty committed to promotion of social change? Do the organizational & community environments legitimize university-sponsored activity for such purposes? Is the faculty competent to act effectively in the community & adopt strategies for political influence? Are there organizational mechanisms, action frameworks, & community contacts that enable collaboration for the purposes of social change? This case discussion uses the analytical framework developed by Taylor (1985) to evaluate the preconditions for action & the processes involved in facilitating university-community collaboration for promoting policy change. 1 Table, 40 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 246 of 487

Partnerships and Processes of Engagement: Working as Consultants in the US and UK

Author: Kearney, Jeremy1; Candy, Denys M1 Centre Social Research & Practice, U Sunderland, England jeremy.kearney@sunderland.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61493652?accountid=14667

Abstract: Government policy in both the United States (US) & United Kingdom (UK) has given increased importance to the concept & practice of partnership. Indeed, partnerships have become a key requirement of most community-based activities. This article explores the nature of partnerships & the need to see partnership as a process committed to engaging all participants. Some examples of partnerships with university-community links from both countries demonstrate the use of a range of consulting skills & creative techniques for facilitating effective collaborative action among community organizations & university partners. The article features the role of consultants in planning, developing, & implementing high engagement techniques in the development of community partnerships. 1 Figure, 45 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Community and University Participation in Disaster-Relief Recovery: An Example from Eastern North Carolina

Author: Farquhar, Stephanie1; Dobson, Noelle1 School Community Health, Portland State U, OR farquhar@pdx.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507712?accountid=14667

Abstract: Marginalized groups that are traditionally excluded from policy & decision-making are often also disproportionately affected by the hardships of natural disasters. By including community residents in research & planning, public health practitioners & researchers can create programs that have immediate relevance & policy implications. This article describes a case study of the formation of a community-university partnership & a community-based participatory research project conducted in the aftermath of Hurricane Floyd. The description of methods used & the implications for practice will highlight the importance of including those most affected by a natural disaster. Members of several groups worked collaboratively to define the social & public health concerns of a rural North Carolina community & to create changes in disaster-recovery policy & practice. 1 Table, 30 References. Document 248 of 487

Addressing Barriers to University-Community Collaboration: Organizing by Experts or Organizing the Experts?

Author: Cherry, Donna J1; Shefner, Jon1 Coll Social Work, U Tennessee, Knoxville dcherry@utk.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61555911?accountid=14667

Abstract: University-community partnerships, & COPC programs in particular, offer important opportunities for traditionally segregated groups to work together in collaborative relationships. The challenge of bringing people who possess distinct differences in background & social power together is a long-standing issue. Class, status, & organizational differences may impede collaboration. This article discusses the history of COPC as social policy & reviews an evaluation report of successful community-university partnerships. Drawing from the community organizing literature in sociology & social work, this article suggests community organizing methods that address structural obstacles to collaborative work. Especially in COPC programs characterized by multiple interactions, it is the community based organization (CBO) which has greatest facility to equalize the playing field between disparate groups. The role of community organizers in CBOs is to acknowledge & disrupt the structural inequalities inherent in these relationships. The community organizer must resist the role of expert or buffer between the community & university & instead strive toward authentic collaboration. 37 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Taking Stock

Author: Alvarez, Ann Rosegrant1; Moxley, David P; Gutierrez, Lorraine M; Butterfield, Alice K. Johnson1 U Hawai'i Manoa

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61380617?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the work of the current editorial staff & provides a brief description of the articles presented in the current issue.

Subject: *Social Work; *Journals; *Historical Development

Classification: 6111: social work theory/research

Title: Taking Stock

Correspondence author: Alvarez, Ann Rosegrant  

Publication title: Journal of Community Practice

Volume: 13

Issue: 4

Document 251 of 487

Community Organizing to Prevent Youth Drug Use and Violence: The D.A.R.E. Plus Project

Author: Bosma, Linda M1; Komro, Kelli A; Perry, Cheryl L; Veblen-Mortenson, Sara; Farbakhsh, Kian1 Division Epidemiology, School Public Health, U Minnesota, Minneapolis bosma@epi.umn.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61367045?accountid=14667

Abstract: Multiple studies have demonstrated that community organizing is an effective method to influence public health problems. Documenting & describing the community organizing process is critical for understanding & dissemination. The D.A.R.E. Plus Project is a multi-component, community-wide intervention to reduce drug use & violent behaviors among adolescents using classroom, family, & community organizing intervention strategies. This paper describes the community organizing methods & process results of eight adult & youth action teams formed using direct-action organizing, & offers recommendations for future projects. 3 Tables, 1 Figure, 10 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 252 of 487

Community-Centered Clinical Practice: Is the Integration of Micro and Macro Social Work Practice Possible?

Author: Austin, Michael J1; Coombs, Mary; Barr, Ben1 School Social Work, U California, Berkeley mjaustin@berkeley.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61380666?accountid=14667

Abstract: There has been a longstanding tension between the domains of micro & macro practice in social work practice & academic programs. A set of structural & interpersonal tensions can be identified as interfering with accurate perceptions of the underlying continuity of social work practice that is reflected in the mission of the profession. This analysis addresses this tension by defining the elements needed for the integration of micro & macro practice in the form of community-centered clinical practice. A set of cross-over skills are identified along with recommendations for improved agency operations & professional education related to the integration of micro & macro social work practice. References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 253 of 487

La Victoria: Claiming Memory, History, and Justice in a Santiago Poblacion

Author: Finn, Janet L11 Dept Social Work, U Montana, Missoula janet.finn@umontana.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61369839?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article utilizes the key themes of the just practice perspective (Finn & Jacobson, 2003ab) to examine a fifty-year history of community practice in La Victoria, a poor urban sector of Santiago, Chile. The author employs five key themes-meaning, power, context, history, & possibility-in exploring the challenges, contradictions & possibilities for community building under dictatorship & democracy. Lessons for critical community practice learned from La Victoria's history are addressed. References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 254 of 487

Social Work and Labor Unions: Historical and Contemporary Alliances

Author: Scanlon, Edward1; Harding, Scott1 School Social Welfare, U Kansas, Lawrence escanlon@ku.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61531514?accountid=14667

Abstract: While the profession of social work and the labor movement have moved in different directions since the post-WW2 era, recent events, such as the dominance of managed care and cuts in government financing, have led social workers to rediscover unions as potential political and workplace allies. This essay uses interviews, union documents and secondary data to document both historical and contemporary alliances between unions and social workers. Specifically, the cases of public sector workers organized through Service Employees International Union 535 and the affiliation of the Clinical Social Work Federation with the Office and Professional Employees International Union are examined and compared. Implications for community and workplace organizing are developed. 1 Table, 56 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580
