Document 255 of 487

Relationships between Assets and Perceived Economic Strain: Findings from an Anti-Poverty Policy Demonstration

Author: Shobe, Marcia A1; Boyd, A Suzanne1 Dept Social Work, U North Carolina Charlotte mshobe@email.uncc.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61394337?accountid=14667

Abstract: Income & wealth disparity continue to widen among U.S. households. Efforts to combat poverty generally consist of income based policies while wealth creation involves asset-based policies. Asset theory suggests that an asset-based approach to poverty reduction will help increase the personal, social, & economic well-being of low-income households. As a result, Individual Development Accounts (IDAs), or dedicated savings accounts, were designed to help propel low & moderate-income individuals out of poverty by building assets in the form of home ownership, small business development, & post-secondary education. One way in which IDAs are hypothesized to increase well-being is by improving household economic stability. This longitudinal study examined the relationships between asset building & perceived economic strain. Findings support the notion that IDAs are positively associated with perceptions of economic stability among households. In other words, it may be that assets help increase economic resources & well-being among low-income households. 5 Tables, 44 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Relationships+between+Assets+and+Perceived+Economic+Strain%3A+Findings+from+an+Anti-Poverty+Policy+Demonstration&amp;rft.au=Shobe%2C+Marcia+A%3BBoyd%2C+A+Suzanne&amp;rft.aulast=Shobe&amp;rft.aufirst=Marcia&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n02_03

Document 256 of 487

Interorganizational Collaboratives for Children of Prisoners: One That Succeeds, Another That Struggled

Author: Abram, Faye Y1; Mahaney, Heather A; Linhorst, Donald M; Toben, Jackie; Flowers, Marie1 School Social Service, Saint Louis U, MO abramfy@slu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61512376?accountid=14667

Abstract: Almost 1.5 million children in the United States have parents who are incarcerated in prisons. These children are at-risk for juvenile delinquency, failure in school, and residential instability. Efforts to locate and provide services to these children require cooperation from a range of social institutions that historically have not worked together. This article describes two collaboratives organized to identify and address the needs of these children. One collaborative has largely succeeded, while the other did not meet all of its goals. Drawing upon models of interorganizational and interdisciplinary collaboration, this article analyzes their successes and failures and offers lessons for interorganizational collaboratives. 2 Tables, 28 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 257 of 487

Developing Financial Management Training in Low-Income Communities: Assessing Needs and Community Practice Implications

Author: Anderson, Steven G1; Zhan, Min; Scott, Jeff1 School Social Work, U Illinois Urbana-Champaign

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61389052?accountid=14667

Abstract: As welfare policy contractions & declines in real wages have placed severe financial pressures on low-income families, programs to improve financial management practices & to help the poor accumulate assets have grown. This article examines the need for such programs & the implications associated with implementing two prominent training strategies -- one that focuses solely on financial management training & another that combines such training with savings incentives. Based on data from a large financial management training program, we find that knowledge deficits about basic financial issues are substantial, & that the type of financial training program offered has important implications with respect to the subgroups of low-income people likely to be served within a community. We discuss program issues critical to the implementation of such programs in low-income communities, with a focus upon more carefully attending to their participant empowerment & community development potential. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+Financial+Management+Training+in+Low-Income+Communities%3A+Assessing+Needs+and+Community+Practice+Implications&amp;rft.au=Anderson%2C+Steven+G%3BZhan%2C+Min%3BScott%2C+Jeff&amp;rft.aulast=Anderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Steven&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=31&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n04_03

Document 258 of 487

Leveraging Environmental, Social, and Economic Justice at Chattanooga Creek: A Case Study

Author: Rogge, Mary E1; Davis, Kimberly; Maddox, Deborah; Jackson, Milton1 Coll Social Work, U Tennessee, Knoxville mrogge@utk.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379858?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes neighborhood-based resilience & action among African American residents, to promote environmental cleanup & to reverse economic oppression, in a neighborhood bordering the most polluted waterway in the southeastern United States. This community-university partnered research explored how environmental contamination problems eventually served as a rallying cause for economic development & empowerment for the neighborhood. Based on review of neighborhood archives & newspaper articles, examination of reports from environmental regulatory authorities, & interviews with neighborhood residents & others, we identify environmental problems, barriers, & action on grievances that stem from environmental & economic conditions. A community collective action framework is used to depict the process by which community members have become increasingly sophisticated in leveraging local, state, & federal resources for environmental cleanup & neighborhood development. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 259 of 487

A Coordinated Response to Intimate Partner Violence: Lessons from an Exploratory Study

Author: Slaght, Evelyn1; Hamilton, Nina1 School Social Work, Illinois State U, Normal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61367652?accountid=14667

Abstract: A qualitative study of two Family Violence Coordinating Councils in Illinois confirmed the importance of collaboration between the law enforcement & treatment communities in responding to the needs of families enmeshed in domestic violence. A key finding of the study is that a joint philosophy of intervention is crucial to effective coordination. As key actors change, training is needed to reemphasize the special needs of batterers & victims, so that emphasis on prosecution does not preclude treatment. The judiciary, the State's Attorney's Office, probation, treatment programs, the medical community, the child welfare agency, & the clergy need to be invested in the coordinating process. Multimodal treatment services are needed, & must be supported by law enforcement. Data documenting the impact of intervention on intimate partner violence should be routinely collected to assess the effectiveness of a coordinated response in reducing recidivism. 20 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Coordinated+Response+to+Intimate+Partner+Violence%3A+Lessons+from+an+Exploratory+Study&amp;rft.au=Slaght%2C+Evelyn%3BHamilton%2C+Nina&amp;rft.aulast=Slaght&amp;rft.aufirst=Evelyn&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n02_04

Document 260 of 487

Organizing Self-Help Groups for Empowerment and Social Change: Findings and Insights from an Empirical Study in Hong Kong

Author: Mok, Bong-Ho11 Dept Social Work, Chinese U Hong Kong, Shatin abmok@cuhk.edu.hk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61505257?accountid=14667

Abstract: Empirical research has shown that self-help groups are not purely about individual change and intra-personal empowerment, but also about policy change and collective empowerment. In North America and Europe, such groups have been in the forefront of social change, and self-help represents a new political potential. However, findings of this study of self-help groups in Hong Kong indicate that social change has never been their common objective. In addition, members of the Hong Kong groups feel unable to impact social policies that affect their lives, despite wanting to do so. It is contended in this paper that this feeling of powerlessness among members might be related to the nature, size and length of existence of the self-help groups. It is further argued that self-help groups should form coalitions and seek professional assistance in order to effect social change and to strengthen and broaden their power base. 2 Tables, 57 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Organizing+Self-Help+Groups+for+Empowerment+and+Social+Change%3A+Findings+and+Insights+from+an+Empirical+Study+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Mok%2C+Bong-Ho&amp;rft.aulast=Mok&amp;rft.aufirst=Bong-Ho&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n01_04

Document 261 of 487

Selling Dreams and Buying Hope: The Challenge of Fraudulent Immigration Counseling Practices and the Consequences for Community-Based Organizing

Author: Hofman, Nila Ginger11 Dept Anthropology, Chicago, IL nhofman1@depaul.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378188?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses the deceptive practices of unqualified immigration counselors & the prospects for community-based organizing & peer education as a means of steering potential victims away from such practices. Although legislators have recently begun to pay attention to the potential for unqualified counselors to exploit the vulnerability of immigrants, non-citizens continue to fall prey to the inviting & perceived cultural legitimacy of their solicitation practices. Action research in the Chicago metropolitan area reveals the challenges faced by community-based organizations in providing a viable alternative to such practices. References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 262 of 487

United Way and University Partnerships in Community-Wide Human Services Planning and Plan Implementation: The Case of Lincoln/Lancaster County, Nebraska

Author: Tomkins, Alan1; Shank, Nancy; Tromanhauser, Darcy; Rupp, Sandy; Mahoney, Robin1 U Nebraska Public Policy Center, Lincoln atomkins@nebraska.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61387629?accountid=14667

Abstract: Given the similar interests of United Way organizations & universities in planning, implementation, & evaluation of human services, the two social institutions could be extensively & effectively partnering with one another. However, there is little documentation that such cooperative efforts are taking place. This article describes one such collaboration in Lincoln, Nebraska. The purpose of the article is to show the potential of such collaboration to improve community-wide coordination & outcomes by following the principles of a community-engagement model, to generate more effective use of evaluative tools that can assist in developing evidence-based practices in community planning, & to connect areas of study within the university to United Way efforts. References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 263 of 487

Citizens' Perceptions of the Neighborhood Council: The Case of Arab Neighborhoods in East Jerusalem

Author: Schmid, Hillel1; Salman, Hatem1 Paul Baerwald School Social Work & Social Welfare, Hebrew U Jerusalem, Mt. Scopus, Israel

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61371938?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper presents the findings of a study that explored an attempt to establish neighborhood councils in the Arab neighborhoods of Jerusalem. The Arab residents participating in the study recognized the importance of the neighborhood council, but expressed reservations about the extent to which the model is suited to a traditional society such as theirs. The obstacles encountered in the attempt to establish neighborhood councils derive from the residents' perception of themselves as being incapable of managing their lives autonomously. Moreover, the residents are resistant about having the neighborhood council model imposed on them by a foreign government, to which they have not given political legitimation. In this connection, it is particularly interesting to consider the responses & perceptions of Arab residents with higher education, who have expressed skepticism about the model & about the processes of participatory democracy that it represents. 1 Table, 18 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Citizens%27+Perceptions+of+the+Neighborhood+Council%3A+The+Case+of+Arab+Neighborhoods+in+East+Jerusalem&amp;rft.au=Schmid%2C+Hillel%3BSalman%2C+Hatem&amp;rft.aulast=Schmid&amp;rft.aufirst=Hillel&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=61&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n02_05

Affordable Financial Services and Credit for the Poor: The Foundation of Asset Building

Author: Birkenmaier, Julie1; Tyuse, Sabrina Watson1 School Social Service, Saint Louis U, MO

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61552443?accountid=14667

Abstract: The financial services and sources of credit available to poor families affect the rate at which families can be financially empowered through building assets. This paper provides background information on financial services, including credit sources, which are available for low-income people and communities. Also discussed are policies affecting financial markets and promising innovations in delivering affordable financial services to low-income families. Implications for social work education, practice and advocacy are discussed. 47 References. Adapted from the source document. NASW Chapters: Directors' Perceptions of Factors Which Impede and Encourage Active Member Participation

Author: Hartnett, Helen1; Harding, Scott; Scanlon, Edward1 School Social Welfare, U Kansas, Lawrence helenh@ku.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61383946?accountid=14667

Abstract: NASW state chapters provide a mechanism through which members can become involved in formal political & community advocacy practice. However, there is little understanding of the extent to which members are actively involved in policy & political practice & the factors that encourage or discourage participation. Through a mailed survey to state NASW chapter directors, this paper describes the extent to which members are involved in advocacy & the perceived factors which contribute to or impede participation. Document 266 of 487

Community Centers in Urban China: Context, Development, and Limitations

Author: Xu, Qingwen1; Gao, Jianguo; Yan, Miu Chung1 Graduate School Social Work, Boston Coll, Chestnut Hill, MA xuq@bc.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379912?accountid=14667

Abstract: While China's economic progress & social transformation demand an urgent refurbishment of its social welfare system, after a decade of development, community centers have gradually become the major infrastructure of service delivery in urban China. In this article, the authors examine the social & historical context of the development of community services in urban China & then focus on the community center as an emerging force in a society undergoing considerable change. A study of community centers in Jinan, a large city in eastern China, is reported, which reveals major difficulties that hinder the development of these centers as the principal hubs of community life. The authors outline the possible future directions of community service in China &, in particular, consider the role of community centers in the new social welfare sector of this nation. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 267 of 487

Promoting Client Participation by Social Workers: Contributing Factors

Author: Itzhaky, Haya1; Bustin, Edna1 School Social Work, Bar-Ilan U, Ramat-Gan, Israel

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61371986?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article presents a study that examined the contribution of empowerment (personal, political, & abilities) & background variables (age, religiosity, & marital status) of social workers to promoting participation among two groups of clients: long-term residents of Israel, & new immigrants. The findings revealed that only political empowerment contributed toward promoting client participation among both of the groups examined. As for the impact of background variables, the findings indicated that gender (for long-term residents) & religiosity (for immigrants) contributed to promoting client participation only when there was an interaction with political empowerment. Background variables & maturity (in terms of age & marital status) also contributed toward promoting participation among immigrant clients. The article discusses the nature of empowerment & analyzes the relationship between empowerment of social workers & promoting client participation. 1 Table, 44 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 268 of 487

Building Evaluation Capacity in Community-Based Organizations: Reflections of an Empowerment Evaluation Team

Author: Andrews, Arlene Bowers1; Motes, Patricia Stone; Floyd, Anita G; Flerx, Vicki Crocker; Lopez-De Fede, Ana1 Instit Families Society, U South Carolina, Columbia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61395882?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents the challenges & successes of a university-based empowerment evaluation team as they promoted community-based organizational (CBO) self-evaluation skills through a large community capacity building effort funded by a community foundation. Using a reflective inquiry approach, the team's approach to empowerment evaluation is discussed, & the how's, the why's, & the outcomes of the team's efforts are presented. Lessons learned emphasize the significance of training, role clarity, management of power relations, participant readiness, adequate resources, technology, coaching skill, & mutual support through a coaching network & interagency networks. Perhaps most significantly, clear & consistent communication between grantee & grantmaker, mediated by evaluation coaches, promoted evaluations that address internal & external stakeholder needs. The ideology of empowerment guided this project, & participatory research did prevail, but grantee self-direction was harder to enable. Likewise, consumer participation was woefully limited. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Building+Evaluation+Capacity+in+Community-Based+Organizations%3A+Reflections+of+an+Empowerment+Evaluation+Team&amp;rft.au=Andrews%2C+Arlene+Bowers%3BMotes%2C+Patricia+Stone%3BFloyd%2C+Anita+G%3BFlerx%2C+Vicki+Crocker%3BLopez-De+Fede%2C+Ana&amp;rft.aulast=Andrews&amp;rft.aufirst=Arlene&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=85&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n04_06

Document 269 of 487

A Context-Specific Community Practice Model of Women's Empowerment: Lessons Learned in Rural India

Author: Pardasani, Manoj11 Wurzweiler School Social Work, Yeshiva U, NY mpardasani@doe.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61531463?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article will demonstrate the need for a context-specific model of community practice that aims to empower impoverished rural women and simultaneously improve their living conditions. The two main empowerment-based models of community practice currently prevalent in rural India and their ideological differences are highlighted. A unique case of community planning and mobilization that resulted in incremental yet significant changes in the socioeconomic milieu of a rural Indian community and initiated a re-evaluation of traditional gender roles is illustrated. Recommendations for community practitioners and leaders working with women in under-developed and economically deprived communities are offered to facilitate successful program implementation. 37 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 270 of 487

Critical Variables for Infusing Community Content into a Clinical Program: An Empirical Study

Author: Ager, Richard11 Dept Social Work, Tulane U, New Orleans, LA ager@tulane.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61374796?accountid=14667

Abstract: This empirical study seeks to identify effective methods for infusing community material into a clinical social work program. It draws from Diffusion of Innovation Theory (Rogers, 1995b) & the Transtheoretical Model (Prochaska, DiClemente, & Norcross, 1992) to guide implementation. Based on qualitative & quantitative data from a variety of sources, the results identify variables critical in the change process & some preliminary outcomes of that change. Finding suggest that teaching community content can be enhanced through developing a pool of outside community guest speakers & field trips, addressing the varying faculty development needs of professors teaching macro & micro social work courses, & defining & redefining the concept of community during implementation & change processes. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 271 of 487

Teaching Community Organizing: A Dialogue about Creativity

Author: Wehbi, Samantha1; Ali, Shaun; Enros, Brynn1 School Social Work, McGill U, Montreal samanthawehbi@yahoo.ca

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61372677?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, our experiences as professor & students will form the basis of reflection on the use of innovative teaching methods in a community organizing course. Based on student evaluations & participant observation, we discuss the role of creativity in enhancing the learning experience in a case example of this one course. Findings indicate that reliance on innovative teaching methods provides students with the opportunity to exercise their creativity. In turn, this creativity has a potentially positive impact on community practice. 17 References. Adapted from the source document. Document 273 of 487

The Decision Case Method: Teaching and Training for Grassroots Community Organizing

Author: Gray, Karen A1; Wolfer, Terry A; Maas, Carl1 Coll Social Work, U South Carolina, Columbia karen.gray@sc.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61534701?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although seldom used for educating community organizers, the decision case method of teaching fits well with grassroots community organizing philosophy. The decision case method can help students and grassroots leaders learn how to critically analyze problems, develop successful solutions, and learn more about themselves and collaborative work. Instructors may use it as a strategy for teaching grassroots community organizing in the social work classroom. For prospective organizers, the decision case method represents a strategy for learning that they can use in professional practice. Community organizers may also use it for leadership development in local communities. Because there are few decision cases that combine direct practice and macro skills in grassroots community organizing, the authors wrote the case included in this article. In conclusion, they offer lessons learned from teaching the case, and recommend the decision case method as an appropriate method for teaching grassroots community organizing. 55 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Decision+Case+Method%3A+Teaching+and+Training+for+Grassroots+Community+Organizing&amp;rft.au=Gray%2C+Karen+A%3BWolfer%2C+Terry+A%3BMaas%2C+Carl&amp;rft.aulast=Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=105&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n01_07

Document 275 of 487

Learning through Partnering: Lessons for Organizational and Community Renewal

Author: Mai, Robert P1; Kramer, Thomas J; Luebbert, Christine A1 Center Organizational Learning & Renewal, Saint Louis U, MO

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61380051?accountid=14667

Abstract: Organizational partnerships offer a variety of benefits to participants. Besides being able to leverage resources & accomplish broad objectives, organizations can also learn about themselves through the experience of partnering. The article addresses how partnerships, especially those involving universities & community organizations, can best benefit from the learning potential in a partnership. Drawing from the 13 conference presentations of successful partnerships, we conclude that significant organizational learning can occur within these four frameworks: formulating shared objectives; managing personal relationships; creating structures & processes to support, rather than impede, collaboration; & reflecting on purpose & consulting data to assess outcomes. 9 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Learning+through+Partnering%3A+Lessons+for+Organizational+and+Community+Renewal&amp;rft.au=Mai%2C+Robert+P%3BKramer%2C+Thomas+J%3BLuebbert%2C+Christine+A&amp;rft.aulast=Mai&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=107&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n02_08

Document 278 of 487

Removing Barriers to the Use of Community Information Systems

Author: Hillier, Amy1; Wernecke, Mary L; McKelvey, Heather1 Cartographic Modeling Lab, Philadelphia, PA ahillier@ssw.upenn.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61512340?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community information systems (CINS) are emerging as important tools for community, government, and educational organizations. This paper considers the training, evaluation, and outreach efforts relating to the Philadelphia Neighborhood Information System (NIS), a collection of online applications that integrate and distribute housing and demographic data. It presents an overview of the types of NIS users and uses and some specific examples of how the NIS is being used for individual property inquiries, community surveys, needs assessments, and research. Finally, the paper discusses the barriers to more analytical uses and offers recommendations for social work education aimed at preparing social workers to support community organizations in their efforts to harness the potential of CINS for social change. 22 References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Removing+Barriers+to+the+Use+of+Community+Information+Systems&amp;rft.au=Hillier%2C+Amy%3BWernecke%2C+Mary+L%3BMcKelvey%2C+Heather&amp;rft.aulast=Hillier&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.date=2005-01-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v13n01_08

Document 282 of 487

Children as Citizens

Author: Golombek, Silvia Blitzer11 Youth Service America sgolombek@ysa.ort

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61377942?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article makes the case for a definition of citizenship that emphasizes the civic participation activities of young people rather than an age at which they receive formal recognition as citizens. It provides a conceptual framework & some of the arguments which favor a definition of this type, & draws upon examples from the youth service, service-learning, & youth in decision-making fields from the United States & other countries, which support the notion that children are not "citizens in the making" but instead social agents who already participate in building strong & democratic communities. References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Children+as+Citizens&amp;rft.au=Golombek%2C+Silvia+Blitzer&amp;rft.aulast=Golombek&amp;rft.aufirst=Silvia&amp;rft.date=2006-01-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=11&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n01_02

Document 283 of 487

Toward a Critical Social Theory of Youth Empowerment

Author: Jennings, Louise B1; Parra-Medina, Deborah M; Messias, DeAnne K. Hilfinger; McLoughlin, Kerry1 Dept Educational Psychology, U South Carolina, Columbia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61386657?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article contributes to the development of a critical social theory of youth empowerment which emphasizes collective efforts to create sociopolitical change. It draws upon analysis of four youth empowerment models, & upon findings from a participatory research study which identified key dimensions of critical youth empowerment: (1) a welcoming, safe environment, (2) meaningful participation & engagement, (3) equitable power-sharing between youth & adults, (4) engagement in critical reflection on interpersonal & sociopolitical processes, (5) participation in sociopolitical processes to effect change, & (6) integrated individual- & community-level empowerment. It concludes with discussion of the measurement of outcomes, & the challenges & opportunities for empowerment in youth organization. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 284 of 487

Sariling Gawa Youth Council as a Case Study of Youth Leadership Development in Hawai'i

Author: Luluquisen, Esminia M1; Trinidad, Alma M O; Ghosh, Dipankar1 Dept Community Health Education, San Francisco State U, CA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61388934?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes Sariling Gawa Youth Council as a case study of youth leadership development in Hawai'i. Since 1980, thousands of young people -- primarily Filipino youth -- have participated in Sariling Gawa activities which have developed their leadership skills. Many of them have continued to lead the organization & utilize what they learned with numerous local organizations & state agencies. The authors examine Sariling Gawa's growth, structure, & other factors that contribute to its longevity. The model includes (1) youth empowerment through building their leadership skills, (2) fostering & strengthening peer social support & social networks, (3) promotion of positive ethnic identity, & (4) community capacity building by involving youth in civic & community affairs. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 285 of 487

Youth as Engaged Citizens and Community Change advocates through the Lexington Youth Leadership Academy

Author: Otis, Melanie D11 Coll Social Work, U Kentucky, Lexington mdotis00@Uky.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61395639?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Lexington Youth Leadership Academy is a leadership development & community change program which has helped high school-aged youth develop into effective leaders in a diverse society. The author describes a multifaceted approach emphasizing education & dialogue about diversity, training in problem solving & leadership skills, adult & peer mentoring, & community collaborations. The program employs an empowerment approach that begins with youth leadership development skills training, & culminates in youth-driven community change projects that focus on social injustice & educational reform. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 286 of 487

The Hampton Experience as a New Model for Youth Civic Engagement

Author: Carlson, Cindy11 Hampton Coalition for Youth ccarlson@Hampton.gov

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61377992?accountid=14667

Abstract: A commitment to engaging young people in civic life & public decision-making in Hampton, Virginia has inspired a model for youth civic engagement. The article presents two ingredients for successfully engaging youth: creation of a system of multiple engagement opportunities, & systematic efforts to address adult attitudes that fail to recognize young people as resources to their communities. The author analyzes the lessons learned from working within a system of youth civic engagement, & presents preliminary findings of the benefits of engaging young people in the civic life of a city. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 287 of 487

Urban Youth Building Community: Social Change and Participatory Research in Schools, Homes, and Community-Based Organizations

Author: Nygreen, Kysa1; Kwon, Soo Ah; Sanchez, Patricia1 U California, Santa Cruz

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61358598?accountid=14667

Abstract: "Urban" youth -- a euphemism for underserved, poor, marginalized, ethnic minority youth -- can be active participants in community change. Countering the predominant image of these youth as disengaged or troubled, this article describes three projects that engage urban youth in community change through participatory research. The authors share their experiences as adult allies on these projects & examine four lessons learned, addressing: (1) the importance of positionality; (2) the role of adult allies in youth-led projects; (3) the creation of safe spaces; & (4) the building of trust & relationships. They conclude that urban youth can become a vital resource for community transformation. References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Urban+Youth+Building+Community%3A+Social+Change+and+Participatory+Research+in+Schools%2C+Homes%2C+and+Community-Based+Organizations&amp;rft.au=Nygreen%2C+Kysa%3BKwon%2C+Soo+Ah%3BSanchez%2C+Patricia&amp;rft.aulast=Nygreen&amp;rft.aufirst=Kysa&amp;rft.date=2006-01-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=107&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n01_07

Youth Action for Health through Youth-Led Research

Author: Suleiman, Ahna Ballonoff1; Soleimanpour, Samira; London, Jonathan1 Contra Costa County Health Services Dept, Martinez, CA asuleiman@hsd.ccounty.us

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61384102?accountid=14667

Abstract: Youth participation in social action can contribute to healthier, more just communities & more effective youth serving institutions. Reflecting on youth-led research projects conducted in seven school-based health centers, this article presents specific youth engagement strategies, the benefits of youth participation in health research, & the lessons learned for improving adolescent health & other outcomes. Document 289 of 487

Youth Participation in Photovoice as a Strategy for Community Change

Author: Wang, Caroline C11 School Public Health, U Michigan, Ann Arbor wangc@umich.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61384140?accountid=14667

Abstract: Photovoice is a participatory action research strategy which can contribute to youth mobilization for community change. The strategy can enable youth to (1) record & vivify their community's strengths & concerns; (2) promote critical dialogue & knowledge about community issues through group discussion of photographs; & (3) reach policy makers. Following a description of the photovoice methodology, this article briefly highlights ten projects in which youth used photovoice to represent, advocate, & enhance community health & well-being. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 290 of 487

Participatory Action Research with Youth in Bosnia and Herzegovina

Author: Maglajlic, Reima Ana1; Tiffany, Jennifer1 c/o Tiffany -- HIV/AIDS Education Project, Cornell U, Ithaca, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61395689?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sparked by a global UNICEF initiative, Bosnia & Herzegovina launched a participatory action research process in which 75 young people in three towns explored local understandings, needs, & actions about HIV/AIDS, drug use, human rights, & other issues. This article chronicles the research process, the action recommendations generated by young people, & the current status of the project. It reflects on the commitments & efforts which are required when large, adult-directed organizations decide to promote youth participation, & on the institutional changes necessary to support sustained youth participation that benefits ordinary youth rather than a selected few. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

The Growing Up in Cities Project: Global Perspectives on Children and Youth as Catalysts for Community Change

Author: Chawla, Louise1; Driskell, David1 Kentucky State U, Frankfort louise.chawla@kysu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61380036?accountid=14667

Abstract: The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child contains a set of "participation clauses" which are leading members of development agencies, municipal offices, &, community organizations to incorporate children & youth into community planning. The Growing Up in Cities project of UNESCO provides a model for doing this, with a focus on low-income areas of special concern for urban policy-makers. The authors describe a case study of this project in Bangalore, India, explore the complexities of implementation of youth participation, & discuss the lessons learned. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 292 of 487

Training Students as Facilitators in the Youth Empowerment Strategies (YES!) Project

Author: Wilson, Nance1; Minkler, Meredith; Dasho, Stefan; Carrillo, Roxanne; Wallerstein, Nina; Garcia, Diego1 Youth Empowerment Strategies, Public Health Instit, Berkeley, CA nwilson@phi.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61391630?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the training of students as facilitators for the Youth Empowerment Strategies (YES!) project designed to promote problem-solving, social action & civic participation among underserved elementary school youth in West Contra Costa County, California. This project involved 160 fifth grade students in after-school activities which identified their capacities & strengths in ways which aimed to decrease rates of alcohol, tobacco & other drug use & other risky behaviors. The article describes the recruitment & training of high school students & their graduate student counterparts as facilitators in this university-community partnership, & discusses the implications for other youth-focused community-based projects. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Collaborative Teams for Youth Engagement

Author: Scheve, Julie A1; Perkins, Daniel F; Mincemoyer, Claudia1 c/o Perkins -- Dept Agricultural & Extension Education, Pennsylvania State U, University Park

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61399829?accountid=14667

Abstract: Youth engagement on collaborative teams is a viable approach to healthier youth development & community development. This article examines four characteristics of engagement in the research literature & a specific school-community-university project: adult support, a youth-friendly environment, the completion of meaningful tasks, & the learning & utilization of new skills. Document 294 of 487

Youth Organizing, Identity-Support, and Youth Development Agencies as Avenues for Involvement

Author: Gambone, Michelle Alberti1; Yu, Hanh Cao; Lewis-Charp, Heather; Sipe, Cynthia L; Lacoe, Johanna1 Youth Development Strategies Inc, Philadelphia, PA mgambone@ydsi.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61380375?accountid=14667

Abstract: What are the differences in outcomes among youth organizing & other efforts to involve young people at the community level? This paper examines differences in developmental outcomes among youth organizing, identity-support, & traditional youth development agencies, with the finding that there are significant differences in outcomes such as civic activism & identity development. It reports that youth organizing agencies show higher levels of youth leadership, decision making, & community involvement in comparison with other agencies, & concludes that deliberate approaches to staffing & decision-making can influence youth outcomes. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 295 of 487

ARTICLES: Garbage and Democracy: The Chicago Community Organizing Campaign of the 1890s

Author: Knight, Louise W11 Independent scholar and Adjunct Professor, Northwestern University Communication Studies Department, Evanston, IL.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61410330?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the 1890s, before community development existed as a theory or profession, some citizens in Chicago organized for reform on a citywide scale. Their goals were to compel the municipal government to clean up its garbage problem and to strengthen democracy. Two new organizations-the first founded by women and the second, by women and men together-tackled the garbage issue, using strategies of self-help and of targeting the state sector. Some progress was made in the garbage problem, particularly once reformers started campaigning against corrupt aldermen, but working-class people were never drawn into the campaign after the first year. Middle-class women, however, were significantly empowered by the effort. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 296 of 487

In Search of Safe Campus Communities: A Campus Response to Violence Against Women

Author: Danis, Fran S11 Associate Professor, School of Social Work, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO, 65211 email: danisf@missouri.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61396470?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although there is a perception of college and university campuses as sanctuaries of learning, they are not always safe places for women. The studies by the Carnegie Foundation for Higher Education as well as other research on violence against women confirm sexual harassment and dating violence as significant barriers to women's educational achievement. Ernest Boyer, former President of the Carnegie Foundation, envisioned the college campus as a community of learners where civility is affirmed, diversity pursued, group obligations guide behavior, individuals are supported and service is encouraged, and traditions are celebrated and shared. This vision has strong parallels with efforts to develop coordinated campus responses to violence against women. Based on a case study of a strategic alliance within a university and between the university and community-based organization, this article highlights the achievements of this collaboration along with the role of a school of social work in facilitating this alliance. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 297 of 487

Organizing for Economic Empowerment of Battered Women: Women's Savings Accounts

Author: Sanders, Cynthia K1; Schnabel, Meg1 Assistant Professor, School of Social Work, Boise State University, Boise, ID

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61403342?accountid=14667

Abstract: When describing reasons for remaining with or returning to an abusive partner, many women mention economic dependence on their abuser. Few battered women, especially those who are poor, have the economic resources necessary to live independently. Additionally, battered women are commonly isolated from financial resources lacking ready access to cash, checking accounts, or charge accounts. Creating strategies that address financial well-being is essential to addressing the issue of domestic violence. This article discusses collaboration among domestic violence service providers in the St. Louis, Missouri region created to promote the economic development of low-income battered women. The collaboration has culminated in formalized economic service provisions including economic education and credit counseling; women's matched savings accounts; and economic advocacy and support services. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Organizing+for+Economic+Empowerment+of+Battered+Women%3A+Women%27s+Savings+Accounts&amp;rft.au=Sanders%2C+Cynthia+K%3BSchnabel%2C+Meg&amp;rft.aulast=Sanders&amp;rft.aufirst=Cynthia&amp;rft.date=2007-03-22&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=47&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n03_04

Document 298 of 487

Practice What You Preach? The Role of Rural NGOs in Women's Empowerment

Author: Handy, Femida1; Kassam, Meenaz1 Associate Professor, School of Social Policy & Practice, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61358141?accountid=14667

Abstract: If NGO employees are facilitating change for self-empowerment, such behavior must be modeled for successful transmission, as suggested in self-efficacy models of behavior change. Rural NGOs in India often depend on employees from the local population who are as likely to be marginalized as their clients. This may cause a gap between what the employees may be trained to 'preach' and what they 'practice,' thereby diminishing their effectiveness. We examine the employees of a successful rural NGO in India to establish if this gap exists. Using three empowerment instruments, we find that employees indeed 'walk the talk.'. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Practice+What+You+Preach%3F+The+Role+of+Rural+NGOs+in+Women%27s+Empowerment&amp;rft.au=Handy%2C+Femida%3BKassam%2C+Meenaz&amp;rft.aulast=Handy&amp;rft.aufirst=Femida&amp;rft.date=2007-03-22&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n03_05

Document 299 of 487

Perspectives from Women Organizers: Views on Gender, Race, Class, and Sexual Orientation

Author: Mizrahi, Terry1; Lombe, Margaret1 Professor, School of Social Work, Hunter College, New York, NY

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61394069?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper compares the perspectives of a diverse group of women in relation to their views about the impact of gender, race, class, and sexual orientation on their organizing and feminism. It uses data from a group of women organizers who first came together in 1989, and who were interviewed in 2002 as part of this follow-up study. The study found both commonalities and differences in comparing white women with women of color. While all the women identified as feminists and most used a feminist model of organizing, the women of color were more likely to express frustrations and divisions within the women's movement and it's organizing goals than were white women. They were less likely to embrace coalitions as a current strategy, and were engaged in or focused on the local versus global picture. Neither group of women addressed issues of sexual orientation in their work regardless of their background or affiliation. Using an intersectionality framework, the paper assesses the challenges the women face, especially women of color, as they attempt to negotiate the complexity of their identities and achieve important goals for women. Notwithstanding their differences, many of these organizers were working to bridge the divisions and envisioned a humanistic and equalitarian women's agenda. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Perspectives+from+Women+Organizers%3A+Views+on+Gender%2C+Race%2C+Class%2C+and+Sexual+Orientation&amp;rft.au=Mizrahi%2C+Terry%3BLombe%2C+Margaret&amp;rft.aulast=Mizrahi&amp;rft.aufirst=Terry&amp;rft.date=2007-03-22&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n03_06

Document 300 of 487

Re-Conceptualizing the Belmont Report: A Community-Based Participatory Research Perspective

Author: Shore, Nancy11 MPH, PhD, School of Social Work, University of New England, Portland, ME, 04103 email: nshore@une.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61399959?accountid=14667

Abstract: University-based researchers must seek Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval when their projects meet the human subjects regulations' definition of research. Regulations guiding IRBs are informed by the Belmont Report's (1979) ethical principles of respect for persons, beneficence, and justice. Debates exist about whether these principles apply to all research approaches. These debates prompted this study involving interviews with 10 community-based participatory researchers (CBPR). Interviewees identified ethical issues relevant to their research, interpreted the Belmont principles, and reflected upon the appropriateness of these principles. Constant Comparative Method guided data analysis. Differences exist between CBPR and the Belmont Report's conceptualizations of the ethical principles. The discussion includes suggestions to address these differences with the aim of strengthening the IRB process' relevance. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 301 of 487

Predictors of Neighborhood Satisfaction

Author: Grogan-Kaylor, Andrew1; Woolley, Michael; Mowbray, Carol; Reischl, Thomas M; Gilster, Megan; Karb, Rebecca; MacFarlane, Peter; Gant, Larry; Alaimo, Katherine1 Assistant Professor School of Social Work, University of Michigan School of Social Work., Ann Arbor, MI, 48109 email: agrogan@umich.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61416705?accountid=14667

Abstract: Insufficient attention has been devoted to an examination of the factors that predict the level of satisfaction that community residents have with the neighborhoods in which they live. In this paper, we describe a program of research to examine the predictors of neighborhood satisfaction. Data on neighborhoods and individuals in Flint, Michigan were obtained from the 2000 Census and a citywide survey of neighborhood residents. Multilevel models were used to predict the effect of individual and neighborhood-level characteristics. Findings suggested that many factors from the survey predicted residents' satisfaction from their neighborhoods. While neighborhood characteristics derived from the census were statistically related to levels of neighborhood satisfaction, census variables did not add information to a model of neighborhood satisfaction already containing survey variables. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 302 of 487

Faith-Based and Secular Social Service Agencies in Pittsburgh: Location, Mission, and Organizational Capacity

Author: Kearns, Kevin P11 Associate Professor and Director, Graduate School of Public and International Affairs, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, 15260 email: kkearns@gspia.pitt.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61405042?accountid=14667

Abstract: How are faith-based organizations (FBOs) and secular social service organizations distributed in relatively poor urban neighborhoods? How do FBOs compare with their secular counterparts in terms of services, resources, and organizational characteristics? What are the implications for community practice and capacity-building? This paper draws on a survey of 230 nonprofit organizations in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania to address these questions. The data suggest that FBOs are evenly distributed across communities of varying wealth, but in the poorest quartile communities, FBOs account for a disproportionately high share of essential social services. FBOs are comparable with secular organizations in terms of management infrastructure. The author offers suggestions for building the capacity of community-based social service organizations. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Faith-Based+and+Secular+Social+Service+Agencies+in+Pittsburgh%3A+Location%2C+Mission%2C+and+Organizational+Capacity&amp;rft.au=Kearns%2C+Kevin+P&amp;rft.aulast=Kearns&amp;rft.aufirst=Kevin&amp;rft.date=2007-05-22&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n04_04

Document 303 of 487

Youth Service: A Comprehensive Perspective

Author: McBride, Amanda Moore1; Pritzker, Suzanne; Daftary, Dolly; Tang, Fengyan1 Assistant Professor and Research Director, Center for Social Development, Washington University, St. Louis, MO, 63130 email: ammcbride@wustl.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61395518?accountid=14667

Abstract: When youth are involved in their communities, they typically do so through institutional structures. We construe youth service as a type of long-term, intensive volunteerism or civic service, which takes a range of institutional forms including service-learning, national service, and international service. We define these forms as having common operational features, and summarize what is known about them and their effects on youth and the individuals and communities with whom the youth are engaged. We identify directions for future research, including issues of server inclusion and impacts on the served. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Youth+Service%3A+A+Comprehensive+Perspective&amp;rft.au=McBride%2C+Amanda+Moore%3BPritzker%2C+Suzanne%3BDaftary%2C+Dolly%3BTang%2C+Fengyan&amp;rft.aulast=McBride&amp;rft.aufirst=Amanda&amp;rft.date=2007-05-22&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n04_05

Document 304 of 487

The Decision Case Method: Teaching and Training for Grassroots Community Organizing

Author: Gray, Karen A1; Wolfer, Terry A; Maas, Carl1 Assistant Professor, College of Social Work, University of South Carolina , Columbia, SC, 29208 email: karen.gray@sc.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61414816?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although seldom used for educating community organizers, the decision case method of teaching fits well with grassroots community organizing philosophy. The decision case method can help students and grassroots leaders learn how to critically analyze problems, develop successful solutions, and learn more about themselves and collaborative work. Instructors may use it as a strategy for teaching grassroots community organizing in the social work classroom. For prospective organizers, the decision case method represents a strategy for learning that they can use in professional practice. Community organizers may also use it for leadership development in local communities. Because there are few decision cases that combine direct practice and macro skills in grassroots community organizing, we wrote the case we discuss in this article. In conclusion, we offer lessons learned from teaching the case, and recommend the decision case method as an appropriate method for teaching grassroots community organizing. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Decision+Case+Method%3A+Teaching+and+Training+for+Grassroots+Community+Organizing&amp;rft.au=Gray%2C+Karen+A%3BWolfer%2C+Terry+A%3BMaas%2C+Carl&amp;rft.aulast=Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2007-05-22&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1300%2FJ125v14n04_06

Document 305 of 487

Youth-Adult Partnership in Community Organizing: A Case Study of the My Voice Counts! Campaign

Author: Share, Ryley Aran1; Stacks, Jonathan Shayne1 Assistant to the President and CEO, Youth Leadership Institute (2004 alum of Pomona College), Chicago, IL, 60604 email: jonathan@icah.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61412026?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper presents a case study of a campaign developed around sexuality education policy by a national youth-focused organization, Advocates for Youth, and its network of youth activists. The paper provides an overview of the national sexuality education debate and the specific strategies youth and adults use in partnership to advocate for a comprehensive approach to the education. The case study of the My Voice Counts! Campaign provides insight into the creation and evolution of a youth-adult partnership approach to community organizing, beginning with an online activism campaign and resulting in local youth-led projects to improve sex education policies and curricula. Following an analysis of the Campaign's accomplishments, the paper lays out recommendations for action and research to demonstrate the positive effects of this form of community practice. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

The Community Development for Healthy Children Initiative

Author: Ealey, Sarah1; Wituk, Scott A; Schultz, Jerry; Usher, Jeff; Meissen, Greg; Pearson, Rachel1 Research Associate and Project Facilitator, Wichita State University, Self-Help Network\, Wichita , KS, 67260-0201 email: sarah.ealey@wichita.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61420702?accountid=14667

Abstract: An increasing interest in positive youth development has led to the creation and expansion of programs and initiatives related to youth involvement and engagement. This article focuses on the Community Development for Healthy Children initiative, which envisions making Kansas the best state in the nation in which to raise a child. The initiative includes three primary strategies: A multi-media campaign; technical assistance and support to local communities; and mini-grant opportunities. The paper provides examples of activities from across the state that promote youth involvement. Outcomes across four areas are examined, and the benefits and challenges of this initiative are also discussed. Adapted from the source document. Document 307 of 487

Towards Interdisciplinary Community Collaboration and Development: Knowledge and Experience from Israel and the USA

Author: Korazim-Korosy, Yossi1; Mizrahi, Terry; Katz, Chana; Karmon, Amnon; Garcia, Martha Lucia; Smith, Marcia Bayne1 Chair/Head, Interdisciplinary Forum for Community Development/Policy-Planning Department, Ministry of Social Affairs, Mevasseret, 90805, Israel

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61412687?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article looks at the conceptualization and practice of interdisciplinary community collaboration and development (ICCD) in Israel and the US. It is based on the work of two interdisciplinary professional groups which were initiated by social workers-one in Israel and one in the US. This article presents a mapping of key issues and concepts, including distinguishing between mono-, multi-, and inter-, trans-disciplinary and inter-perspectives. The article addresses the issues of multiple professional identities, identification of a common core knowledge base and skills among disciplinary specializations for community development practice, and an understanding of inter-organizational perspectives. A qualitative methodology was used to conduct a content analysis of data from dialogues among professional practitioners in the Israeli and the US groups. Despite differences in the purpose, frequency and intensity of the two forums, there is an underlying belief in the importance of these discussions and in the commitment to interdisciplinary practice. Both groups believe that multiple types of expertise are needed, alongside new models of both inter-organizational and interdisciplinary relationships as well as professional-community interactions. Recommendations include the need for further examination of interdisciplinary community collaboration and development. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 308 of 487

The Contribution of Law and Social Work to Interdisciplinary Community Development and Peace Building in the Middle East

Author: Grodofsky, Merav Moshe11 Lecturer, Department of Social Work, Department of Public Policy and Administration, The Sapir College, Ashkelon, Israel meravmo@zahav.net.il

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61420238?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reducing inequity and strengthening civil society are both intrinsically related to peace building. This article outlines how social work and legal theory, coupled with an interdisciplinary practice framework, advance the development of community networks for the promotion of social rights as a medium for peace building in the Middle East. The combined effect of human rights advocacy, civic engagement, and the structuring and building of community, work to reduce inequality and promote civil society. Examples of interdisciplinary practice as implemented through the initiative of the McGill Middle East Program in Civil Society and Peace Building are presented. Finally, implications for interdisciplinary training for schools of social work are discussed. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 309 of 487

Adult Literacy Education and Community Development

Author: Subban, Jennifer E11 Assistant Professor, Urban Affairs and Public Administration, Wright State University, Dayton, OH, 45435 jennifer.subban@wright.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61408841?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article responds to the concern that low-literate community residents often are marginalized in community development processes. They are unable to give voice to their concerns, interests and their vision for their community. Perspectives and approaches in the fields of adult literacy education and community development are explored to determine how adult literacy education might be used to further the goals of community development. While there are parallels between these two disciplines, there are also barriers to overcome if an integrated approach to dealing with community issues is realized. This article reflects an interest in advancing a comprehensive approach to community development in communities with limited economic resources, low-level literacy and limited access. It seeks to address the issue of whether adult literacy education programs have a meaningful role to play in community development. The strengths of participatory approaches such as community-based literacy, and community development principles such as collective action, shared values, participation, social justice, political awareness and action, comprehensiveness, empowerment, and learning and reflection, facilitate an interdisciplinary approach. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 310 of 487

Reconceptualizing Community Organization in India: A Transdisciplinary Perspective

Author: Andharia, Janki11 Professor and Head, Department of Urban and Rural Community Development (URCD), Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, 400088, India andharia@tiss.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61428105?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article traces the history of community organization (CO) in the disciplinary and practice arena in India. Although CO within the academia grew with social work, the trajectory of CO practice reveals an increasing tension with the discipline of social work, especially the way it is structured and taught in India. The interface with the community development (CD) programme of the government, as also the growth of the voluntary sector and the influence of new social movements, compelled a review of the orientation of CD and CO. A sectoral thrust on livelihoods, health, education, housing, wages, land alienation, access to entitlements along with the pluralization of debates on caste, ethnicity, tribal and gender identities enriched CO in India. The article offers a perspective on CO based on practice and the critical engagements of faculty members in one of the premier institutes of India which offers social work programmes. Concerted efforts to respond to the changing social and political context with consistent pro-poor stances provided unique insights which are reshaping, refining and re-conceptualizing the perspective of CO in India. This is reflected in course work, the conscious recasting of fieldwork, the criteria of selecting sites of practice and agencies, and the policy work undertaken by faculty members. Could the new curriculum be termed as transdisciplinary or is CO emerging as a distinct discipline? This is a question posed for further debate. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580

Document 311 of 487

Transcending Boundaries: An International, Interdisciplinary Community Partnership to Address Domestic Violence

Author: Ritchie, Dennis J1; Eby, Kimberly K1 Elisabeth Shirley Enochs Endowed Chair in Child Welfare/Professor of Social Work, Department of Social Work, George Mason University, Fairfax, VA, 22030-4444

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61425942?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper presents a participatory research and planned change effort to develop a coordinated community response system to domestic violence in a United States culturally diverse community with a large immigrant population. This work grew out of an international, interdisciplinary project that was designed to establish ongoing collaborative relationships between university and community practitioners in the United States, Honduras, and Costa Rica around the theme of intra-familial violence, particularly gender-based violence against women. The paper analytically describes the international collaborative project, the local community-based participatory research and community development project, and lessons learned from both the local and international interdisciplinary collaboration. Examination of differences across disciplinary and cultural contexts generated critical reflection on the need to consider reframing domestic violence in the context of fundamental human rights, as is the case in Central America. At the same time, challenges around developing a coordinated community response, addressing inadequacies in the legal system, and implementing education and training were echoed across boundaries, demonstrating the need for continued international collaboration. Adapted from the source document. COPIES ARE AVAILABLE FROM: HAWORTH DOCUMENT DELIVERY CENTER, The Haworth Press, Inc., 10 Alice Street, Binghamton, NY 13904-1580
