Document 402 of 487

Globalization and Free Trade Agreements: A Profile of a Nicaraguan Factory Community

Author: Campbell, Wendy Sellers1; Lainez Hernandez, Idania Lisette; Ceremuga, Jessica; Farmer, Hallie1 Department of Social Work, Winthrop University, Rock Hill, South Carolina, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/853218215?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines a Nicaraguan community 3 years after the signing of the Dominican Republic-Central American Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA). Qualitative and quantitative methods were used to learn how families, living in a community constructed near a US-owned factory, maintained resilience under growing negative conditions. These conditions relate to family dislocation, loss of support systems, lack of childcare, safe water, and food security, in addition to labor injustices. Although maintaining relatively high scores on a baseline resilience test, these families and others like them in Central America, demonstrate a struggle for survival in a globalized context. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Globalization+and+Free+Trade+Agreements%3A+A+Profile+of+a+Nicaraguan+Factory+Community&amp;rft.au=Campbell%2C+Wendy+Sellers%3BLainez+Hernandez%2C+Idania+Lisette%3BCeremuga%2C+Jessica%3BFarmer%2C+Hallie&amp;rft.aulast=Campbell&amp;rft.aufirst=Wendy&amp;rft.date=2010-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=440&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2010.519223

Document 403 of 487

Review and Analysis of the Benefits, Purposes, and Motivations Associated with Community Gardening in the United States

Author: Draper, Carrie1; Freedman, Darcy1 South Carolina Fair Share, Columbia, South Carolina, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/853217092?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community gardens have been a part of modern American culture since the late 19th century. Participation in community gardening has ebbed and flowed in response to changing socioeconomic conditions, and thus the current economic recession has reheightened public interest. In a review of the scholarly literature from 1999 to 2010, rigorous quantitative research studies on the effects of community gardens are found to be sparse; however, a larger body of qualitative data is available. Eleven themes related to the purposes, benefits of, and motivations for participating in community gardens are identified. Community gardens can serve as an effective tool for community-based practitioners in carrying out their roles within the arenas of organizing, development, and change. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Review+and+Analysis+of+the+Benefits%2C+Purposes%2C+and+Motivations+Associated+with+Community+Gardening+in+the+United+States&amp;rft.au=Draper%2C+Carrie%3BFreedman%2C+Darcy&amp;rft.aulast=Draper&amp;rft.aufirst=Carrie&amp;rft.date=2010-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=458&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2010.519682

Document 404 of 487

Using Social Network Analysis to Enhance Nonprofit Organizational Research Capacity: A Case Study

Author: Johnson, Jennifer A1; Honnold, Julie A; Stevens, F Paul1 L. Douglas Wilder School of Government and Public Affairs, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Virginia, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/853216848?accountid=14667

Abstract: As donor agencies become more specific in funding requirements, research that can demonstrate the collaborative efforts of a nonprofit agency with its organizational neighbors and how those efforts pay off in terms of capacity and provision of services is highly useful. Recognizing these benefits, a local funding agency in Virginia commissioned a study to look at the ways in which social network analysis (SNA) can enhance the data resources available to nonprofits for funding and grant requests. In this article, we present a case study of a network of 52 nonprofit organizations to illustrate the viability of SNA in terms of funding and research needs specific to nonprofit organizations. We discuss the outcomes of the case study in terms of how the visual and metric outputs of SNA can be used by nonprofits to enhance the accomplishment of their organizational missions and strengthen their grant requests. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Social+Network+Analysis+to+Enhance+Nonprofit+Organizational+Research+Capacity%3A+A+Case+Study&amp;rft.au=Johnson%2C+Jennifer+A%3BHonnold%2C+Julie+A%3BStevens%2C+F+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=Jennifer&amp;rft.date=2010-10-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=493&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2010.519683

Document 405 of 487

Sustaining and Strengthening a Macro Identity: The Association of Macro Practice Social Work

Author: Hill, Katharine M1; Ferguson, Sarah M; Erickson, Christina1 School of Social Work, St. Catherine University/University of St. Thomas, St. Paul, Minnesota, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/853217463?accountid=14667

Abstract: Macro practice focuses on community-level interventions, such as management, organizing, research, and policy advocacy. Despite social work's deep roots in this type of work, macro practice and macro practitioners often practice without support or connections with other macro practitioners, and are underrepresented in the profession. In 2006, a group of social workers, including academics and practitioners, formed the Association of Macro Practice Social Work (AMPSW). AMPSW works to strengthen the professional identity of macro practitioners, elevate the status of macro social workers, and address common concerns within the social work profession. Adapted from the source document.

If They Build It, They Will Come -- or Letting the People Decide: Lessons in Building Community Participation, Partnership, and Public Trust for Social and Economic Justice

Author: Soska, Tracy M

Document 408 of 487

Finding Place in Community Change Initiatives: Using GIS to Uncover Resident Perceptions of their Neighborhoods

Author: Coulton, Claudia1; Chan, Tsui; Mikelbank, Kristen1 Mandel School of Applied Social Sciences, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/870998714?accountid=14667

Abstract: The growing recognition that place matters has led to numerous foundation- and government-sponsored initiatives that attempt to simultaneously strengthen neighborhoods and address the needs of families that live there. Despite the centrality of the concept of neighborhood, these place-based initiatives have few tools to understand how residents identify with the space within their target areas. This article demonstrates how resident-drawn maps gathered in a household survey can be used to uncover individual and collective neighborhood definitions. Using data gathered as part of the Annie E. Casey Foundation's Making Connections program in 10 cities, the study finds that there is considerable variation among residents in how they define their neighborhoods, but that there are also commonly held neighborhood identities that need to be taken into account in community practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Finding+Place+in+Community+Change+Initiatives%3A+Using+GIS+to+Uncover+Resident+Perceptions+of+their+Neighborhoods&amp;rft.au=Coulton%2C+Claudia%3BChan%2C+Tsui%3BMikelbank%2C+Kristen&amp;rft.aulast=Coulton&amp;rft.aufirst=Claudia&amp;rft.date=2011-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=10&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.550258

Document 409 of 487

Community-Based Research and Participatory Change: A Strategic, Multi-Method Community Impact Assessment

Author: Cordova, Teresa L11 School of Architecture and Planning, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/870433599?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a community impact assessment that was triggered by a proposed land development project that had the potential to dramatically change the social fabric and quality of life in a neighborhood whose history dated back several generations. Developers of the project never asked, "How would this project impact the surrounding neighborhood?" Community planning faculty and student researchers embarked on a 5-month effort to answer this question. This case study presents this research and points to the usefulness of community impact assessments for neighborhoods that are faced with development where the future of their community is at stake. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community-Based+Research+and+Participatory+Change%3A+A+Strategic%2C+Multi-Method+Community+Impact+Assessment&amp;rft.au=Cordova%2C+Teresa+L&amp;rft.aulast=Cordova&amp;rft.aufirst=Teresa&amp;rft.date=2011-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=29&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.550259

Document 410 of 487

Cooperatives and Community Development: A Perspective on the Use of Cooperatives in Development

Author: Majee, Wilson1; Hoyt, Ann1 Community Development, University of Missouri Extension, Princeton, Missouri, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/870433606?accountid=14667

Abstract: Community developers have long understood the importance of local participation in the events and processes that shape communities. Effective, democratic, and people-and-place-centered development strategies have the potential to achieve such participation. This article suggests that cooperatives can be an effective participatory strategy to bootstrap low-income people into the socio-economic mainstream. Woolcock and Narayan's (2000) social capital and poverty transition model is adapted to demonstrate the development potential of cooperative businesses. We hope to stimulate discussion among community development scholars and practitioners, policymakers, and the public on the potential of cooperative business as a community development strategy, particularly in resource limited communities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Cooperatives+and+Community+Development%3A+A+Perspective+on+the+Use+of+Cooperatives+in+Development&amp;rft.au=Majee%2C+Wilson%3BHoyt%2C+Ann&amp;rft.aulast=Majee&amp;rft.aufirst=Wilson&amp;rft.date=2011-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=48&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.550260

Document 411 of 487

Food Security: An Ecological-Social Analysis to Promote Social Development

Author: Kaiser, Michelle L11 School of Social Work, University of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/867747292?accountid=14667

Abstract: Coupled with the obesity epidemic, food insecurity presents a public health and social crisis. The United States' industrialized food system embodies an unsustainable network of production and unequal distribution of food creating threats to both the natural environment and human development. Ecological, economic, and social systems are interdependent and their relationships to food security are complex and dynamic. Social workers have a unique set of community practice knowledge and skills that can help communities achieve greater access to affordable, healthy food. Building interdisciplinary networks to change food policies and develop sustainable and equitable food systems can address food insecurity.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Assamodule&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Food+Security%3A+An+Ecological-Social+Analysis+to+Promote+Social+Development&amp;rft.au=Kaiser%2C+Michelle+L&amp;rft.aulast=Kaiser&amp;rft.aufirst=Michelle&amp;rft.date=2011-01-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=62&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.550261

Document 412 of 487

Introducing Asset-Based Models of Social Justice into Service Learning: A Social Work Approach

Author: Donaldson, Linda Plitt1; Daughtery, Laura1 National Catholic School of Social Service, Catholic University of America, Washington, District of Columbia, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/870997518?accountid=14667

Abstract: Increased attention is being given to university-community partnerships. Among such partnerships is service learning, a pedagogical model that integrates experiential community service activities and academic learning. Traditional service learning models often diverge from social work methods that embrace strengths, empowerment, antioppressive principles, and citizen-driven approaches. This article presents the integration of a progressive service learning model into a graduate-level social work macro practice course. The model gives explicit attention to respecting the dignity and worth of the individual by sharing power and developing collaborative relationships between students and community residents where both are serving and learning together. Adapted from the source document.

Document 414 of 487

Under the Cover of Books

Author: Butterfield, Alice K

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902080728?accountid=14667

Abstract: Several years ago, just after the fall of the totalitarian government of Romania in 1989, I had the opportunity to travel to Romania. The communist regime of Nicolai Ceausescu had banned books from Western countries for 30 years. Social work education was about to start in the country, but with no books to support it. In discussing this situation, I will never forget what one woman said to me: "A few books in our specialty is more than we could dream." That statement is still true in the South, a term used to describe developing countries. Books take a back seat to articles published in peer-reviewed journals in the North, a term that refers to developed countries. Tenure in social work and related disciplines largely stands on the number and quality of published articles. The assumption is that peer review guarantees that scholarship published in journals meets some standard of excellence in research methods, and that work contributes to the larger body of knowledge residing in the literature. The absence of peer review relegates books to second-class citizen status in the development of knowledge. Preferably, after obtaining tenure, one goes on to write a book. However, in disciplines such as the humanities and languages, standards are different. The contribution of a major book often serves as the evidence of excellence in scholarship, giving weight for promotion and tenure in academia. My purpose here is not to dismiss completely the value of peer review, but to point out that perhaps more is made of the process than it merits. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Under+the+Cover+of+Books&amp;rft.au=Butterfield%2C+Alice+K&amp;rft.aulast=Butterfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Alice&amp;rft.date=2011-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.571083

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Under+the+Cover+of+Books&amp;rft.au=Butterfield%2C+Alice+K&amp;rft.aulast=Butterfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Alice&amp;rft.date=2011-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.571083

Subject: *Peer Review; *Knowledge; *Journals; *Social Work Education; *Values; *Books; *Developing Countries; *Tenure

Classification: 6113: social work education

Document 415 of 487

Capacity Building Contributions of Short-Term International Volunteers

Author: Lough, Benjamin J1; McBride, Amanda Moore; Sherraden, Margaret S; O'Hara, Kathleen1 School of Social Work, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, Illinois, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902080744?accountid=14667

Abstract: Previous research suggests that international volunteer service may have both positive and negative effects on host organizations. Applying a capacity-building perspective, this study uses semistructured interviews to ask staff in hosting organizations to identify the main outcomes of short-term volunteer service. These views were compared with perspectives of staff from matched organizations that do not host international volunteers. Findings suggest that international volunteers may increase organizational capacity by supplying extra hands, providing technical and professional skills, contributing tangible resources, and enhancing intercultural understanding. Volunteers may also challenge organizations as they absorb staff time and resources. Staff members from both types of organizations identify individual and institutional variables that may affect the quality of these outcomes, including volunteers' language capacity and the intensity of the service placement. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Capacity+Building+Contributions+of+Short-Term+International+Volunteers&amp;rft.au=Lough%2C+Benjamin+J%3BMcBride%2C+Amanda+Moore%3BSherraden%2C+Margaret+S%3BO%27Hara%2C+Kathleen&amp;rft.aulast=Lough&amp;rft.aufirst=Benjamin&amp;rft.date=2011-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=120&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.568921

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Capacity+Building+Contributions+of+Short-Term+International+Volunteers&amp;rft.au=Lough%2C+Benjamin+J%3BMcBride%2C+Amanda+Moore%3BSherraden%2C+Margaret+S%3BO%27Hara%2C+Kathleen&amp;rft.aulast=Lough&amp;rft.aufirst=Benjamin&amp;rft.date=2011-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=120&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.568921

Document 416 of 487

What Money Cannot Buy: The Distinctive and Multidimensional Impact of Volunteers

Author: Haski-Leventhal, Debbie1; Hustinx, Lesley; Handy, Femida1 Centre for Social Impact, Australia School of Business, Kensington, Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902080756?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although it is assumed that volunteers make an extremely important contribution to organizations and the community, studies that examine their direct impact are scarce. Using quantitative and qualitative data collected from clients, volunteers and staff at the Philadelphia Ronald McDonald House, examined is the impact of volunteers on the organization, the clients and on themselves. Volunteers had a high direct and indirect impact on recipients, including on their attitudes toward volunteering and their future behavior. Volunteers gained intrinsic and extrinsic benefits and, as expected, their participation had a positive impact on the organization. The study contributes to the body of knowledge on social impact and volunteering. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=What+Money+Cannot+Buy%3A+The+Distinctive+and+Multidimensional+Impact+of+Volunteers&amp;rft.au=Haski-Leventhal%2C+Debbie%3BHustinx%2C+Lesley%3BHandy%2C+Femida&amp;rft.aulast=Haski-Leventhal&amp;rft.aufirst=Debbie&amp;rft.date=2011-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=138&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.568930

Document 417 of 487

Developing a Strategy to Meaningfully Engage Stakeholders in Program/Policy Planning: A Guide for Human Services Managers and Practitioners

Author: Woodford, Michael R1; Preston, Susan1 School of Social Work, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902080768?accountid=14667

Abstract: Stakeholder participation can be a valuable component of program/policy development in the human services. However, service users and other stakeholders often experience it as tokenistic and having little effect. Although management literature recommends stakeholder participation and social work ethics promote it, agency leaders and practitioners are given little guidance on how to design participation initiatives that integrate stakeholders' input into agency decision making. This article focuses on creating a strategy that can foster meaningful stakeholder participation. We outline 7 principles of meaningful participation and present a 12-step process for formulating a participation strategy that applies these principles. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+a+Strategy+to+Meaningfully+Engage+Stakeholders+in+Program%2FPolicy+Planning%3A+A+Guide+for+Human+Services+Managers+and+Practitioners&amp;rft.au=Woodford%2C+Michael+R%3BPreston%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Woodford&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2011-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=159&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.571091

Document 418 of 487

The Experiential Community Assessment Project: Integrating Social Work Practice Skills

Author: Timm, Tina1; Birkenmaier, Julie; Tebb, Susan1 School of Social Work, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/902080775?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although most social work students are primarily interested in micro practice, the Council on Social Work Education mandates teaching macro practice. The challenge of incorporating meaningful and relevant community assignments within practice courses is noted in the literature (Koerin, Reeves, & Rosenblum, 2000). This article discusses the Experiential Community Assessment Project (ECAP) that integrates social work practice skills through interviewing a community leader, attending a community meeting, and using publicly available data to assess at risk neighborhoods. Grounded in experiential learning theory, a series of reflection papers are used to help students process what they are learning. A capstone poster presentation is required at the end. Suggestions and recommendations are made for using or adapting this project within other social work curricula. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Experiential+Community+Assessment+Project%3A+Integrating+Social+Work+Practice+Skills&amp;rft.au=Timm%2C+Tina%3BBirkenmaier%2C+Julie%3BTebb%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Timm&amp;rft.aufirst=Tina&amp;rft.date=2011-04-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.569649

Engaging Youth in Community Practice-An Imperative for the Future

Author: Simmons, Louise; Harding, Scott

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/919904367?accountid=14667

Abstract: Introduction to journal issue devoted to youth and their social engagement in meaningful activities. Adapted from the source document.

Document 420 of 487

Tagging Walls and Planting Seeds: Creating Spaces for Youth Civic Action

Author: Richards-Schuster, Katie1; Dobbie, David1 School of Social Work, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/919904372?accountid=14667

Abstract: Youth civic spaces are environments in which youth participation in civic action is fostered-the pathways, structures, and vehicles that provide opportunities for young people to engage in critical discussion, dialogue, and action. The concept of youth civic space includes the formal and informal places in which youth civic engagement can occur and how the lived experience of those places contributes to young people's development as civic actors. It extends discussions regarding the physical locations of youth civic engagement to include the activities, perceptions, and interactions within them. Drawing on archival materials from 2 multiyear projects, this article explores the role of community-based organizations in mediating youth civic action and understanding the characteristics and qualities of the organizations that facilitate youth engagement in community action and social change. We use this analysis of empirical examples to develop a conceptual framework for strengthening practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Tagging+Walls+and+Planting+Seeds%3A+Creating+Spaces+for+Youth+Civic+Action&amp;rft.au=Richards-Schuster%2C+Katie%3BDobbie%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Richards-Schuster&amp;rft.aufirst=Katie&amp;rft.date=2011-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=234&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.595283

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Tagging+Walls+and+Planting+Seeds%3A+Creating+Spaces+for+Youth+Civic+Action&amp;rft.au=Richards-Schuster%2C+Katie%3BDobbie%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Richards-Schuster&amp;rft.aufirst=Katie&amp;rft.date=2011-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=234&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.595283

Document 421 of 487

The Community Action Framework in Practice: An Illustration Based on the Ready by 21 Coalition of Austin/Travis County

Author: Travis, Raphael Jr1; Leech, Tamara G J1 School of Social Work, Texas State University, San Marcos, Texas, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/919904375?accountid=14667

Abstract: The field of positive youth development has expanded focus from articulating and measuring desired manifestations of positive well-being to assembling the environmental conditions known to promote these desired outcomes. Evidence of the effectiveness of community-level efforts promoting positive youth development is still emerging, in particular theory-driven examples of community-driven youth development. This study examined the Community Action Framework, one theory-based community youth development model, through the experiences of the Ready by 21 Austin/Travis County coalition (RB21). The coalition connects youth-serving organizations and also regional coalitions, while promoting the positive development of area youth. Participant observation, interviewing, and archival strategies were integrated to capture information related to the complex and dynamic coalition. Results indicated that RB21 represents a practical and meaningful application of the Community Action Framework. Specific examples and recommendations are provided as guidance for other community level youth development efforts. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Community+Action+Framework+in+Practice%3A+An+Illustration+Based+on+the+Ready+by+21+Coalition+of+Austin%2FTravis+County&amp;rft.au=Travis%2C+Raphael+Jr%3BLeech%2C+Tamara+G+J&amp;rft.aulast=Travis&amp;rft.aufirst=Raphael&amp;rft.date=2011-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=252&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.595288

Document 422 of 487

Precarious Partnerships: Designing a Community Needs Assessment to Develop a System of Care for Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual, Transgender and Questioning (GLBTQ) Youths

Author: Craig, Shelley L11 Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/919904378?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the planning and implementation of a mixed-method community needs assessment with the intent of creating a system of care for gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, and questioning (GLBTQ) youths in an urban area. Flowing from qualitative to quantitative research strategies, this needs assessment utilized key informant interviews, focus groups, and survey research in a countywide initiative. Rather than outline each set of findings, this article provides a brief description of the four phases of research activities and the action steps that were completed during each phase. Community context for the needs assessment is described in detail and a final system of care is proposed. Notable barriers and challenges associated with the community needs assessment are also articulated. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Precarious+Partnerships%3A+Designing+a+Community+Needs+Assessment+to+Develop+a+System+of+Care+for+Gay%2C+Lesbian%2C+Bisexual%2C+Transgender+and+Questioning+%28GLBTQ%29+Youths&amp;rft.au=Craig%2C+Shelley+L&amp;rft.aulast=Craig&amp;rft.aufirst=Shelley&amp;rft.date=2011-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=274&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.595301

An Examination of Foster Parent Unionization: The Washington State Experience

Author: Rome, Sunny Harris1; Blome, Wendy Whiting; Raskin, Miriam1 Department of Social Work, George Mason University, Fairfax, Virginia, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/919904392?accountid=14667

Abstract: In 2006, the Washington Federation of State Employees charted new territory by initiating an effort to unionize foster parents. Using a case study approach, we describe the development of this unique alliance, perspectives of stakeholder groups, and the social and economic conditions surrounding the organizing effort. Implications for policy and community practice are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Document 424 of 487

Upper Middle Class NIMBY in Phoenix: The Community Dynamics of the Development Process in the Arcadia Neighborhood

Author: Buckman, Stephen T11 School of Geographical Sciences and Urban Planning, Arizona State University, Tempe, Arizona, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/919904395?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article highlights the role that neighborhood activism plays in the development process. The article particularly highlights the Arcadia Camelback Neighborhood Association's (ACMNA) fight against, and collaboration with, developers at the intersection of 44th Street and Camelback Road in Phoenix, AZ, where issues of place, community empowerment, and attitudes of not-in-my-back- yard (NIMBYism) played out. The role of neighborhood activism is evaluated using interview, survey, and archival data, including news media reports and meeting minutes, with regards to the ACMNA and struggles to stave off development. The results of the research point out that the community is essential in shaping the development process and that without community support including collaboration between communities and developers, major development projects face a difficult road to completion, this is particularly evident when wealthy neighborhood NIMBY campaigns are at the forefront of the debate over development. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Upper+Middle+Class+NIMBY+in+Phoenix%3A+The+Community+Dynamics+of+the+Development+Process+in+the+Arcadia+Neighborhood&amp;rft.au=Buckman%2C+Stephen+T&amp;rft.aulast=Buckman&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2011-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=308&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.595306

Document 426 of 487

Rebuilding Community Organizing Education in Social Work

Author: Fisher, Robert1; Corciullo, Danielle1 School of Social Work, University of Connecticut, West Hartford, Connecticut, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266147941?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although the campaign and election of Barack Obama as the nation's first President with a background in community organizing (CO) has boosted the visibility and popularity of the field, graduate social work programs have not taken full advantage of the opportunity. This article, therefore, presents a three-fold argument regarding the future of CO education. There is an increasing demand and need for trained organizers and community organizing education. This historical moment holds significant potential for CO education in social work. Graduate schools of social work with CO programs should broaden their outreach to attract potential students and activists to careers as social change agents. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Rebuilding+Community+Organizing+Education+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Fisher%2C+Robert%3BCorciullo%2C+Danielle&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2011-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=355&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.625537

Document 427 of 487

Advanced Concentration Macro Competencies for Social Work Practitioners: Identifying Knowledge, Values, Judgment and Skills to Promote Human Well-Being

Author: Gamble, Dorothy N11 School of Social Work, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, North Carolina, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266147951?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Association of Community Organization and Social Administration (ACOSA) was formed in 1987-88; thereafter, the annual ACOSA meetings became part of the Council on Social Work Education's (CSWE) Annual Program Meeting (Roberts-DeGennaro, 2002). ACOSA's purpose is "to promote teaching, research, and social work practice in the areas of community organization and social administration" (ACOSA, 2011a). Most schools of social work have some required content for students in the areas of policy practice, program development, community planning, organizational development, administration, management, and community and neighborhood organizing. Organizational members sought to support these areas with research, best practice identification, and effective teaching/learning strategies. Adapted from the source document.

Document 428 of 487

Right-Wing Organizers Do This Too: The Case of the Christian Coalition

Author: Fisher, Robert1; Tamarkin, Sally1 School of Social Work, University of Connecticut, West Hartford, Connecticut, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266147961?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article documents and evaluates the organizing strategies of the Christian Coalition in the 1990s. Unlike most other Christian Right efforts, the Christian Coalition strongly emphasized a grassroots component in a social movement strategy that combined local efforts with a national organization. This study informs three debates in the field of community organizing: whether anything of value can be learned from right-wing organizing; whether contemporary organizing should remain focused on the local community or build power at the national level as well; and whether there is a place for mobilizing strategies in progressive community organizing. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Right-Wing+Organizers+Do+This+Too%3A+The+Case+of+the+Christian+Coalition&amp;rft.au=Fisher%2C+Robert%3BTamarkin%2C+Sally&amp;rft.aulast=Fisher&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2011-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=403&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.625540

Document 429 of 487

The Community Organization Method in Social Work Education (1959)

Author: Stuart, Paul H11 School of Social Work, Florida International University, Miami, Florida, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148593?accountid=14667

Abstract: For this themed issue on the state of community practice, "From the Archives" presents excerpts from The Community Organization Method in Social Work Education by Harry L. Lurie. This report was published as volume IV of the Council on Social Work Education's landmark Curriculum Study (New York: Council on Social Work Education, 1959). Published 7 years after the merger of the American Association of Schools of Social Work and the National Association of Schools of Social Administration resulted in the creation of the new Council on Social Work Education, and 4 years after the merger of seven practitioner organizations resulted in the creation of the National Association of Social Workers, the curriculum study represented an attempt to define educational requirements for a newly-united profession. In the excerpts that follow, Lurie speculates on the reasons for the small number of community organization jobs in social work and the low enrollments in the community organization concentrations which existed in schools of social work during the 1950s. He attempts to explain why the development of community organization practice theory had lagged behind the development of practice theory in casework. However, he states reasons for believing that progress in the development of practice theory -- and of practice opportunities -- can be expected and discusses the place of community organization in social work. The excerpts conclude with Lurie's definitions of education for community organization and of community organization practice in social work. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Community+Organization+Method+in+Social+Work+Education+%281959%29&amp;rft.au=Stuart%2C+Paul+H&amp;rft.aulast=Stuart&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2011-10-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=422&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2011.625541

EU-US Symposium on Community and Social Development: A Transatlantic Dialogue on Comparative Perspectives on the State of Community Work and Social Inclusion-A Summary Report on the Proceedings of May 5-7, 2011 at the University of Pittsburgh

Author: Soska, Tracy M1; Teixeira, Samantha; Legault, Stephen; Crawford, Kyle; Hardoby, Melissa1 School of Social Work, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1266148599?accountid=14667

Abstract: On May 5 -- 7, 2011, nearly 40 scholars, educators, and practitioner-educators from 10 European countries and the United States gathered with regional educators and practitioners at the University of Pittsburgh for the "EU/US Symposium on Community and Social Development: A Transatlantic Dialogue on Comparative Perspectives on the State of Community Work and Social Inclusion." This article is a very limited attempt to provide a sense of the rich dialogue and exchange of ideas, as well as to frame the discussion, questions, priorities, and agenda that emerged from the symposium. Adapted from the source document.

Document 431 of 487

The Grassroots Londolozi Model of African Development: Social Empathy in Action

Author: Groch, Kate1; Gerdes, Karen E; Segal, Elizabeth A; Groch, Maureen1 Good Work Foundation, Philippolis, Free State, South Africa, kegerdes@asu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1551620704?accountid=14667

Abstract: Aid efforts in Africa often fail, sometimes increasing the very problems they are meant to ease. A grassroots effort we call the Londolozi model is bringing local South Africans out of poverty by restoring their homeland's ecosystem. Based on principles of social empathy to develop local ecotourism, the model demonstrates how it is possible to generate a small, medium, and micro-enterprise economy that creates jobs for the local community. In addition, the Londolozi learning center and the private, not-for-profit Good Work Foundation have worked in partnership with the local community to offer adult literacy training, educational opportunities for children and youth, AIDS education, and other sustainable services necessary to end poverty. The basic precepts of the Londolozi model and principles of social empathy can be used to promote social development in other parts of Africa, as well as in other regions of the world.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Assamodule&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Grassroots+Londolozi+Model+of+African+Development%3A+Social+Empathy+in+Action&amp;rft.au=Groch%2C+Kate%3BGerdes%2C+Karen+E%3BSegal%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BGroch%2C+Maureen&amp;rft.aulast=Groch&amp;rft.aufirst=Kate&amp;rft.date=2012-01-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=154&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.644207

Document 432 of 487

Strategies for Preventing Neighborhood Violence: Toward Bringing Collective Efficacy into Social Work Practice

Author: Beck, Elizabeth1; Ohmer, Mary; Warner, Barbara1 Center for Collaborative Social Work, Georgia State University, Atlanta, Georgia, USA Ebeck@gsu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567043479?accountid=14667

Abstract: Neighborhood violence has profound effects on issues associated with social work practice, such as health, safety, and the positive development of children, youth, and families. This article brings together the literatures in criminology and public health that examine violence and social work's history in community practice to develop violence prevention strategies. One important concept from the criminology and public health literatures is collective efficacy, defined as neighbors having shared values, trust, and a willingness to intervene in neighborhood problems. By building on the community practice literature and studies from peacemaking criminology, the article provides examples of ways that collective efficacy can be built and implemented in low income neighborhoods. Strategies include awareness of collective efficacy, relationship building, bystander education, and restorative justice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Strategies+for+Preventing+Neighborhood+Violence%3A+Toward+Bringing+Collective+Efficacy+into+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Beck%2C+Elizabeth%3BOhmer%2C+Mary%3BWarner%2C+Barbara&amp;rft.aulast=Beck&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=225&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.700278

Document 433 of 487

Race, Power and Social Action in Neighborhood Community Organizing: Reproducing and Resisting the Social Construction of the Other

Author: Lavoie, Carmen11 Lavoie Consulting, North Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada Carmen_lavoie@yahoo.com

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567043492?accountid=14667

Abstract: Scholars argue in favor of social action in community organizing to address the oppression experienced by racialized groups. This study examines how community organizing practice in one diverse neighborhood constructed race to understand the potential for social action. Using interview and observational data with 16 community organizers working in 1 diverse, low-income neighborhood in Quebec, Canada, I examine the social construction of race through the lens of postcolonial theory and the writings of Michel Foucault. I argue that a discourse of neutrality existed among community organizers, which was tied to state policy and a colonial discourse embedded therein. The resulting disconnect between race and power in community organizing practice not only forecloses on social change efforts, it also extends a state-driven nation-building agenda into community. As the basis for an anticolonial approach to neighborhood community organizing, I juxtapose the discourse of neutrality in community organizing with strategies that recoupled race and power by drawing attention to efforts among community organizers that were antagonistic to the discourse. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Race%2C+Power+and+Social+Action+in+Neighborhood+Community+Organizing%3A+Reproducing+and+Resisting+the+Social+Construction+of+the+Other&amp;rft.au=Lavoie%2C+Carmen&amp;rft.aulast=Lavoie&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmen&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=241&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.700277

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Race%2C+Power+and+Social+Action+in+Neighborhood+Community+Organizing%3A+Reproducing+and+Resisting+the+Social+Construction+of+the+Other&amp;rft.au=Lavoie%2C+Carmen&amp;rft.aulast=Lavoie&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmen&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=241&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.700277

Document 434 of 487

Community-Based Participatory Research as a Social Work Research and Intervention Approach

Author: Branom, Christina11 School of Social Welfare, University of California, Berkeley, California, USA cbranom@berkeley.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044314?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers are now often expected to base their practice on solid empirical findings, but research can vary in terms of its usefulness and relevance to practice. Some social workers have criticized traditional research approaches, suggesting that they are not consistent with the profession's mission to serve vulnerable and disadvantaged populations (e.g., Finn, 1994). Community-based participatory action research may be an appropriate alternative that is participatory, empowering, and committed to social justice (Minkler & Wallerstein, 2008). This article explores the connection between social work and CBPR, illustrating how CBPR can contribute significantly to achieving the field's goals. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community-Based+Participatory+Research+as+a+Social+Work+Research+and+Intervention+Approach&amp;rft.au=Branom%2C+Christina&amp;rft.aulast=Branom&amp;rft.aufirst=Christina&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.699871

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community-Based+Participatory+Research+as+a+Social+Work+Research+and+Intervention+Approach&amp;rft.au=Branom%2C+Christina&amp;rft.aulast=Branom&amp;rft.aufirst=Christina&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.699871

Document 435 of 487

Monitoring Human Rights of Persons in Police Lockups: Potential Role of Community-Based Organizations

Author: Hounmenou, Charles11 Jane Addams College of Social Work, University of Illinois, Chicago, Illinois, USA chounm2@uic.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567042964?accountid=14667

Abstract: Little research has been done about detention conditions in police lockups. Unlike prisons, no system is in place to monitor police lockups in the United States. Yet, research shows that most police abuse issues occur while persons are in police custody. Good practices of community-visiting mechanisms in a few countries show that community-based groups can play an important role in helping to protect the basic human rights of persons in police lockups. This article examines how community organizations can collaborate with civilian review agencies to monitor detention conditions and treatment in police custody in the American context. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Monitoring+Human+Rights+of+Persons+in+Police+Lockups%3A+Potential+Role+of+Community-Based+Organizations&amp;rft.au=Hounmenou%2C+Charles&amp;rft.aulast=Hounmenou&amp;rft.aufirst=Charles&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=274&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.700279

Document 436 of 487

An Emerging Typology of Community Aging Initiatives

Author: Lehning, Amanda1; Scharlach, Andrew; Wolf, Jennifer Price1 School of Social Work, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, USA alehning@umich.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567043001?accountid=14667

Abstract: A growing number of initiatives across the country are working to bring about comprehensive changes in community physical and social environments to help older persons meet their long-term care needs and age in place. This study seeks to address gaps in the literature by developing a typology of community aging initiatives and examining variations in community change processes, including the methods they use, roles of participants, funding sources, and challenges. Based on responses to online surveys and the existing community change literature, 124 initiatives were grouped into 5 categories: (a) communitywide planning, (b) consumer-driven support networks, (c) cross-sector systems change initiatives, (d) residence-based support services, and (e) single-sector services. This emerging typology may serve as a useful organizing framework from which to develop future evaluations of the effectiveness and sustainability of these initiatives. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Emerging+Typology+of+Community+Aging+Initiatives&amp;rft.au=Lehning%2C+Amanda%3BScharlach%2C+Andrew%3BWolf%2C+Jennifer+Price&amp;rft.aulast=Lehning&amp;rft.aufirst=Amanda&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=293&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.700175

Document 437 of 487

Increasing Both Organizational and Client Capacities During Tough Economic Times: An Examination of the Consumer and Incentive-Based Ambassador Volunteer Program

Author: Hopkins, Karen M1; Meyer, Megan; McLennan, William; Sharp, Jason; Sheffield, Katie1 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, Maryland, USA khopkins@ssw.umaryland.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044584?accountid=14667

Abstract: Various economic and societal conditions are making it more difficult for community-based agencies to sustain volunteer programs. Therefore, concerned managers have to become creative in designing their volunteer programs. This article examines an innovative consumer and incentive Ambassador Volunteer Program designed to meet the dual goals of building the employment capacities of consumers and the volunteer capacity of the agency in a disadvantaged urban community. Survey, focus group, and interview data help detail the structure of the program, assess its benefits to volunteers, and examine its strengths and limitations as viewed through the experiences of both the volunteers and staff. Adapted from the source document.

Document 438 of 487

'A Dead Battery' Aubrey Williams' Undated Auto-Biographical Account of His Work with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the New Deal

Author: Venturini, Vincent11 Department of Social Work, Mississippi Valley State University, Itta Bena, Mississippi, USA vincent@mvsu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567046010?accountid=14667

Abstract: The New Deal transformed the involvement of the Federal Government in the distribution of relief to persons left destitute due to economic depressions. So dominant is the New Deal in historical presentations of the efforts to end the Great Depression, many social workers assume that before the Presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt and his assignment of Harry Hopkins as the Director of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA), there was no Federal involvement in the distribution of relief. Actually, the seeds for many of the innovations credited to Roosevelt and Hopkins were planted by social workers assisting the Reconstruction Finance Corporation (RFC) with relief loans made to the states late in the Hoover Administration. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%27A+Dead+Battery%27+Aubrey+Williams%27+Undated+Auto-Biographical+Account+of+His+Work+with+the+Reconstruction+Finance+Corporation+and+the+New+Deal&amp;rft.au=Venturini%2C+Vincent&amp;rft.aulast=Venturini&amp;rft.aufirst=Vincent&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=336&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.700302

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%27A+Dead+Battery%27+Aubrey+Williams%27+Undated+Auto-Biographical+Account+of+His+Work+with+the+Reconstruction+Finance+Corporation+and+the+New+Deal&amp;rft.au=Venturini%2C+Vincent&amp;rft.aulast=Venturini&amp;rft.aufirst=Vincent&amp;rft.date=2012-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=336&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.700302

The Road Not Taken ...

Author: Butterfield, Alice K; Soska, Tracy M

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567042866?accountid=14667

Abstract: This fourth issue in Volume 20 of the Journal of Community Practice (JCP) marks a crossroads in several respects. This issue marks the last issue compiled by the editor team of Alice K. Butterfield, Tracy M. Soska, Louise Simmons, and Scott Harding. For Louise Simmons and Scott Harding, this is the end of a challenging and exciting 5-year run guiding the content of this important macro practice journal. For Alice K. Butterfield, it marks the end of 10 years of service and scholarly leadership for the Journal of Community Practice. For Tracy M. Soska, the next issue in Volume 21 will mark the beginning of a second 5-year term with new editorial colleagues, Lorraine Gutierrez and Anna Maria Santiago. Therefore, it is an important crossroad issue. Over the past 5 years, the Butterfield-Soska-Simmons-Harding team has seen its mission of growing the global reach of the Journal and in expanding its interdisciplinary focus. Although we have sought to retain a strong social work base, we were encouraged by our editorial board and Association for Community Organization and Social Administration (ACOSA) board and leadership to ensure JCP offered a broader geographic and multidisciplinary reach that sometimes challenged our presence and stance in social work. Adapted from the source document.

Document 440 of 487

Transforming Communities: Restorative Justice as a Community Building Strategy

Author: Beck, Elizabeth11 School of Social Work, Georgia State University, School of Social Work, Atlanta, Georgia, USA ebeck@gsu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044307?accountid=14667

Abstract: Restorative justice is entering the social work literature as a strategy that can transform lives harmed by violence. However, the literature has yet to explore how restorative justice can transform communities. Despite the lack of published information, communities across the globe and the United States are experiencing important benefits from restorative justice-based interventions. This article explores 4 restorative justice strategies that seek to transform communities: restorative boards, community conferencing, community restorative support, and truth and reconciliation commissions. The examination of the strategies includes case studies that are used to support a larger discussion of application, practice, outcomes, evaluation literature, and critiques. Adapted from the source document.

Document 441 of 487

The Durham Community Land Trustees

Author: Gray, Karen A1; Miller-Cribbs, Julie E1 School of Social Work, University of Oklahoma, Tulsa, Oklahoma, USA karen.gray@ou.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044806?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the possible impact of the Durham Community Land Trustees (DCLT) on home-owner-occupied rates and median rent in Durham since 1990. Establishing causality in community-based interventions is difficult due to the pragmatic barriers. However, by matching the DCLT census tract to other tracts and comparing them to Durham, the DCLT census tract changes were better isolated. This study used the Neighborhood Change Database to explore the neighborhood characteristics of the DCLT and similar neighborhoods and to test for differences in key housing variables. The results enhance knowledge of CLTs and ways they might contribute to community change. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Durham+Community+Land+Trustees&amp;rft.au=Gray%2C+Karen+A%3BMiller-Cribbs%2C+Julie+E&amp;rft.aulast=Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2012-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=402&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.731638

Document 442 of 487

Promoting Bank Accounts to Low-Income Households: Implications for Social Work Practice

Author: Birkenmaier, Julie11 School of Social Work, Saint Louis University, St. Louis, Missouri, USA birkenjm@slu.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567043183?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the wake of the recent economic challenges, it is clear that social workers must be educated about the financial opportunities for low-income households. Encouraging low-income households to have a bank account at an insured depository institution, or become banked, is increasingly emphasized in policy and practice. Becoming banked offers the opportunity to avoid high-cost alternative financial services. Social workers can facilitate relationships between low-income households and the mainstream financial services industry to help families advance their long-term financial interest. Understanding the structure of all types of banks and credit unions is imperative. Implications for social work practice are explored. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+Bank+Accounts+to+Low-Income+Households%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Birkenmaier%2C+Julie&amp;rft.aulast=Birkenmaier&amp;rft.aufirst=Julie&amp;rft.date=2012-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=414&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.732004

Document 443 of 487

Strength in Process: Using Concept Mapping to Inform Community Coalition Development

Author: Miller, J Jay1; Rhema, Susan; Faul, Anna; D'Ambrosio, Joseph; Yankeelov, Pamela; Amer, Rhonda; Clark, Rebecca1 Kent School of Social Work, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY, USA justin.miller@louisville.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567045777?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study reports on the use of Concept Mapping to delineate a conceptual framework germane to the planning and initial formation of tri-county rural diabetes coalition in a southeast US community. The focus of the tricounty coalition is to reduce diabetes-related inequalities in vulnerable populations. After a review of pertinent literature on community coalitions, this article explicates Concept Mapping processes utilized to plan and organize the formation of a coalition, offers analyses of the results, and discusses implications for current and future practices pertaining to community coalition work. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Strength+in+Process%3A+Using+Concept+Mapping+to+Inform+Community+Coalition+Development&amp;rft.au=Miller%2C+J+Jay%3BRhema%2C+Susan%3BFaul%2C+Anna%3BD%27Ambrosio%2C+Joseph%3BYankeelov%2C+Pamela%3BAmer%2C+Rhonda%3BClark%2C+Rebecca&amp;rft.aulast=Miller&amp;rft.aufirst=J&amp;rft.date=2012-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=432&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.736074

Document 444 of 487

Finding Missing Families: A Community Collaboration to Prevent Child Abuse and Neglect

Author: Dettlaff, Alan J1; Ferrari, Susan; Cheong, Pat1 Jane Addams College of Social Work, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, Illinois, USA

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567043962?accountid=14667

Abstract: When families move to avoid a child protection investigation or otherwise cannot be located, the children in those families remain at continued risk of maltreatment and the potentially severe consequences. Following the death of a 9-year-old boy in Texas, whose family moved repeatedly to avoid investigation, child welfare administrators collaborated with United Way and a community-based private investigator to develop and implement an innovative strategy to address this issue. This article provides a description of this project, results of the program evaluation, and implications for child welfare agencies. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Finding+Missing+Families%3A+A+Community+Collaboration+to+Prevent+Child+Abuse+and+Neglect&amp;rft.au=Dettlaff%2C+Alan+J%3BFerrari%2C+Susan%3BCheong%2C+Pat&amp;rft.aulast=Dettlaff&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan&amp;rft.date=2012-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=457&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.736073

Document 445 of 487

Urban and Indigenous: The Challenges of being a Native American in the City

Author: Weaver, Hilary N11 School of Social Work, State University of New York at Buffalo, Buffalo, New York, USA hweaver@buffalo.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044312?accountid=14667

Abstract: The United States is home to more than 4 million Native Americans, the majority of whom live in urban areas. Urban Native Americans often experience significant social, health, and economic problems while having access to substantially fewer Native-specific resources than their reservation-based counterparts. They also face challenges with access to tribal services and political processes, as well as identity-sustaining cultural resources. This article describes the urban nature of many contemporary Native American communities. Examples from various urban Native American communities highlight the challenges faced by urban Native people, as well as creative initiatives developed to serve this population. This paper draws on and synthesizes the literature on contemporary urban Native communities, thus providing needed information for service providers and researchers working in these communities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Urban+and+Indigenous%3A+The+Challenges+of+being+a+Native+American+in+the+City&amp;rft.au=Weaver%2C+Hilary+N&amp;rft.aulast=Weaver&amp;rft.aufirst=Hilary&amp;rft.date=2012-10-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=470&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2012.732001

Document 446 of 487

At the Intersection of Community Practice and Health Practice: Building Stronger and Healthier Communities

Author: Soska, Tracy M; Gutierrez, Lorraine; Santiago, Anna Maria

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044798?accountid=14667

Abstract: The connection between health and place is an increasingly vital focus for social workers, public health professionals, community psychologists, urban planners and others for whom community practice and health practice are intrinsically intertwined. As the Association for Community Organization and Social Administration (ACOSA), who sponsors the Journal of Community Practice, has engaged in a growing dialogue with kindred organizations and associations both nationally and internationally, we also have been evolving a common literature weaving our practice, teaching, research, and scholarship with threads of knowledge, values, and skills that embraces community organizing and community building for stronger and healthier communities. Adapted from the source document.

Document 447 of 487

Community Organizing for Health Care: An Analysis of the Process

Author: Bezboruah, Karabi C11 School of Urban and Public Affairs, University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, Texas bezborua@uta.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567046071?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the community organizing process for better health services for disenfranchised populations that cannot afford medical care in an affluent community. In response, concerned citizens and voluntary organizations have attempted to organize to transform policies and to implement new healthcare services. The author adopts a researcher participant role and examines the organizing process by studying six nonprofit agencies, one public health office, and shadowing the community organizer. The paper concludes that community organizing can be an especially challenging process when strategies are misaligned, stakeholders are dissentaneous, the public is apathetic to needs of low-income people, and solutions are diverse. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Organizing+for+Health+Care%3A+An+Analysis+of+the+Process&amp;rft.au=Bezboruah%2C+Karabi+C&amp;rft.aulast=Bezboruah&amp;rft.aufirst=Karabi&amp;rft.date=2013-01-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2013.788328

Document 448 of 487

Effective Pluralistic Participation: Case Study of a Community Health Worker Partnership in Miami, Florida

Author: Concha, Maritza1; Villar, Maria Elena1 College of Health and Public Affairs, University of Central Florida, Orlando, Florida

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1567044838?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article analyzes the participation of community health workers (CHWs) in a community partnership. Active participation at all levels is needed for effective influence on the goals of the partnership. This case applies the criteria of pluralistic participation, specifically: (a) role of groups involved, (b) opportunity for learning, (c) access to officials, and (d) means of coercion. By applying a pluralistic democratic approach to community participation of CHWs in Miami, this article explores how CHWs, funding agencies, service organizations, community residents, researchers, and public health officials brought together resources, knowledge and influence to empower community health workers. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Effective+Pluralistic+Participation%3A+Case+Study+of+a+Community+Health+Worker+Partnership+in+Miami%2C+Florida&amp;rft.au=Concha%2C+Maritza%3BVillar%2C+Maria+Elena&amp;rft.aulast=Concha&amp;rft.aufirst=Maritza&amp;rft.date=2013-01-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1-2&amp;rft.spage=28&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2013.788329
